oppress.eng_def: to govern people in an unfair and cruel way and prevent them from having opportunities and freedom
oppress.eg: For years now, the people have been oppressed by a ruthless dictator.

oppress.eng_def: to make a person feel uncomfortable or worried, and sometimes ill
oppress.eg: Strange dreams and nightmares oppressed him.

oppression.eng_def: a situation in which people are governed in an unfair and cruel way and prevented from having opportunities and freedom
oppression.eg: Every human being has the right to freedom from oppression.

oppression.eng_def: a feeling of being very uncomfortable and worried
oppression.eg: Several people had experienced the same feeling of oppression when they slept in that room.

optimism.eng_def: the quality of being full of hope and emphasizing the good parts of a situation, or a belief that something good will happen
optimism.eg: There was a note of optimism in his voice as he spoke about the company's future.

optimistic.eng_def: hoping or believing that good things will happen in the future
optimistic.eg: She is optimistic about her chances of winning a gold medal.

option.eng_def: one thing that can be chosen from a set of possibilities, or the freedom to make a choice
option.eg: The best option would be to cancel the trip altogether.

option.eng_def: the right to buy something in the future
to have to do a particular thing because there is no possibility of doing anything else
option.eg: After her appalling behaviour, we had no option but to dismiss her.

optional.eng_def: If something is optional, you can choose if you want to do it, pay it, buy it, etc.
optional.eg: English is compulsory for all students, but art and music are optional.

or.chi_def: （用於連接不同的可能性）或，或者；還是，亦或
or.eg: Is it Tuesday or Wednesday today?

or.eng_def: used after a negative verb to mean not one thing and also not another
or.eg: The child never smiles or laughs.
You should eat more, or you'll make yourself ill.

or.eng_def: used to show that a word or phrase means the same as, or explains, limits, or corrects, another word or phrase
or.chi_def: （用於引出同義詞、同義片語或解釋性、限定性、糾正性詞語或片語）或者說，也就是，即
or.eg: Rosalind, or Roz to her friends, took the initiative.

or.chi_def: 手術室（operating room 的縮寫）

or.eng_def: written abbreviation for the US state of Oregon: used in addresses
or.chi_def: （美國）俄勒岡州，奧勒岡州（寫地址時Oregon的縮寫）

oral.eng_def: of, taken by, or done to the mouth
an exam, often a type of language exam, in which you give spoken and not written answers
oral.chi_def: 口試（通常是一種語言的測驗，對問題做口頭而不是書面回答）
oral.eg: When do you have your Spanish oral (= exam in spoken Spanish)?

orange.eng_def: a round sweet fruit that has a thick orange skin and an orange centre divided into many parts
a colour between red and yellow
of a colour between red and yellow
orange.eg: The setting sun filled the sky with a deep orange glow.

orbit.eng_def: the curved path through which objects in space move around a planet or star
orbit.chi_def: （天體圍繞行星或恆星運行的）軌道
orbit.eg: The satellite is now in a stable orbit.

orbit.eng_def: to follow a curved path around a planet or star
orbit.chi_def: 繞軌道運行，沿軌道圍繞（行星或恆星）運行
orbit.eg: On this mission the Shuttle will orbit (the Earth) at a height of several hundred miles.

orchard.eng_def: an area of land where fruit trees (but not orange trees or other citrus trees) are grown

orchestra.eng_def: a large group of musicians who play many different instruments together and are led by a conductor
orchestra.eg: She's a cellist in the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra.

orchestra.eng_def: the seats on the main floor of a theatre or cinema, not at a higher level

ordeal.eng_def: a very unpleasant and painful or difficult experience
ordeal.chi_def: 磨難；苦難；嚴峻考驗；煎熬
ordeal.eg: The hostages' ordeal came to an end when soldiers stormed the building.

order.eng_def: a request to make, supply, or deliver food or goods
order.eg: "Can I take your order now?" said the waiter.

order.eng_def: a product or a meal that has been asked for by a customer
order.eg: I got an email saying that the order has been shipped.

order.eng_def: If something is on order, you have asked for it but have not yet received it.
order.eg: The new drilling equipment has been on order for several weeks.

order.eng_def: to do or make something especially for a person who has asked for it
order.eg: We make wedding cakes to order.

order.eng_def: the way in which people or things are arranged, either in relation to one another or according to a particular characteristic
order.eg: The children lined up in order of age/height.

order.eng_def: something that someone tells you you must do
order.eg: The soldiers fired as soon as their commander gave the order.

order.eng_def: to have been told that you must do something by someone in authority
order.chi_def: 命令就是命令，命令必須執行
order.eg: We are under orders not to allow anyone into the building.

order.eng_def: an official instruction telling someone what they can or cannot do, or a written instruction to a bank to pay money to a particular person
with the aim of achieving something
order.eg: He came home early in order to see the kids before they went to bed.

order.eng_def: a situation in which everything is arranged in its correct place
order.eg: The house was such a mess that she spent the whole day trying to establish some kind of order.

order.eng_def: to organize something well
order.chi_def: 使有條理；把…整理得井井有條
order.eg: I try to leave my desk in order when I go home.

order.eng_def: the state of working correctly or of being suitable for use
order.chi_def: 正常工作狀況；良好使用狀況
order.eg: TV for sale in (good) working order.

order.eng_def: a situation in which rules are obeyed and people do what they are expected to do
order.eg: The teacher found it hard to keep her class in order.

order.eng_def: an expression used in a parliament or a formal meeting to get people's attention and make them stop talking, so that the meeting or discussion can start or continue
order.chi_def: 安靜！安靜！（用於議會或正式會議中）

order.eng_def: a social or political system
order.eg: The collapse of Communism at the end of the 1980s encouraged hopes of a new world order.

order.eng_def: a group of people who join together for religious or similar reasons and live according to particular rules
order.chi_def: （按照一定規範生活的）修道會；會社
order.eg: religious/holy orders

order.eng_def: a group that people are made members of as a reward for services they have done for their country
order.eg: He was made a knight of the Order of the Garter.

order.eng_def: the type or size of something
order.eg: These were problems of a completely different order from anything we had faced before.

order.eng_def: approximately
order.eg: The cost will be something in the order of $500.

order.eng_def: (used in the classification of plants and animals) a group of related plants or animals
order.eg: An order is below a class and above a family.

order.eng_def: to ask for something to be made, supplied, or delivered, especially in a restaurant or shop
order.chi_def: （尤指在飯店或商店）點（飯菜），訂購，訂製，訂貨
order.eg: I ordered some pasta and a mixed salad.

order.eng_def: If a person in authority orders someone to do something, or orders something to be done, they tell someone to do it.
order.eg: The management has ordered a cutback in spending.

order.eng_def: to arrange a group of people or things in a list from first to last
order.eg: The documents have been ordered alphabetically.

orderly.eng_def: a hospital worker who does jobs for which no training is necessary, such as helping the nurses or carrying heavy things
orderly.eg: He has a part-time job as a hospital orderly.

orderly.eng_def: a soldier who acts as an officer's servant

orderly.eg: She put the letters in three orderly piles.

ordinary.eng_def: not different or special or unexpected in any way; usual
ordinary.chi_def: 普通的，平常的；平凡的；一般的

ordinary.eng_def: normally, or in the way that usually happens
ordinary.eg: If we hadn't seen the TV programme, we would have carried on giving money to the charity in the ordinary way.
For the police, the incident was nothing out of the ordinary/did not seem out of the ordinary.

organ.eng_def: a part of the body of an animal or plant that performs a particular job

a musical instrument with a keyboard in which sound is produced by air being forced through pipes of different sizes and lengths when you press the keys with your hands or feet, or in which sound is produced electronically
organ.eg: Electronic organs are much smaller and cheaper than pipe organs.

organ.eng_def: a newspaper or broadcasting station produced by a particular organization and giving only the opinions of that organization
organ.chi_def: （某組織的）喉舌，宣傳工具（指報紙或廣播電台）
organ.eg: The newspaper Pravda was the official organ of the Communist Party in the Soviet Union.

organic.eng_def: not using artificial chemicals in the growing of plants and animals for food and other products
being or coming from living plants and animals
organic.eg: A quarter of the contents of an average family's dustbin is organic matter.

organic.eng_def: (of a disease or illness) producing a physical change in the structure of an organ or part of the body
organic.chi_def: （疾病）器質性的，器官的，官能的

organic.eg: Organic chemicals are used in the manufacture of plastics, fibres, solvents and paints.

organism.eng_def: a single living plant, animal, virus, etc.
organism.eg: Amoebae and bacteria are single-celled organisms.

organization.eng_def: a group of people who work together in an organized way for a shared purpose
the planning of an activity or event
organization.eg: He didn't want to be involved in the organization of/for the conference, although he was willing to attend and speak.

organization.eng_def: the way in which something is done or arranged

organize.eng_def: to make arrangements for something to happen
organize.eg: They organized a meeting between the teachers and students.

organize.eng_def: to do or arrange something according to a particular system
organize.eg: The books were organized on the shelves according to their size.

organizer.eng_def: the person or group who plans and arranges an event or activity
organizer.eg: There aren't enough seats for all the guests - I must tell the organizers.

organizer.eng_def: a person who is able to plan things carefully
organizer.eg: We need someone who is a good organizer.

orient.eng_def: to aim something at someone or something, or make something suitable for a particular group of people
orient.chi_def: 以…為目標；使面向；使適應
orient.eg: It is essential that the public sector orientates itself more towards the consumer.

orient.eng_def: to discover your position in relation to what is around you
orient.chi_def: 確定自己的位置，識別方向
orient.eg: If you get lost while you are out walking, try to use the sun to orientate yourself.

origin.eng_def: the beginning or cause of something
origin.eg: It's a book about the origin of the universe.

origin.eng_def: used to describe the particular way in which something started to exist or someone started their life
origin.eg: The story has obscure origins (= no one knows how it started).
He is of North African origin.
The furniture was French in origin.

origin.eng_def: the end of a muscle attached to the bone that does not move when the muscle is used

original.eng_def: existing since the beginning, or being the earliest form of something
An original piece of work, such as a painting, etc. is produced by the artist and not a copy.
original.chi_def: 原作的，真跡的，非贗品的

original.eng_def: not the same as anything or anyone else and therefore special and interesting
original.chi_def: 獨創的，有創意的，新穎的

original.eng_def: the first one made and not a copy
original.eg: Can you give me the original of your report? I can't read this copy.

original.eng_def: a piece of work by a famous artist or designer and not a copy by someone else
original.eg: If the painting is an original, it will be very valuable.

original.eng_def: If you read something in the original, you read it in the language in which it was first written.

originality.eng_def: the quality of being special and interesting and not the same as anything or anyone else
originality.eg: We were impressed by the originality of the children's work.

originate.eng_def: to come from a particular place, time, situation, etc.
originate.eg: Although the technology originated in the UK, it has been developed in the US

originate.eng_def: to start something or cause it to happen
originate.eg: Who originated the saying "Small is beautiful"?

ornament.eng_def: an object that is beautiful rather than useful
decoration that is added to increase the beauty of something
ornament.eg: The building relies on clever design rather than on ornament for its impressive effect.
She ornamented her letters with little drawings in the margin.

orphan.eng_def: a child whose parents are dead
orphan.eg: The civil war is making orphans of many children.
He was orphaned as a baby (= his parents died when he was a baby).

orphanage.eng_def: a home for children whose parents are dead or unable to care for them

ostrich.eng_def: a very large bird from Africa that cannot fly
ostrich.eg: The ostrich is the fastest animal on two legs.

ostrich.eng_def: someone who says that a problem does not exist, because they do not want to deal with it
ostrich.chi_def: 逃避現實者，不願正視現實者
ostrich.eg: If you're an ostrich about your debts, you're only going to make matters worse.

other.eng_def: as well as the thing or person already mentioned
other.eg: The product has many other time-saving features.

other.eng_def: used at the end of a list to show that there are more things, without being exact about what they are
other.eg: The plan has been opposed by schools, businesses and other local organizations.

other.eng_def: the opposite side or end of something
other.eg: Put the chair at the other end of the desk.

other.eng_def: different from the thing or person already mentioned
other.eg: Idon't have any cash - is there no other way of paying?

other.eng_def: referring to a day, week, etc. in the recent past without saying exactly when it was
other.chi_def: （指最近某個大概的時間）那天/那個星期（等等）
other.eg: I saw him just the other day/night.
Cruises other than the ones listed below are not discounted at this time.

other.eng_def: in a negative sentence, used to mean "except"
other.eg: There's nothing on TV tonight, other than the usual rubbish.

other.eng_def: used to introduce an explanation that is simpler than the one given earlier
other.eg: He was economical with the truth - in other words, he was lying.

other.eng_def: used when you cannot or do not want to be exact about the information you are giving
other.eg: The event was held in some park or other.

other.eng_def: the second of two things or people, or the thing or person that is left in a group or set of things
other.chi_def: （兩者中的）另一個，第二個；（一組或一套中的）另一個
other.eg: Hold the racquet in one hand and the ball in the other.
I only know about this book, but there might be others (= other books).

other.eng_def: people in general, not including yourself
other.eg: You shouldn't expect others to do your work for you.

otherwise.eng_def: used after an order or suggestion to show what the result will be if you do not follow that order or suggestion
otherwise.eg: I'd better write it down, otherwise I'll forget it.
The police believe he is the thief, but all the evidence suggests otherwise (= that he is not).

otherwise.eng_def: except for what has just been referred to
otherwise.eg: The bike needs a new wheel, but otherwise it's in good condition.

otherwise.eng_def: used to show that something is completely different from what you think it is or from what was previously stated
otherwise.chi_def: 全然不是那樣的，根本不是那回事的
otherwise.eg: He might have told you he was a qualified electrician, but the truth is quite otherwise.

ought.eng_def: used to show when it is necessary or would be a good thing to perform the activity referred to by the following verb
ought.chi_def: （表示做某事有必要、值得或有利）應該，應當
ought.eg: You ought to be kinder to him.

ought.eng_def: used to express something that you expect will happen
ought.eg: He ought to be home by seven o'clock.

ounce.eng_def: a unit of weight equal to approximately 28 grams
ounce.chi_def: 盎司（重量單位，1盎司約等於28克）
ounce.eg: There are 16 ounces in one pound.
She can eat as much as she wants and she never puts on an ounce (= her weight does not increase).

out.eng_def: used to show movement away from the inside of a place or container
out.eg: She opened the window and stuck her head out.

out.eng_def: outside a building or room
out.eg: If you wait out here, we will call you when the doctor is ready.

out.eng_def: absent for a short time from the place where you live or work
out.chi_def: 暫時外出的，暫時不在的
out.eg: I came around to see you this morning, but you were out.

out.eng_def: used to refer to a period of time when someone goes away from home for a social activity
out.chi_def: 出去，外出（參加社交活動）
out.eg: I can't go out tonight - I have work to do.

out.eng_def: used to refer to a time when someone is away from the main office in order to do a particular job
out.eg: The thieves were spotted by a postman out on his rounds (= as he was delivering the post).

out.eng_def: In a library, if a book is out, it has been borrowed by someone.
out.chi_def: （圖書館的書）借出的，被借走的
out.eg: Both copies of "Wuthering Heights" were out.

out.eng_def: to the point where something is removed or disappears
out.eg: The stain won't come out.

out.eng_def: used to say that no more of something is available
out.eg: We're nearly out of petrol.

out.eng_def: (in sport) no longer able to play because your turn is over
out.eg: Two of the best players on the team were out after ten minutes.

out.eng_def: (in politics) no longer able to govern because you have lost an election
out.eg: The Social Democrats were voted out after 15 years in power.

out.eng_def: to many people
out.eg: The teacher gave out test books to all the students.

out.eng_def: spreading out from a central point over a wider area
out.eg: The police search party spread out across the fields.

out.eng_def: When a book, magazine, film, or musical recording is out, it is available to the public.
out.chi_def: （書、雜誌、電影、音樂帶等）出版，問世
out.eg: Is her new book out yet?

out.eng_def: able to be seen
out.eg: The stars are out tonight.

out.eng_def: used to make the meaning of a word stronger
out.chi_def: （用於增強詞義）完全地，徹底地
out.eg: We walked all day and were tired out (= very tired) by the time we got home.

out.eng_def: used with verbs describing sounds to emphasize the loudness of the sound
out.eg: He cried out in pain as he hit his head.

out.eng_def: a long distance away from land, a town, or your own country
out.chi_def: 離（大陸、城市或祖國）很遠，遙遠地
out.eg: The fishing boats were out at sea for three days.

out.eng_def: If a light or fire is out, it is no longer shining or burning.
out.eg: When we got home, all the lights were out.

out.eng_def: away from the coast or beach
out.eg: Is the tide coming in or going out?

out.eng_def: (of information) no longer kept secret
out.eg: You can't hide your gambling any longer - the secret's out.

out.eng_def: If a gay person comes out, they tell people that they are gay, and do not keep it a secret.
out.eg: She came out three years ago.

out.eng_def: (of a ball in a sport such as tennis) landing outside one of the lines that mark the area where the game is played
out.eg: He thought the ball had bounced on the line, but the umpire said it was out.

out.eng_def: unconscious or sleeping
out.chi_def: 不省人事的（地），昏迷的（地）；熟睡的（地）
out.eg: He passes out (= loses consciousness) at the sight of blood.

out.eng_def: not accurate
out.chi_def: 不準確的，錯誤的，有出入的
out.eg: Our estimates were only out by a few dollars.

out.eng_def: (used with superlatives) available or in existence
out.chi_def: （用於最高級後）可用地，現有地
out.eg: This is the best automatic camera out.

out.eng_def: used to show that a period of time is finished
out.eg: I think I can finish this project before the month's out.

out.eng_def: not acceptable or not possible
out.eg: Smoking is definitely out among my friends.

out.eng_def: no longer fashionable or popular
out.chi_def: 不再流行的（地）；不再時髦的（地）；過時的（地）
out.eg: Every month the magazine lists what's out and what's in (= fashionable).

out.eng_def: doing something, or intending to do something, for an unpleasant reason or only because it is good for you and not others
out.chi_def: （常出於自私或令人不快的動機）做，意圖做（或得到），蓄意
out.eg: She doesn't usually help the charity - she's only out for the publicity.

out.eng_def: to publish the fact that a famous person is gay, especially when that person does not want it to be known
out.chi_def: 公開（名人）的同性戀身份
out.eg: Hardly a week went by without someone famous being outed.

out.eng_def: an excuse or reason for avoiding an unpleasant situation
out.eg: We must arrange the negotiations so we have an out if we need it.

out.eng_def: People who are on the outs have argued and are not now friendly with each other.
out.eg: Lizzie and Tyler are on the outs again.

out.eng_def: used to add the meaning "not central" to nouns and adjectives
out.chi_def: （用於給名詞和形容詞加上「非中心的」之意）
out.eg: the outskirts of town (= the areas that form the edge of the town)

out.eng_def: used to add the meaning "going further" or "being better than" to verbs
out.chi_def: （用於給動詞加上「超越」或「勝過」之意）
out.eg: She doesn't drink or smoke and I'm sure she'll outlive (= live longer than) us all.

out.eng_def: used to add the meaning "out of" or "away from" to nouns and adjectives
out.chi_def: （用於給名詞和形容詞加上「向外」或「離開」之意）
out.eg: She turned away from their outstretched hands (= hands held out).

outbreak.eng_def: a time when something suddenly begins, especially a disease or something else dangerous or unpleasant
outbreak.chi_def: （尤指疾病、危險或不快之事的）發作，暴發，突然發生

outcome.eng_def: a result or effect of an action, situation, etc.
outcome.eg: It's too early to predict the outcome of the meeting.

outdo.eng_def: to be, or do something, better than someone else
outdo.eg: He always tries to outdo everybody else in the class.

outdoor.eng_def: existing, happening, or done outside, rather than inside a building
liking or relating to outdoor activities, such as walking and climbing
outdoor.chi_def: 喜歡戶外活動的；戶外活動的
outdoor.eg: Sara's not really the outdoor type.

outdoors.eg: If the weather's good, we'll eat outdoors (= not in a building).

outer.eng_def: at a greater distance from the centre

outfit.eng_def: a set of clothes worn for a particular occasion or activity
outfit.chi_def: （為特定場合或活動而穿的）全套服裝，裝束
outfit.eg: I'm going to wear my vampire outfit for Halloween.

outfit.eng_def: an organization, company, team, military unit, etc.
outfit.chi_def: 組織；公司；團隊；軍事單位
outfit.eg: He has recently set up his own research outfit.

outfit.eng_def: to provide someone or something with equipment or clothes
outfit.chi_def: 裝備，配備；為…提供設備（或服裝）
outfit.eg: The ambulances have all been outfitted with new radios.

outgoing.eng_def: (of a person) friendly and energetic and finding it easy and enjoyable to be with others
outgoing.chi_def: （人）開朗的，外向的，友好的，愛交際的
outgoing.eg: Sales reps need to be outgoing, because they are constantly meeting customers.

outgoing.eng_def: leaving a place, or leaving a job
outgoing.chi_def: 離開的；即將離職的，即將卸任的；即將結業的
outgoing.eg: Outgoing flights are booked until 15 January.

outing.eng_def: a short journey made by a group of people, usually for pleasure or education
outing.chi_def: 短途旅遊，遠足；外出參觀
outing.eg: Every year the professor takes her students on an outing to the archives of the Library of Congress.

outing.eng_def: an occasion when it is made public that a famous person is gay when he or she wanted to keep this information private
outing.chi_def: 爆料某名人是同性戀者
outing.eg: There have been several outings of well-known movie stars recently.

outlaw.eng_def: (especially in the past) a person who has broken the law and who lives separately from the other parts of society because they want to escape legal punishment
outlaw.eg: Robin Hood was an outlaw who lived in the forest and stole from the rich to give to the poor.

outlaw.eng_def: to make something illegal or unacceptable
outlaw.eg: The new law will outlaw smoking in public places.

outlet.eng_def: a way, especially a pipe or hole, for liquid or gas to go out
outlet.chi_def: （尤指管道或洞口的）出口，排放孔

outlet.eng_def: a way in which emotion or energy can be expressed or made use of
outlet.chi_def: （情緒或精力的）發泄方式，發泄途徑，施展的機會
outlet.eg: Her work provided no outlet for her energies and talents.

outlet.eng_def: a shop that is one of many owned by a particular company and that sells the goods that the company has produced
outlet.chi_def: 零售網點；經銷點；專賣店

outline.eng_def: the main shape or edge of something, without any details
outline.eg: She drew the outline of the boat and then coloured it in.

outline.eng_def: as a shape with an edge but without any details
outline.eg: The mountain was visible only in outline as the light faded.

outline.eng_def: a description of the main facts about something
outline.eg: If you read the minutes of the meeting, they'll give you a broad outline of what was discussed.

outline.eng_def: to draw the main shape or edge of something
outline.eg: The area we're interested in is outlined in red on the map.

outline.eng_def: to give the main facts about something
outline.eg: At the interview she outlined what I would be doing.

outlook.eg: The outlook for the economy is bleak.

outlook.eng_def: a person's way of understanding and thinking about something
outlook.eg: He has a fairly positive outlook on life.

outlook.eng_def: what you can see from a particular place
outlook.eg: From the top of the tower, the outlook over the city was breathtaking.

outnumber.eng_def: to be greater in number than someone or something
outnumber.eg: In our office the women outnumber the men three to one.

output.eng_def: an amount of something produced by a person, machine, factory, country, etc.
output.eg: Last year manufacturing output fell by 14 percent.

outrage.eng_def: a feeling of anger and shock
outrage.eg: These murders have provoked outrage across the country.

outrage.eng_def: a shocking, morally unacceptable, and usually violent action
outrage.chi_def: 暴行；（道義上）難以接受的事情；駭人聽聞的行為
outrage.eg: The bomb, which killed 15 people, was the worst of a series of terrorist outrages.

outrage.eng_def: (especially of an unfair action or statement) to cause someone to feel very angry, shocked, or upset
outrage.chi_def: （尤指不公平的行為或言論）使感到義憤，使憤慨，激怒
outrage.eg: Local people were outraged at the bombing.

outrage.chi_def: 憤怒的；憤慨的，義憤填膺的
outrage.eg: Outraged viewers jumped onto social media to complain about the ending of the series.

outrageous.chi_def: 駭人的；無恥的；無法接受的
outrageous.eg: The judge criticized the "outrageous greed" of some of the bankers.

outrageous.eng_def: used to describe something or someone that is shocking because they are unusual or strange
outrageous.chi_def: （因反常或怪異）嚇人的，驚人的，令人震驚的

outright.eg: I think cigarette advertising should be banned outright.
Outsiders are regarded with outright hostility.

outset.eg: I told him at/from the outset I wasn't interested.

outside.chi_def: 在外面（的），在室外（的）；在…外面（的）
outside.eg: It was a sunny day outside.

outside.eng_def: coming from another place or organization
outside.chi_def: 外來（的）；來自外地（或組織外）（的）；…以外（的）
outside.eg: The company has called in outside experts.

outside.eng_def: a phone call or connection going outside the place where you are
the most that would be accepted or possible
outside.chi_def: 最大限度的；最高限度的

outside.eng_def: not in a particular building or room, but near it
outside.eg: She sat for two hours on the floor outside his room.
Nobody outside this room must ever know what we have discussed.

outside.eng_def: not within or part of something
outside.eg: I'm afraid that would be outside my job description.
Outside of us three, no one knows anything about the problem, yet.

outside.eng_def: the outer part or side of something
outside.eg: The outside of the house needs painting.

outside.eng_def: used to say that an amount is the most possible in a situation
outside.eg: The job will take about ten days at the outside.
There's still an outside chance/possibility that Scotland will make it into the World Cup.

outsider.eng_def: a person who is not involved with a particular group of people or organization or who does not live in a particular place
outsider.chi_def: 局外人；外來者；外部的人
outsider.eg: Outsiders have a glamorized idea of what it is like to work in Hollywood.

outsider.eng_def: a person who is not liked or accepted as a member of a particular group, organization, or society and who feels different from those people who are accepted as members
outsider.chi_def: （不被某一團體、組織或社會接受的）局外人，不合群的人，外人
outsider.eg: As a child he was very much an outsider, never participating in the games other children played.

outsider.eng_def: a person or animal with only a slight chance of winning
outsider.chi_def: 取勝希望渺茫的人（或動物）
outsider.eg: A complete outsider won this year's award.

outskirts.eng_def: the areas that form the edge of a town or city
outskirts.eg: The factory is in/on the outskirts of New Delhi.

outstanding.eng_def: clearly very much better than what is usual
not yet paid, solved, or done
outstanding.chi_def: 未支付的；未解決的；未完成的

outward.eng_def: relating to how people, situations, or things seem to be, rather than how they are inside
outward.eg: The outward appearance of the building has not changed at all in 200 years.
outward investment (= investment in other companies/countries)

outward.eng_def: going towards a particular place, rather than returning from it
outward.eg: The outward flight/journey took eight hours.

outwards.eng_def: going or pointing away from a particular place or towards the outside

oval.eng_def: shaped like a circle that is flattened so that it is like an egg or an ellipse

oven.eng_def: the part of a cooker with a door, used to bake or roast food

over.eng_def: above or higher than something else, sometimes so that one thing covers the other; above
over.eg: The sign over the door said "Exit".

over.eng_def: in a position that is covering something
over.eg: Put a clean cloth over the cakes while they cool.

over.eng_def: across from one side to the other, especially by going up and then down
over.eg: She jumped over the gate.

over.eng_def: falling down from somewhere
over.eg: The coin rolled over the edge of the table.

over.eng_def: falling because of stepping on something
over.eg: She tripped over a toy lying on the path.

over.eng_def: more than
over.eg: Most of the carpets cost/are over $5,000.

over.eng_def: increasing to further than a particular limit or point
over.eg: They are already $25 million over budget.

over.eng_def: in addition to
over.eg: They receive extra money over and above the usual welfare payments.

over.eng_def: on the other side of
over.eg: There's a bar over the road we could go to.

over.eng_def: (referring to a cause of interest, worry, discussion, etc.) connected with or about
over.eg: There's no point in arguing over something so unimportant.

over.eng_def: during something, or while doing something
over.eg: I was in Seattle over the summer.

over.eng_def: to feel physically or mentally better after an illness or an upsetting experience
over.chi_def: 從（疾病或不愉快的經歷中）恢復過來
over.eg: It takes you a while to get over an illness like that.

over.eng_def: in control of or teaching someone or something
over.chi_def: （表示控制或管教）在…之上，高於
over.eg: A good teacher has an easy authority over a class.

over.eng_def: using
over.eg: They spoke over the phone.

over.eng_def: sometimes used when talking about a calculation in which one number is divided by another number
over.eg: 40 over 7 is roughly 6.

over.eng_def: from a higher to a lower position; down
over.eg: The lamp fell over and broke.

over.eng_def: across; from one side or place to another
over.chi_def: 越過；從一邊（或一地）到另一邊（或另一地）
over.eg: She leaned over and kissed me.

over.eng_def: used to describe the way an object moves or is moved so that a different part of it is facing up
over.eg: She turned another page over.

over.eng_def: changing or exchanging position
over.eg: Would you mind changing/swapping those plates over?

over.eng_def: above or higher than something else, sometimes so that one thing covers the other
over.eg: A fighter plane flew over.

over.eng_def: more than a particular amount or level
over.eg: People who are 65 years old and over can get half-price tickets.

over.eng_def: (especially of an event) finished
over.eg: I'll be glad when the competition is over.

over.eng_def: completely finished
over.eg: She gets unpleasant tasks over and done with as quickly as possible.

over.eng_def: extra; not used
over.eg: I have some euros left over from the last time I was in France.

over.eng_def: again or repeatedly
over.eg: You ruined it - now I'll have to do it over!

over.eng_def: said when you are talking to someone by radio, to mean that you have finished speaking and will wait for their answer
over.chi_def: （用於無線電通話）完畢，請回話
over.eg: "This is flight 595X. Do you read me? Over."

over.eng_def: said when you are talking to someone by radio in order to end the conversation
over.eg: "Thank you, control tower. Over and out."

over.eng_def: (in cricket) a set of six bowls (= throws) from the same end of the field
too much or more than usual
over.eg: The children got over-excited (= too excited).

over.eng_def: more than
over.eg: a club for the over-50s

over.eng_def: across
over.eg: Of course, the overland route is much slower than going by air.

over.eng_def: above
over.eg: She was knocked off her bicycle by an overhanging branch.

overall.eng_def: in general rather than in particular, or including all the people or things in a particular group or situation
overall.chi_def: 總的（來說）；全面的（地）；包括一切的（地）
overall.eg: The overall situation is good, despite a few minor problems.

overcoat.eng_def: a long thick coat worn in cold weather

overcome.eng_def: to defeat or succeed in controlling or dealing with something
overcome.eg: Juventus overcame Ajax in a thrilling game.

overcome.eng_def: to prevent someone from being able to act or think in the usual way
overcome.chi_def: 使受不了；使無法行動（或思考）
overcome.eg: They were overcome by fumes from the fire and had to be carried out of their houses.

overdo.eng_def: to do something in a way that is too extreme
overdo.eg: After a heart attack you have to be careful not to overdo it/things (= you have to work and live calmly).

overeat.eng_def: to eat more food than your body needs, especially so that you feel uncomfortably full
overeat.chi_def: 吃得太多；（尤指）吃得過飽

overflow.eng_def: When a liquid overflows, it flows over the edges of a container, etc. because there is too much of it.
overflow.eg: The milk overflowed when I poured it into the jug.

overflow.eng_def: If a container or a place overflows, whatever is inside it starts coming out because it is too full.
overflow.chi_def: （容器或場所）裝不下，擠得太滿
overflow.eg: Oh no, the sink is overflowing all over the floor.

overflow.eng_def: When a place overflows, or people or things overflow from somewhere, some people or things have to come out because it cannot contain them all.
overflow.chi_def: （場所、人或事物）擠滿，滿得容不下；爆滿；人滿為患
overflow.eg: The bar was so full that people were overflowing into/onto the street.

overflow.eng_def: so that water or another substance is almost coming over the top
overflow.eg: Someone had filled the sink to overflowing.

overflow.eng_def: If you overflow with thoughts or feelings, you express them strongly.
overflow.chi_def: （想法或感情）充滿，洋溢；（激情）澎湃
overflow.eg: They were overflowing with emotion at the birth of their baby.

overflow.eng_def: an amount of liquid or number of people that cannot fit in a space
overflow.eg: I put a bucket underneath to catch the overflow from the water tank.

overflow.eng_def: a pipe that carries away water that is not needed

overhead.eng_def: above your head, usually in the sky
relating to the overheads of a business
overhead.chi_def: 企業日常開支的；營運費用的
overhead.eg: One way of increasing profit margins is to cut overhead costs.

overhead.eng_def: a transparent sheet used for showing text or pictures with an overhead projector
the regular and necessary costs, such as rent and heating, that are involved in operating a business
overhead.chi_def: （公司的）經常性開支，營運費用，經費
overhead.eg: We need to reduce our overheads.

overhear.eng_def: to hear what other people are saying without intending to and without their knowledge
overhear.eg: I overheard a very funny conversation on the bus this morning.

overlap.eng_def: to cover something partly by going over its edge; to cover part of the same space
overlap.eg: The fence is made of panels that overlap (each other).

overlap.eng_def: If two or more activities, subjects, or periods of time overlap, they have some parts that are the same.
overlap.chi_def: （活動、課程或時間）互相重疊，有共同之處
overlap.eg: My musical tastes don't overlap with my brother's at all.

overlap.eng_def: If a football player overlaps, they pass the ball to another member of their team and then run beyond that player so that they are ready to receive the ball again.
overlap.chi_def: （足球）疊瓦式跑動，疊加式跑動

overlap.eng_def: the amount by which two things or activities cover the same area
overlap.eg: The roof tiles will need an overlap of several centimetres.

overlap.eng_def: in football, a movement in which a player passes the ball to another member of their team and then runs beyond that player so that they are ready to receive the ball again
overlap.chi_def: （足球）疊瓦式跑動，疊加式跑動

overlook.eng_def: to provide a view of, especially from above
overlook.eg: Our hotel room overlooked the harbour.

overlook.eng_def: to fail to notice or consider something or someone
overlook.eg: I think there is one key fact that you have overlooked.

overlook.eng_def: to forgive or pretend not to notice something
overlook.chi_def: 寬恕，不計較；對…視而不見
overlook.eg: I'm prepared to overlook his behaviour this time.

overlook.eng_def: a place from where a person can look at something, especially at an area of natural beauty
overlook.eg: There are lots of scenic overlooks along the road from New York to Montreal.

overnight.chi_def: 一夜間（的）；在夜間（的），在晚上（的）

overpass.eng_def: a bridge that carries a road or railway over another road

overseas.eng_def: in, from, or to other countries
overseas.chi_def: 在海外（的）；從國外來（的）；到國外（的）
overseas.eg: We need to open up overseas markets.

oversleep.eng_def: to sleep for longer than you intended to and so wake up late
oversleep.eg: I missed the bus this morning because I overslept again.

overtake.eng_def: to go past something by being a greater amount or degree
overtake.eg: Our US sales have now overtaken our sales in Europe.

overtake.eng_def: to come from behind another vehicle or a person and move in front of them
overtake.chi_def: 超過，趕上，追上（人或車輛）
overtake.eg: Always check your rear view mirror before you overtake (another car).

overtake.eng_def: to happen to a person or a place suddenly and unexpectedly
overtake.chi_def: 突然降臨於；意外發生在
overtake.eg: The family was overtaken by tragedy several years ago, and they still haven't recovered.

overthrow.eng_def: to defeat or remove someone from power, using force
overthrow.eg: He said that Allende's government in Chile was overthrown by the army and the CIA in 1973.

overthrow.eng_def: to throw a ball past the person or object you intended to throw to
overthrow.chi_def: 投（球）過猛；投球超過（接手或目標）；扔得比…遠

overthrow.eng_def: an occasion when someone or something is removed from power using force
the act of throwing a ball too far
a score in cricket made when the ball is thrown past the person it was intended to be thrown to
overthrow.chi_def: 投（球）過猛；投球超過（接手或目標）；扔得比…遠

overturn.chi_def: 打翻，弄翻；（使）傾覆；（使）翻倒
overturn.eg: The car skidded off the road, hit a tree and overturned.
The Court of Appeal overturned the earlier decision.

overturn.eng_def: If you overturn someone's majority in an election in the UK, you defeat them.
overturn.chi_def: （在英國大選中）因獲得多數席位而獲勝
overturn.eg: The Labour candidate unexpectedly overturned the long-standing Tory majority.

overwhelm.eng_def: to defeat someone or something by using a lot of force
overwhelm.eg: Government troops have overwhelmed the rebels and seized control of the capital.

overwhelm.eng_def: to cause someone to feel sudden strong emotion
overwhelm.chi_def: （強烈的感情）充溢，使難以承受，使不知所措
overwhelm.eg: They were overwhelmed with/by grief when their baby died.

overwhelm.eng_def: If water overwhelms a place, it covers it suddenly and completely.

overwork.eng_def: to (cause someone to) work too much
overwork.eg: You look exhausted - I hope they're not overworking you.

owe.eng_def: to need to pay or give something to someone because they have lent money to you, or in exchange for something they have done for you
to have success, happiness, a job, etc. only because of what someone has given you or done for you or because of your own efforts
owe.eg: I owe my success to my education.

owl.eng_def: a bird with a flat face and large eyes that hunts small mammals at night
a person who likes to stay up late at night

own.eng_def: belonging to or done by a particular person or thing
own.eg: Each neighbourhood in New York has its own characteristics.
I like living on my own.
I did my buttons up all on my own, Dad .

own.eng_def: If you do something in your own time, you do it at the speed at which you want to work.
during the time when you are not officially working
own.eg: You may only use company computers to access the Web in your own time.

own.eng_def: to have something that legally belongs to you

own.eg: I own (that) I was not very happy with the group's decision.

own.eng_def: to defeat someone completely or be much better than him or her; to perform extremely well
own.eg: Last time we played them, we owned them!

owner.eg: Are you the owner of this car?

ownership.eng_def: the fact that you own something
ownership.eg: Do you have any proof of ownership of/for this car?

ox.eng_def: a bull (= male cow) that has had its reproductive organs removed, used in the past for pulling heavy things on farms, or, more generally, any adult of the cattle family

oxygen.eng_def: a chemical element that is a gas with no smell or colour. Oxygen forms a large part of the air on earth, and is needed by animals and plants to live.

oyster.eng_def: a large flat sea creature that lives in a shell, some types of which can be eaten either cooked or uncooked, and other types of which produce pearls (= small round white precious stones)

ozone.eng_def: air that is clean and pleasant to breathe, especially near the sea

pa.eng_def: abbreviation for per annum (= each year)
abbreviation for personal assistant: someone whose job is helping someone in a higher position, especially by writing letters, arranging meetings, and making phone calls
pa.eg: Chris works as a PA to the chief executive officer.

pa.eng_def: abbreviation for public address system  (= equipment for making sound, especially someone's voice, louder in a public place)
pa.chi_def: 用於公共場合作廣播公告的設備系統（public address system的縮寫）
pa.eg: They've just announced on the PA that our flight's been delayed.

pa.eng_def: abbreviation for pulmonary artery (= the artery that carries dexogygenated blood from the heart to the lungs)
written abbreviation for the US state of Pennsylvania: used in addresses
pa.chi_def: （美國）賓夕法尼亞州（寫地址時Pennsylvania的縮寫）

pace.eng_def: the speed at which someone or something moves, or with which something happens or changes
pace.chi_def: （移動的）步調；（發生的）速度；節奏

pace.eng_def: to make other people in a race go faster by going faster yourself
pace.chi_def: （在速度比賽中）透過加速迫使對手加速

pace.eng_def: the ability of a football player or team to move quickly with the ball
pace.chi_def: （足球）球員（或球隊）的快速帶球能力
pace.eg: He plays on the right wing and has pace as well as skill.

pace.eng_def: a single step, or the distance you move when you take a single step
to get someone to run a race at a particular speed, for example by running with them
to be careful not to do something too quickly, so that you do not get too tired to finish it
pace.chi_def: 控制自己的速度；調整自己的工作（或活動）節奏
pace.eg: No more soup, thank you. I'm pacing myself so that I have room for a dessert.

pace.eng_def: to walk with regular steps in one direction and then back again, usually because you are worried or nervous
pace.chi_def: （通常因焦慮或擔憂而）來回踱步，走來走去

pacific.eng_def: peaceful or helping to cause peace
belonging to or relating to the Pacific Ocean
the ocean that is to the east of Asia and Australasia and to the west of North and South America

pack.eng_def: to put something into a bag, box, etc.
pack.eg: We're leaving early tomorrow morning, so you'd better pack (= put clothes and other possessions into suitcases or bags) tonight.

pack.eng_def: to put a material around something before putting it into a bag, box, etc. so that it will not break or be damaged
pack.eg: She packed the vase in tissue paper to protect it.

pack.eng_def: to come or bring together in large numbers or to fill a space
pack.eg: Thousands of fans are packing into the stadium.

pack.eng_def: to (cause to) form into a solid mass
pack.eg: The wind has packed the snow against the garage door.

pack.eng_def: to carry something, especially a gun
a group, set, or collection of something
pack.eg: The information pack consists of a brochure and a map.

pack.eng_def: a group of animals, such as dogs, that live and/or hunt together
pack.chi_def: （一同生活和／或獵食的）一群（動物）

pack.eng_def: an organized group of children who are brownies or cubs
pack.eg: My uncle was the leader of my Cub pack.

pack.eng_def: a group of similar people, especially one that contains people whose activities you do not approve of
pack.chi_def: （尤指行為不受歡迎的）一夥人，一幫人

pack.eng_def: a small paper or cardboard container in which a number of small objects are sold
a type of bag that you usually carry on your back when you are travelling
a thick mass of a substance, often like clay, that is used as a beauty treatment for the face
a thick mass of cloth, etc. that can be put on an injury to stop any bleeding or swelling
pack.chi_def: （放在傷口上止血或消腫的）裹布；敷料
pack.eg: Hold this ice pack to your head to stop the bruising.

pack.eng_def: used in combination with an amount to show that that many of a particular type of goods have been wrapped and are being sold together

package.eng_def: an object or set of objects wrapped in paper, usually in order to be sent by post
package.eg: The courier has just delivered a package for you.

package.eng_def: a small paper or plastic container in which a number of small objects are sold
a related group of things when they are offered together as a single unit
package.eg: The computer comes with a software package.

package.eng_def: the pay and other rewards that a company manager receives
package.chi_def: （企業經理收到的工資和其他福利與獎勵的總和）待遇包
package.eg: He will receive a compensation package worth $15 million over three years.

package.eng_def: to put goods into boxes or containers to be sold
package.eg: These organic olives are packaged in recycled glass containers.

package.eng_def: to sell several things together as a single product
package.eg: The program comes packaged with some games.

package.eng_def: to show someone or something in a particular, usually attractive, way
package.chi_def: 對…進行包裝；修飾…的外表
package.eg: As a young film star, she was packaged as a sex symbol.

packet.eng_def: a small paper or cardboard container in which a number of small objects are sold
a small closed container made of paper or plastic, containing a small amount of something, usually enough for only one occasion
an object that is wrapped in paper, etc., for example so that it can be sent by post
packet.eg: It will be cheaper to send it as a small packet.

packet.eng_def: several documents provided as a set, giving information about something
packet.eg: Our bookkeeping training packet includes everything you need to get started.

packet.eng_def: a unit of data that is sent over a computer network
packet.chi_def: （在電腦網路內傳播的）資料包

packet.eg: That house must have cost a packet!

pact.eng_def: a formal agreement between two people or groups of people
pact.eg: The United States and Canada have signed a free-trade pact.

pad.eng_def: a piece of soft, thick cloth or rubber, used to protect a part of the body, give shape to something, or clean something
a number of pieces of paper that have been fastened together along one side, used for writing or drawing on
pad.eg: I have a pad and pencil for taking notes.

pad.eng_def: a hard flat area of ground where helicopters can take off and land, or from which rockets are sent
pad.chi_def: （直升機的）起降場地；（火箭的）發射台
pad.eg: The hotel has its own helicopter pad.

pad.eng_def: one of the large, flat leaves of a water lily
the soft part under the paw (= foot) of a cat, dog, etc.
to put pieces of soft material in something to make it soft, give it a different shape, or protect what is inside
pad.eg: These boots are padded with shock-resistant foam.

paddle.eng_def: a short pole with a wide, flat part at one end or both ends, used for moving a small boat or canoe through the water
a blade on a paddle wheel
a walk through water that is not very deep, especially at the edge of a beach, etc.
paddle.eg: Shall we go for a paddle?

paddle.eng_def: to push a pole with a wide end through the water in order to make a boat move
to hit a child on the bottom with a short, wide piece of wood as a punishment
to walk with no shoes or socks on through water that is not very deep, often at the edge of a beach, etc.
paddle.chi_def: 涉水，趟水；在（海邊）淺水中走
paddle.eg: We rolled up our trousers and paddled along the seashore.

paddle.eng_def: to swim by moving your feet and hands up and down

page.eng_def: a side of one of the pieces of paper in a book, newspaper, or magazine, usually with a number printed on it
page.eg: For details on how to enter the competition, see page 134.

page.eng_def: one of the sheets of paper in a book, newspaper, or magazine
page.chi_def: （書或報紙、雜誌中紙的）一頁，一張
page.eg: Several pages have been torn out of this book.

page.eng_def: (in the past) a boy who worked as a servant for a knight and who was learning to become a knight
to call a person using a loudspeaker (= an electric device for making sounds louder) in a public place
page.chi_def: （用擴音器在公共場合）呼叫（某人）
page.eg: He was paged at the airport and told to return home immediately.

page.eng_def: to send a message to someone's pager (= small electronic device that receives signals)
page.eg: Have you tried to page him?

pain.eng_def: a feeling of physical suffering caused by injury or illness
pain.eg: Her symptoms included abdominal pain and vomiting.
It's a film about the pains and pleasures of parenthood.

pain.eng_def: If something pains you, it causes you to feel sad and upset.
pain.eg: It pains me to see animals being mistreated.

painful.chi_def: 令人痛苦的，引起痛苦的
painful.eg: The old photograph brought back painful memories.

painful.eng_def: If something is painful to watch or listen to, it is so bad that it makes you feel embarrassed.
painful.eg: It was painful to listen to his pathetic excuses.

paint.eng_def: a coloured liquid that is put on a surface such as a wall to decorate it
tubes of paint or blocks of dried paint used for making pictures
to cover a surface with paint
to make a picture using paints
paint.eg: All these pictures were painted by local artists.

paint.eng_def: If you paint your nails or face, you put make-up on that part of your body.
paint.eg: She painted her nails bright red.

painter.eng_def: someone whose job is to paint surfaces, such as walls and doors

painting.eg: The walls are covered in oil paintings.

painting.eng_def: the skill or activity of making a picture or putting paint on a wall
painting.eg: We were taught painting and drawing at art college.

pair.eng_def: two things of the same appearance and size that are intended to be used together, or something that consists of two parts joined together
two people who have a romantic relationship or are doing something together
pair.eg: They seem a very happy pair.

pair.eng_def: two animals that come together to have sex and produce young
to make something one of a pair, or to become one of a pair
pair.eg: Famous paintings have been paired with poems by Sandburg, Angelou, and others.

pal.eng_def: used when talking to a man, sometimes in a friendly way but more often to a man who is annoying you
pal.chi_def: （有時用於稱呼令人討厭的男性）老兄，老弟
pal.eg: Look, pal, you're asking for trouble.

palace.eng_def: a large house that is the official home of a king, queen, or other person of high social rank
used in the names of large buildings, such as cinemas or places where people go dancing
palace.chi_def: （用於電影院、舞廳等大型建築物的名稱中）
palace.eg: An old movie palace is being restored.

palace.eng_def: used when referring to the people who live in a palace
palace.eg: The Palace has issued a statement criticizing the newspaper report.

pale.eng_def: used to describe a person's face or skin if it has less colour than usual, for example when the person is or ill or frightened, or if it has less colour than people generally have
pale.eg: You're looking pale - are you feeling well?

pale.eng_def: A pale light or colour is not bright or strong.
pale.eg: She wore a pale blue hat.

pale.eng_def: If a person's face pales, it loses its usual colour.
pale.eg: His face paled and he looked as if he might faint.

palm.eng_def: the inside part of your hand from your wrist to the base of your fingers
palm.eg: This tiny device fits into the palm of your hand.

palm.eng_def: to look at the lines on the inside of someone's hand and say what these lines say about their character and future
a tree that grows in hot countries and has a tall trunk with a mass of long pointed leaves at the top
to make something seem to disappear by hiding it in the palm of your hand as part of a trick, or to steal something by picking it up in a way that will not be noticed
palm.chi_def: （變戲法或偷竊時）把…藏在手心內
palm.eg: I suspected that he had palmed a playing card.

pamphlet.eng_def: a thin book with only a few pages that gives information or an opinion about something

pan.eng_def: a metal container that is round and often has a long handle and a lid, used for cooking things on top of a cooker
pan.eg: Heat the milk in a small pan.

pan.eng_def: a metal container without a lid used for cooking food in the oven
pan.eg: Put both cake pans in the oven for half an hour.

pan.eng_def: the bowl-shaped part of a toilet
(of a video camera) to move slowly from one side to another or up and down
pan.eg: In the first scene, the camera pans slowly across the room.
The critics panned the movie version of the novel.

pan.eng_def: including or relating to all the places or people in a particular group

pancake.eng_def: a thin, flat, round cake made from a mixture of flour, milk, and egg, fried on both sides
pancake.eg: Do you want a sweet pancake or a savoury one?

pancake.eng_def: a thin, flat, round cake made from flour, sugar, milk, and eggs, cooked in a pan and usually eaten with maple syrup for breakfast
pancake.chi_def: （當早點吃的）厚煎餅（通常和楓糖漿一起食用）

panda.eng_def: a large, black and white mammal that lives in forests in China. Pandas eat bamboo.

pane.eng_def: a flat piece of glass, used in a window or door

panel.eng_def: a small group of people chosen to give advice, make a decision, or publicly discuss their opinions as entertainment
panel.eg: The competition will be judged by a panel of experts.

panel.eng_def: a flat, usually rectangular part, or piece of wood, metal, cloth, etc., that fits into or onto something larger
panel.eg: a beautiful old door with oak panels

panel.eng_def: a board or surface that has controls and other devices on it for operating an aircraft or other large machine
to cover or decorate with flat, usually rectangular pieces of wood, metal, cloth, etc.
panel.eg: The walls of the dining hall were panelled in oak.

panic.eng_def: a sudden strong feeling of fear that prevents reasonable thought and action
to suddenly feel so worried or frightened that you cannot think or behave calmly or reasonably
panic.eg: Don't panic! Everything will be okay.

pants.eng_def: a piece of underwear covering the area between the waist and the tops of the legs
a piece of clothing that covers the lower part of the body from the waist to the feet, consisting of two cylinder-shaped parts, one for each leg, that are joined at the top
not useful or of bad quality
pants.chi_def: 無價值的，無用的，低劣的

pants.eg: "Just look at this scar," said Aaron proudly, rolling up his pants leg.

papa.eg: "Why is the sky blue, Papa?" she asked.

papaya.eng_def: a large oval fruit with a yellowish skin and sweet orange flesh, or the tropical tree on which this grows

paper.eng_def: thin, flat material made from crushed wood or cloth, used for writing, printing, or drawing on
official documents, especially ones that show who you are
paper.eg: The border guards stopped me and asked to see my papers.

paper.eng_def: a set of printed questions for an exam
paper.eg: Candidates must answer two questions from each paper.

paper.eng_def: a piece of writing on a particular subject written by an expert and usually published in a book or journal, or read aloud to other people
paper.eg: He will give a paper on thermodynamics at a conference in Berlin.

paper.eng_def: a short piece of writing on a particular subject, especially one done by students as part of the work for a course
paper.eg: Mr Jones thought my history paper was terrific.

paper.eng_def: to cover a wall, room, etc. with wallpaper

parachute.eng_def: a piece of equipment made of a large piece of special cloth that is fastened to a person or thing that is dropped from an aircraft, in order to make him, her, or it fall slowly and safely to the ground
to jump from an aircraft using a parachute
parachute.eg: The plan is to parachute into the town.

parachute.eng_def: to drop someone or something from an aircraft by parachute
parachute.eg: Thousands of leaflets were parachuted behind enemy lines.

parade.eng_def: a large number of people walking or in vehicles, all going in the same direction, usually as part of a public celebration of something
a series of people or things that appear one after the other
parade.eg: For three hours a committee of state senators listened to a parade of local residents giving their opinions.

parade.eng_def: When soldiers are on parade, they march and practise military movements in front of important officials or as part of a public celebration or ceremony.
parade.eg: The entire regiment was on parade.

parade.eng_def: used in the names of some roads
(of a group) to walk or march somewhere, usually as part of a public celebration
parade.eg: The Saint Patrick's Day marchers paraded up Fifth Avenue, past the cathedral.

parade.eng_def: to show something in an obvious way in order to be admired
parade.eg: It's sickening the way he parades his wealth, his car, and his expensive clothes.

paradise.eng_def: a place or condition of great happiness where everything is exactly as you would like it to be

paradise.eg: They believe they'll go to Paradise after they die.

paradise.eng_def: the garden of Eden (= the place where Adam and Eve lived, in the Bible story)

paradox.eng_def: a situation or statement that seems impossible or is difficult to understand because it contains two opposite facts or characteristics
paradox.chi_def: 自相矛盾的情況；似非而是的說法，悖論；詭論
paradox.eg: It's a curious paradox that drinking a lot of water can often make you feel thirsty.

paragraph.eng_def: a short part of a text, consisting of at least one sentence and beginning on a new line. It usually deals with a single event, description, idea, etc.

parallel.eng_def: If two or more lines, streets, etc. are parallel, the distance between them is the same all along their length.
parallel.eg: Draw a pair of parallel lines.

parallel.eng_def: used to describe an event or situation that happens at the same time as and/or is similar to another one
parallel.chi_def: 同時發生的；相同的，類似的

parallel.eng_def: sending through several bits (= units) of information at a time using a link with several channels (= wires or connections)
something very similar to something else, or a similarity between two things
parallel.chi_def: 可相比擬的事物；相似之處
parallel.eg: I'm trying to see if there are any obvious parallels between the two cases.

parallel.eng_def: If something has no parallel or is without parallel, there is nothing similar to it or of the same high quality as it.
parallel.eg: These beautiful African churches have no parallel in Europe.

parallel.eng_def: a line that is always at the same distance from another line
one of a number of imaginary lines around the earth always at the same distance from the equator
If two or more parts of an electrical system are in parallel, they are arranged in a way that means they both receive the same amount of electricity.
to happen at the same time as something else, or be similar or equal to something else
parallel.chi_def: 與…同時發生；與…相似；與…相當，比得上
parallel.eg: The events of the last ten days in some ways parallel those before the 1978 election.

parallel.eng_def: in a position that is always the same distance from something else
parallel.eg: It's a quiet street running (= positioned) parallel to the main road.

parcel.eng_def: an object or collection of objects wrapped in paper, especially so that it can be sent by post

pardon.eng_def: to forgive someone for something they have said or done. This word is often used in polite expressions
pardon.chi_def: 原諒，寬恕（常用於禮貌的表達方式）
pardon.eg: Pardon my ignorance, but what exactly is ergonomics?

pardon.eng_def: If someone who has committed a crime is pardoned, that person is officially forgiven and their punishment is stopped.
pardon.eg: Large numbers of political prisoners have been pardoned and released by the new president.

pardon.eng_def: an occasion when someone who has committed a crime is officially forgiven
pardon.eg: He had actively sought a pardon from the president.

pardon.eng_def: used to politely ask someone to repeat something they have said because you did not hear it
used to show that someone has said something that offends you
pardon.chi_def: 再說一遍（用於對某人的話感到不快時）
pardon.eg: "Women tend to be fairly useless drivers, anyway." "I beg your pardon!"

parent.eng_def: a mother or father of a person or an animal
parent.eg: I'm going to meet Richard's parents for the first time this weekend.

parent.eng_def: a company that owns one or more other companies
parent.eg: The subsidiary has issued shares that are guaranteed by its parent.

park.eng_def: a large area of land with grass and trees, usually surrounded by fences or walls, and specially arranged so that people can walk in it for pleasure or children can play in it
an area of land that is used for a particular purpose
an area of land for playing sports on
an area of land around a large house in the countryside
to put a vehicle in a place where it can stay for a period of time, usually while you leave it
to put yourself or something in a particular place for a long time, often annoying other people
park.chi_def: （某人）坐在（某處），站在（某處），把…放在（某處）（常因持續時間過長而令人生厭）
park.eg: He parked himself in front of the TV and stayed there all afternoon.

park.eng_def: to not deal with something or answer a question immediately but leave it for a later time
park.eg: Can we park that question until the end of the session?

parliament.eng_def: in some countries, the group of (usually) elected politicians or other people who make the laws for their country
parliament.eg: On Tuesday the country's parliament voted to establish its own army.

parliament.eng_def: a particular period of time during which a parliament is operating, between either holidays or elections

parlor.eng_def: a business that provides a stated type of personal service or sells a stated product
parlor.chi_def: （提供某種服務或銷售某種商品的）店舖

parlor.eng_def: (especially in the past) a room in a private house used for relaxing, especially one that was kept tidy for entertaining guests
parlor.chi_def: （尤指舊時的）起居室，客廳，會客室

parrot.eng_def: a tropical bird with a curved beak, often kept as a pet and trained to copy the human voice
to repeat exactly what someone else says, without understanding it or thinking about its meaning
parrot.chi_def: 鸚鵡學舌般地複述，機械地複述
parrot.eg: She doesn't have an original thought in her head - she just parrots anything that Sara says.

part.eng_def: some but not all of a thing
part.eg: Part of my steak isn't cooked properly.
The deadline for applications is being extended, in part because of the postal strike.
How quickly we can finish the project depends in (a) large part on when we get the payments through.
He was, for the most part, quite helpful.

part.eng_def: a separate piece of something, or a piece that combines with other pieces to form the whole of something
part.eg: We learned about all the different parts of the digestive system.

part.eng_def: one of the pieces that together form a machine or some type of equipment
part.eg: He works for a company that makes aircraft parts.

part.eng_def: a single broadcast of a series of television or radio programmes or a division of a story
part.chi_def: （電視連續劇或連播劇的）集，節，段；（小說的）部，篇
part.eg: Next week we publish part three of the president's diaries.

part.eng_def: one of two or more equal, or almost equal, measures of something
part.eg: Mix one part of the medicine with three parts water.

part.eng_def: one of the characters in a film, play, or dance, or the words, actions, or movements that are said or done by that character
part.eg: He has a small part in the school play.

part.eng_def: the music that a particular musician plays in a group
used to refer to an area of the country
part.eg: We don't see many foreigners in these parts.

part.eng_def: to be involved in an activity with other people
part.eg: She doesn't usually take part in any of the class activities.

part.eng_def: involvement in or responsibility for an activity, or action
part.eg: He admitted his part in the robbery.

part.eng_def: a line on someone's head made by brushing the hair in two different directions
to separate or cause something or someone to separate
part.eg: The curtains parted, revealing a darkened stage.

part.eng_def: If you part your hair, you arrange it so that it falls on either side of your head by separating it with a line down the middle or on one side.
If two people part, they leave each other, often at the end of a relationship.
part.eg: I'm afraid we parted on very bad terms.
He's part African - his father was born in Somalia.

partial.eg: The general has ordered a partial withdrawal of troops from the area.

partial.eng_def: influenced by the fact that you personally prefer or approve of something, so that you do not judge fairly
partial.chi_def: 偏向一方的，偏袒的，偏心的
partial.eg: The reporting in the papers is entirely partial and makes no attempt to be objective.

participant.eng_def: a person who takes part in or becomes involved in a particular activity

participate.eng_def: to take part in or become involved in an activity
participate.eg: She never participates in any of our discussions, does she?

participation.eng_def: the fact that you take part or become involved in something

participle.eng_def: the form of a verb that usually ends in "ed" or "ing" and is used as an adjective
participle.eg: In the sentences "He's sleeping" and "I've already eaten", the words "sleeping" and "eaten" are both participles.

particle.eng_def: a word or a part of a word that has a grammatical purpose but often has little or no meaning
particle.eg: In the sentence "I tidied up the room", the adverb "up" is a particle.

particle.eng_def: an extremely small piece of matter
particle.eg: Dust particles must have got into the motor.

particle.eng_def: a very small amount of something
particle.eg: She wouldn't give me even the slightest particle of information about what she'd been doing.

particular.eng_def: special, or this and not any other
particular.eg: She wanted a particular type of cactus.
What in particular did you like about the last apartment that we saw?

particular.eng_def: not easily satisfied and demanding that close attention should be given to every detail
particular.eg: He's very particular about the kitchen - everything has to be perfectly clean and in its place.

particular.eng_def: details or information about a person or an event, especially when officially recorded
particular.eg: There's a form for you to note down all your particulars.

particular.eng_def: If you are considering the particular, you are considering single examples rather than general matters or ideas.
particular.eg: The report focuses on the particular rather than the general and so doesn't draw any overall conclusions.

partly.eng_def: to some degree, but not completely
partly.eg: His attractiveness is partly due to his self-confidence.

partner.eng_def: a person or organization you are closely involved with in some way
partner.eg: He gave up his job as a police officer after his partner was killed.

partner.eng_def: one of the owners of a company
partner.eg: He's a partner in an insurance company/a law firm.

partner.eng_def: the person you are married to or living with as if married to them, or the person you are having a sexual relationship with
partner.eg: I've invited David and his partner over for dinner.

partner.eng_def: one of a pair of dancers or one of a pair who are playing a sport or a game together, especially when the pair are playing as a team
to act as someone's partner in a sport, game, dance, or activity, or to choose someone to do this
partner.chi_def: （在體育運動、遊戲或舞蹈中）與（某人）合作，與（某人）成為搭檔
partner.eg: He said that Teddy was the best player he had ever partnered.

partnership.eng_def: the state of being a partner
a company that is owned by two or more people

party.eng_def: a social event at which a group of people meet to talk, eat, drink, dance, etc., often in order to celebrate a special occasion
an organization of people with particular political beliefs that competes in elections to try to win positions in local or national government
a group of people who are involved in an activity together, especially a visit
party.chi_def: （共同參加活動，尤指參觀的）一批人，一組人

party.eng_def: one of the people or groups of people involved in an official argument, arrangement, or similar situation
party.eg: The UN called on all parties in the conflict to take a positive stance towards the new peace initiative.

party.eng_def: to enjoy yourself by drinking and dancing, especially at a party
party.chi_def: （尤指在聚會上）吃喝玩樂，狂歡

pass.eng_def: to go past something or someone or move in relation to it, him, or her
pass.eg: I passed him on the stairs this morning.

pass.eng_def: to go past a particular point in time
pass.eg: Don't buy goods that have passed their sell-by date.

pass.eng_def: to go past something by being greater in amount or degree
pass.eg: The company's turnover is expected to pass the $10 million mark by the end of this year.

pass.eng_def: If you say a state or feeling will pass, you mean it will disappear.
pass.eg: Don't worry, his depression is only temporary - it'll soon pass.

pass.eng_def: to be successful in an exam, course, etc.
pass.eg: Guess what? I've passed my driving test!

pass.eng_def: to give something to someone
pass.eg: Could you pass the salt please?

pass.eng_def: In sports, if you pass the ball, you kick, throw, or hit it to someone in your team.
If you pass money, you give someone false or stolen money without telling them.
pass.eg: I haven't trusted him since he passed me a forged $100 bill.

pass.eng_def: When time passes, it goes past.
pass.eg: Time seems to pass (by) so slowly when you're bored.

pass.eng_def: If you pass a period of time, you do something to stop yourself being bored during that period.
pass.eg: The visitors pass their days swimming, windsurfing, and playing volleyball.

pass.eng_def: (of an official group of people) to give approval to something, especially by voting to make it law
pass.eg: The government passed a law to restrict the sale of guns.

pass.eng_def: to express a judgment or opinion about something, especially someone else's behaviour
pass.eg: As a convicted criminal, he's in no position to pass judgment (on the rest of us).

pass.eng_def: to say officially, as a judge, what a criminal's official punishment will be
to remove waste from the body
pass.eg: to pass urine

pass.eng_def: to have blood in your urine or faeces (= solid waste)
pass.eg: If you pass blood, you should go and see your doctor.

pass.eng_def: to choose not to play in a part of a game or not to answer a question in a quiz
pass.chi_def: （紙牌遊戲中不出牌或競賽中不回答問題時的用語）過

pass.eng_def: to change from one state to another
pass.eg: Wax passes from solid to liquid when you heat it.

pass.eng_def: a successful result in an exam
pass.eg: Jon Hill achieved two grade A passes at A-level.

pass.eng_def: a successful result in a course or exam for which the student will not be given a mark
pass.eg: I got a pass in my Literature course.

pass.eng_def: a movement of the ball from one player to another member of the same team in a team sport
an official document or ticket showing that you have the right to go somewhere or use a particular form of transport
pass.eg: a bus pass

pass.eng_def: a document that allows a student to leave a class for a particular reason
pass.chi_def: 免課證（允許某一學生因為特殊原因離開課堂）
pass.eg: She had a pass to go to the library.

pass.eng_def: a path or road between or over mountains
pass.eg: a mountain pass

pass.eng_def: a difficult or unpleasant condition
pass.eg: If I'd been aware things had reached such a pass, I'd have told the police.

pass.eng_def: to speak to or touch someone in a way that shows you would like to start a sexual relationship with them

passage.eng_def: a usually long and narrow part of a building with rooms on one or both sides, or a covered path that connects places
passage.eg: A narrow passage led directly through the house into the garden.

passage.eng_def: a hollow part of the body through which something goes
a short piece of writing or music that is part of a larger piece of work
passage.eg: Several passages from the book were printed in a national newspaper before it was published.

passage.eng_def: travel, especially as a way of escape
passage.eg: The gunman demanded a plane and safe passage to an unspecified destination.

passage.eng_def: a journey, especially over the sea
passage.eg: He had booked his passage to Rio de Janeiro.

passage.eng_def: to do work on a ship during your trip instead of paying for a ticket
passage.chi_def: 在船上做工以抵償船費

passage.eng_def: an act of moving through somewhere
passage.eg: Many meteors disintegrate during their passage through the atmosphere.

passage.eng_def: the process of time going past
passage.eg: Memories fade with the passage of time.

passage.eng_def: the official approval of something, especially a new law
passage.eg: He again urged passage of a constitutional amendment outlawing abortion.

passenger.eng_def: a person who is travelling in a vehicle but is not driving it, flying it, or working on it
a train carrying people rather than goods
passenger.eg: Two passenger trains were involved in the accident.

passion.eng_def: a very powerful feeling, for example of sexual attraction, love, hate, anger, or other emotion
passion.eg: Football arouses a good deal of passion among its fans.

passion.eng_def: an extreme interest in or wish for doing something, such as a hobby, activity, etc.
passion.chi_def: 對…的熱愛，對…的強烈愛好
passion.eg: Anton has a consuming passion for science fiction.
Touch a man's property and his passions are immediately aroused.

passion.eng_def: in Christianity, the suffering and death of Jesus Christ

passionate.eng_def: having very strong feelings or emotions

passive.eng_def: not acting to influence or change a situation; allowing other people to be in control
passive.eg: He's very passive in the relationship.

passive.eng_def: The passive form of a verb is being used when the grammatical subject is the person or thing that experiences the effect of an action, rather than the person or thing that causes the effect.
passive.eg: 'He was released from prison' is a passive sentence.

passive.eng_def: the form of a verb used when the grammatical subject is the person or thing that experiences the effect of an action, rather than the person or thing that causes the effect
passive.eg: When changed into the passive, "The dog chased the cat" becomes "The cat was chased by the dog".

passport.eng_def: an official document containing personal information and usually a photograph that allows a person to travel to foreign countries and to prove who they are
passport.eg: Many refugees have arrived at the border without passports.

passport.eng_def: a certain way of getting something you want
passport.eg: Many students opt for business studies simply because it sounds like a passport to a good job.

password.eng_def: a secret word or combination of letters or numbers, used for communicating with another person or with a computer to prove who you are
password.eg: I can't let you in unless you give the password.

past.eng_def: in or to a position that is further than a particular point
past.eg: I live on Station Road, just past the post office.

past.eng_def: used to say what the time is when it is a particular number of minutes after an hour
above a particular age or further than a particular point
past.eg: She's past the age where she needs a babysitter.

past.eng_def: used to refer to a period of time before and until the present
past.eg: The average temperature worldwide has risen by about one degree Fahrenheit in the past 100 years.

past.eng_def: having happened or existed before now
past.eg: I know from past experience that you can't judge by appearances.
I'm feeling much better now that the cold weather is past.
"Must" does not have a past form.

past.eng_def: the period before and until, but not including, the present time
past.eg: Evolution can explain the past, but it can never predict the future.

past.eng_def: a part of someone's life in which they did unacceptable or dishonest things
past.eg: He's a man with a past.

past.eng_def: the form of a verb used to describe actions, events, or states that happened or existed before the present time

pasta.eng_def: a food made from flour, water, and sometimes egg, that is cooked and usually served with a sauce. It is made in various shapes that have different names
pasta.chi_def: （通常拌以調味醬的）義大利麵食
pasta.eg: Spaghetti, lasagne, ravioli, and cannelloni are all types of pasta.

paste.eng_def: a thick soft sticky substance made by mixing a liquid with a powder, especially to make a type of glue
a thick soft substance made by crushing and mixing things such as fish, fruit, or vegetables for food
a hard type of glass used to make artificial jewels
paste.eg: Are these real diamonds or paste?

paste.eng_def: to stick something to something, especially with paste
paste.eg: You can make your own distorting mirror by pasting a sheet of kitchen foil to a piece of thin cardboard.

paste.eng_def: to move a piece of text to a particular place in a computer document
paste.chi_def: （在電腦檔案中）黏貼（某段文字）
paste.eg: Cut that paragraph and then paste it at the end of the page.

paste.eng_def: to move words or pictures from one place to another in a computer document
paste.chi_def: （電腦檔案中文字或圖片的）剪貼

pastime.eng_def: an activity that is done for enjoyment
pastime.eg: Do-it-yourself is the nation's most popular pastime.

pastry.eng_def: a food made from a mixture of flour, fat, and water, rolled flat and either wrapped around or put over or under other foods, and then baked
a type of sweet cake made of special pastry and usually containing something such as fruit or nuts
