pose.eg: He adopted/assumed/struck (= moved into) an elegant pose.

pose.eng_def: an occasion when someone pretends to have qualities that they do not have
pose.eg: She likes to appear as if she knows all about the latest films and art exhibitions, but it's all a pose (= she's pretending and it's not true).

position.eng_def: the place where something or someone is, often in relation to other things
position.eg: Well, I've found our position on the map if you want to see where we are.

position.eng_def: (in team sports) the part someone plays in a game, relating to the area of the field in which they mostly play
position.chi_def: （團隊體育運動中個人所處的）位置
position.eg: I didn't know you played hockey - what position do you play?

position.eng_def: the place where people are sent in order to carry out a course of action
position.chi_def: 陣地；（採取行動的）恰當位置
position.eg: The troops took up their battle positions at the front line.
My financial position is somewhat precarious at the moment.

position.eng_def: to be able to do something, usually because you have the necessary experience, authority, or money
position.chi_def: （通常指因為有經驗、權威和金錢而）能夠做…
position.eg: I'm not in a position to reveal any of the details of the project at present.

position.eng_def: a rank or level in a company, competition, or society
position.eg: Whether or not you're given a car depends on your position in the company.
She applied for a position in the firm that I work for.

position.eng_def: the way in which something is arranged
position.eg: Keep the bottles in an upright position.
What's the company's position on recycling?

position.eng_def: to put something or someone in a particular place
position.eg: The army had been positioned to the north and east of the city.

positive.eng_def: full of hope and confidence, or giving cause for hope and confidence
positive.chi_def: 建設性的；積極的；懷有希望的
有把握的，確信的，肯定的
positive.eg: Are you positive (that) you saw me switch the iron off?

positive.eng_def: (of a medical test) showing that a person has the disease or condition for which they are being tested
(used to add force to an expression) complete
positive.eg: Far from being a nuisance, she was a positive joy to have around.

positive.eng_def: (of a number or amount) more than zero
being the type of electrical charge that is carried by protons
having the rhesus factor in the blood
positive.chi_def: 血液中含獼因數的；Rh陽性的
positive.eg: My blood type is O positive.

possess.eng_def: to have or own something, or to have a particular quality
possess.eg: I don't possess a single DVD (= I don't have even one DVD).

possess.eng_def: (of a wish or an idea) to take control over a person's mind, making that person behave in a very strange way
possess.eg: Whatever possessed him to wear that appalling jacket!

possession.eng_def: the fact that you have or own something
possession.eg: The possession of large amounts of money does not ensure happiness.

possession.eng_def: something that you own or that you are carrying with you at a particular time
possession.eg: Please remember to take all your personal possessions with you when you leave the aircraft.

possession.eng_def: a country that is ruled by another country
in games such as football and rugby, the time when a team has control of the ball
possession.chi_def: （足球和橄欖球等比賽中，一方球隊的）控球時間
possession.eg: Wolves had a lot of possession but failed to score.

possession.eng_def: to start to use and control a building or piece of land that you may or may not own
possession.eg: We've already bought the house but we won't take possession of it until May.

possibility.eng_def: a chance that something may happen or be true
possibility.eg: It's not likely to happen but I wouldn't rule out the possibility.

possibility.eng_def: something that you can choose to do in a particular situation
possibility.chi_def: 可選擇的方法；可能的情況
possibility.eg: We could take on extra staff - that's one possibility.

possible.eng_def: able to be done or achieved, or able to exist
possible.eg: I can't get it all done by Friday - it's just not possible.

possible.eng_def: as much, quickly, soon, etc. as something can happen or be done
possible.eg: Please take your seats as quickly as possible.

possible.eng_def: that might or might not happen
possible.eg: It's possible (that) Mira might turn up tonight.

post.eng_def: letters, etc. that are delivered to homes or places of work
post.eg: I'd been away for a few days so I had a lot of post waiting for me.

post.eng_def: the public system that exists for the collecting and delivering of letters
post.eg: My letter must have got lost in the post.

post.eng_def: the time during the day when letters, etc. are collected or delivered
post.chi_def: 收集（或投遞）郵件的時間；郵班
post.eg: I missed the post this morning.

post.eng_def: a job in a company or organization
post.eg: Teaching posts are advertised in Tuesday's edition of the paper.

post.eng_def: a vertical stick or pole stuck into the ground, usually to support something or show a position
in the sport of horse racing, the place where the race finishes or, less often, the place from which the race starts
post.chi_def: （賽馬的）終點柱，終點標誌；起點柱

post.eng_def: in sports such as football, a goalpost (= either of two vertical posts showing the area in which the ball is kicked to score points)
the particular place where someone works, especially where a soldier is told to be for military duty, usually as a guard
post.eg: The soldier was disciplined for deserting his post.

post.eng_def: something such as a message or picture that you publish on a website or using social media
post.chi_def: 網站上公佈的資訊；帖子
post.eg: Lots of people have commented on my post.

post.eng_def: to send a letter or parcel by post
post.eg: Did you remember to post my letter?

post.eng_def: to put an object through a letterbox (= special opening in a door)
post.eg: Just post the key through the door after you've locked it.

post.eng_def: to send someone to a particular place to work
post.eg: He's been posted to Pakistan for six months.

post.eng_def: to stick or pin a notice on a wall in order to make it publicly known
post.eg: Company announcements are usually posted (up) on the noticeboard.

post.eng_def: to publish something such as a message or picture on a website or using social media
post.chi_def: （在網站上）公佈，發布（資訊）；發（帖）
post.eg: I never post anything on the Internet that I wouldn't want my boss to see.

post.eng_def: to pay money, especially so that a person who has been accused of committing a crime can be free until their trial
post.eg: She has agreed to post bail for her brother.

post.eng_def: to announce a company's financial results
post.eg: The oil company posted profits of $25.1 billion.

postage.eng_def: the money that you pay for sending letters and parcels through the post

postcard.eng_def: a card, often with a photograph or picture on one side, that can be sent without an envelope

poster.eng_def: a large printed picture, photograph, or notice that you stick or pin to a wall or board, usually for decoration or to advertise something
poster.eg: The children put up posters on the classroom walls.

poster.eng_def: someone who publishes something such as a message or picture on a website or using social media
poster.chi_def: （在網站或社交媒體上發佈資訊或照片的）發帖人
poster.eg: There was a lively debate on the message boards, with many posters arguing against the plan.

postpone.eng_def: to delay an event and plan or decide that it should happen at a later date or time
postpone.eg: They decided to postpone their holiday until next year.

posture.eng_def: the way in which someone usually holds their shoulders, neck, and back, or a particular position in which someone stands, sits, etc.
a way in which a government or other organization thinks about and/or deals with a particular matter
posture.eg: For the third time this week the opposition has attacked the government's posture on defence.

pot.eng_def: any of various types of container, usually round, especially one used for cooking food
pot.eg: Fill a large pot with salted water and bring it to the boil.

pot.eng_def: any of different types of containers, with or without a lid, especially for storing food or liquids
pot.chi_def: （尤指儲藏食物或液體的）罐，瓶，壺

pot.eng_def: the amount that is contained inside a pot
pot.chi_def: 一罐（或一壺、一瓶等）的量
pot.eg: I've just drunk a whole pot of tea!

pot.eng_def: used in combination to refer to a container of a stated type
a dish, bowl, etc. made by hand out of clay

pot.eg: She's got pots of money (= she's very rich).

pot.eng_def: a potty (= bowl used by children as a toilet)
to be damaged or spoiled because people are not working hard on it or caring for it
pot.eg: I'm afraid I've let the garden go to pot this summer.

pot.eng_def: an act of hitting a ball into a hole, especially in games such as snooker
pot.eg: Dawson made a difficult pot look very easy.

pot.eng_def: to shoot birds or small animals for food, or to shoot (at) them without taking careful aim
pot.chi_def: 射殺，射獵（飛禽或小動物）；隨手射（中）
pot.eg: He strolled through the fields, potting (at) the occasional rabbit.

pot.eng_def: in games such as snooker, to hit a ball so that it falls into one of the holes at the edge of the table
to put a plant into a container to grow
pot.eg: I'm just going to pot (up) these seedlings.

potato.eng_def: a round vegetable that grows underground and has white flesh with light brown, red, or pink skin, or the plant on which these grow

potential.eng_def: possible when the necessary conditions exist
potential.eg: A number of potential buyers have expressed interest in the company.

potential.eng_def: someone's or something's ability to develop, achieve, or succeed
potential.eg: The region has enormous potential for economic development.

pottery.eng_def: the activity or skill of making clay objects by hand
objects that are made out of clay by hand
pottery.eg: They sell pottery and other handmade goods.

poultry.eng_def: birds, such as chickens, that are bred for their eggs and meat
poultry.eg: Some poultry farmers keep turkeys and ducks as well as chickens.

poultry.eng_def: the meat from birds such as chickens

pound.eng_def: the standard unit of money used in the UK and some other countries
pound.chi_def: 鎊（英國等國家的貨幣單位）

pound.eng_def: the value of the UK pound, used in comparing the values of different types of money from around the world
pound.eg: The devaluation of the pound will make British goods more competitive abroad.
One pound is approximately equal to 454 grams.

pound.eng_def: to hit or beat repeatedly with a lot of force, or to crush something by hitting it repeatedly
pound.chi_def: 連續重擊；搗碎；猛烈襲擊
pound.eg: I could feel my heart pounding as I went on stage to collect the prize.

pour.eng_def: to make a substance flow from a container, especially into another container, by raising just one side of the container that the substance is in
pour.eg: I spilled the juice while I was pouring it.

pour.eng_def: to (cause to) flow quickly and in large amounts
pour.eg: The bus was pouring out thick black exhaust fumes.

poverty.eng_def: the condition of being extremely poor
poverty.eg: Two million people in the city live in abject (= very great) poverty.

poverty.eng_def: a lack of something or when the quality of something is extremely low
poverty.eg: There is a disappointing poverty of creativity in their work.

powder.eng_def: a loose, dry substance that consists of extremely small pieces, usually made by breaking something up and crushing it
a soft, dry substance that is spread over the skin of the face, in order to stop the skin from looking shiny
fallen snow that is loose and dry and has not begun to melt
powder.eg: I love skiing in deep powder.

powder.eng_def: to put powder on someone's skin
powder.eg: Powder the baby's bottom to stop it chafing.

power.eng_def: ability to control people and events
power.eg: I've no power over him - he does what he wants to.

power.eng_def: the amount of political control a person or group has in a country
power.eg: Does the president have more power than the prime minister?
Our car doesn't have enough power to tow a trailer.

power.eng_def: an official or legal right to do something
power.eg: I'd like to help but I don't have the power to intervene in this dispute.
You were acting beyond your powers when you agreed to give her a pay rise.

power.eng_def: electricity, especially when considering its use or production
power.eg: You should disconnect the power before attempting to repair electrical equipment.
My mental powers aren't as good as they used to be.

power.eng_def: a natural skill or an ability to do something
power.eg: He was so shocked by what happened to his parents that he lost the power of speech.

power.eng_def: a person, organization, or country that has control over others, often because of wealth, importance, or great military strength
power.chi_def: 掌握大權的人；有影響力的機構；強國
power.eg: Spain was an important military power in the 16th century.

power.eng_def: the rate at which energy is used, or the ability to produce energy
power.eg: The ship was only slightly damaged in the collision and was able to sail into port under its own power.

power.eng_def: the amount by which an image is increased by a device used for seeing things that are very small or a long distance away
power.eg: What's the magnification power of your binoculars?

power.eng_def: the number of times that a number is to be multiplied by itself
power.eg: 2 to the fourth power is 2 times 2 times 2 times 2, which equals 16.

power.eng_def: to provide a machine with energy and the ability to operate
power.eg: Buses and trucks are usually powered by diesel engines.

power.eng_def: to act with great strength or in a forceful way
power.eg: Halfway through, she powered into the lead and went on to win the race.

powerful.eng_def: having a lot of power to control people and events
powerful.chi_def: 有權力的；有力量的；強大的
powerful.eg: The president is more powerful than the prime minister.

powerful.eng_def: having a lot of strength or force
having the power to increase the size of an image of something that is very small or far away many times
powerful.chi_def: 高倍率的，高放大倍數的
powerful.eg: You'd need an extremely powerful microscope to see something so small.

practical.eng_def: relating to experience, real situations, or actions rather than ideas or imagination
practical.chi_def: 實際的；實做的；有實際經驗的
practical.eg: Qualifications are important but practical experience is always a plus.
Dr Frampton is in charge, but for all practical purposes, her assistant runs the office.

practical.eng_def: suitable for the situation in which something is used
practical.eg: I tend to wear clothes that are practical rather than fashionable.

practical.eng_def: able to provide effective solutions to problems
practical.chi_def: 實用的，有效的；能解決問題的
practical.eg: She has lots of interesting ideas, but they're not very practical.

practical.eng_def: able to be done or put into action
practical.chi_def: 可實施的，切實可行的；切合實際的
practical.eg: It's simply not practical to divide the work between so many people.

practical.eng_def: a class or exam in a scientific or technical subject in which students do things rather than just write or talk about them
practical.chi_def: 實踐課，實驗課；實驗考核
practical.eg: We had to dissect a worm and a frog in our biology practical today.

practice.eng_def: action rather than thought or ideas
practice.eg: How do you intend to put these proposals into practice, Mohamed?

practice.eng_def: used to describe what really happens as opposed to what you think will happen in a particular situation
practice.chi_def: （用來描述真正發生的事，而不是預計會發生的事）實際上
practice.eg: It seemed like a good idea before we started, but in practice it was a disaster.

practice.eng_def: something that is usually or regularly done, often as a habit, tradition, or custom
practice.eg: What can European companies learn from Japanese business practices?
I'll do your washing for you this time, but I'm not going to make a practice of it.

practice.eng_def: the act of doing something regularly or repeatedly to improve your skill at doing it
practice.eg: I need to get some more practice before I take my driving test.

practice.eng_def: a job or business that involves a lot of skill or training

prairie.eng_def: a wide area of flat land without trees in Canada and the northern US
prairie.chi_def: （加拿大和美國北部的）大草原

praise.eng_def: to express admiration or approval of the achievements or characteristics of a person or thing
praise.eg: He should be praised for his honesty.

praise.eng_def: to honour, worship, and express admiration for a god
things that you say that express your admiration and approval of someone or something
praise.eg: They deserve praise for all their hard work.

praise.eng_def: an expression of respect and worship to a god
praise.eg: As we give praise to God, let us remember those who are less fortunate than ourselves.

pray.eng_def: to speak to a god either privately or in a religious ceremony in order to express love, admiration, or thanks or in order to ask for something
to hope for something very much
pray.eg: We're praying for good weather for tomorrow's game.
Pray tell your sister that I long to see her.

prayer.eng_def: the words that someone says or thinks when they are praying
the act or ceremony in which someone prays
prayer.eg: I found her kneeling in prayer at the back of the church.

preach.eng_def: (especially of a priest or minister in a church) to give a religious speech
preach.chi_def: （尤指牧師在教堂中）講道，佈道
preach.eg: Father Martin preached to the assembled mourners.

preach.eng_def: to try to persuade other people to believe in a particular belief or follow a particular way of life
preach.eg: They preach the abolition of established systems but propose nothing to replace them.

preach.eng_def: to give unwanted advice, especially about moral matters, in a boring way
preach.eg: He's such a pain - he's always preaching about the virtues of working hard and getting up early.

precaution.eng_def: an action that is done to prevent something unpleasant or dangerous happening
precaution.eg: Many people have been stockpiling food as a precaution against shortages.

precaution.eng_def: a polite way of referring to contraception (= methods that prevent a woman becoming pregnant)
precaution.eg: If you're going to have sex, make sure you take precautions.

precede.eng_def: to be or go before something or someone in time or space
precede.chi_def: （指時間或空間上）處在…之前，先於
precede.eg: Kofi Annan preceded Ban Ki-moon as the Secretary-General of the UN.

precedent.eng_def: an action, situation, or decision that has already happened and can be used as a reason why a similar action or decision should be performed or made
precedent.eg: There are several precedents for promoting people who don't have formal qualifications.

precedent.eng_def: the way that something has been done in the past that therefore shows that it is the correct way
precedent.eg: Would it be breaking with precedent for the bride to make a speech?

precedent.eng_def: a decision about a particular legal case that makes it likely that other similar cases will be decided in the same way
precedent.eg: The judgment on pension rights has established/set a precedent.

precious.eng_def: of great value because of being rare, expensive, or important
behaving in a very formal and unnatural way by giving too much attention to details that are not important and trying too hard to be perfect
precious.eg: He's so precious about his work that he never gets anything done.

precious.eng_def: used to express dislike and/or anger
precious.chi_def: （表示討厭和／或惱怒）寶貝似的
precious.eg: You and your precious car - it's all you're interested in!
Lots of people will start, but precious few will finish.

precise.eg: The bunker's precise location is a closely guarded secret.

precise.eng_def: very careful and accurate, especially about small details
precise.chi_def: （尤指在細節上）嚴謹的，細緻的
precise.eg: Years of doing meticulous research had made her very precise in her working methods.

precision.eg: Great precision is required to align the mirrors accurately.

precision.eng_def: the qualities of being careful and accurate
precision.eg: His books are a pleasure to read because he writes with such clarity and precision.

predecessor.eng_def: someone who had a job or a position before someone else, or something that comes before another thing in time or in a series
predecessor.chi_def: 前任，前輩；原有事物，前身
predecessor.eg: My predecessor worked in this job for twelve years.

predict.eng_def: to say that an event or action will happen in the future, especially as a result of knowledge or experience
predict.eg: It's still not possible to accurately predict the occurrence of earthquakes.

prediction.eng_def: a statement about what you think will happen in the future
prediction.eg: Please don't ask me to make any predictions about tomorrow's meeting.

preface.eng_def: an introduction at the beginning of a book explaining its purpose, thanking people who helped the author, etc.
preface.eg: In his preface, the author says that he took eight years to write the book.

preface.eng_def: an event that comes before something more important
preface.eg: We're hoping these talks could be a preface to peace.

preface.eng_def: If you preface your words or actions with something else, you say or do this other thing first.
preface.chi_def: 為…寫序言；作為…的開端（或序幕）
preface.eg: Each work is prefaced by a descriptive note and concludes with an author's note.

prefer.eng_def: to like, choose, or want one thing rather than another
prefer.chi_def: 寧可，更喜愛；覺得還是…更可取
prefer.eg: Do you prefer hot or cold weather?
The police have decided not to prefer charges against them because of insufficient evidence.

preferable.chi_def: 更可取的，更好的，較合適的
preferable.eg: Surely a diplomatic solution is preferable to war.

preference.eng_def: the fact that you like something or someone more than another thing or person
preference.eg: Her preference is for comfortable rather than stylish clothes.

preference.eng_def: an advantage that is given to a person or a group of people
preference.eg: We give preference to those who have worked with us for a long time.

preference.eng_def: If you choose one thing in preference to another thing, you choose it because you like or want it more than the other thing.
preference.eg: He studied chemistry in preference to physics at university.

pregnancy.eg: Most women feel sick in the mornings during their first months of pregnancy.

pregnant.eng_def: (of a woman and some female animals) having a baby or babies developing inside the womb
pregnant.eg: She's five and a half months pregnant.

pregnant.eng_def: filled with meaning or importance that has not yet been expressed or understood
pregnant.chi_def: 意味深長的，意義重大的
pregnant.eg: There followed a pregnant pause in which both knew what the other was thinking but neither knew what to say.

prehistoric.eng_def: describing the period before there were written records
prehistoric.chi_def: 史前的，有文字記載的歷史以前的
老舊不堪的，完全過時的
prehistoric.eg: He has prehistoric views about women who have careers.

prejudice.eng_def: an unfair and unreasonable opinion or feeling, especially when formed without enough thought or knowledge
prejudice.eg: Laws against racial prejudice must be strictly enforced.

prejudice.eng_def: If a decision or action is made without prejudice to a right or claim, it is made without having an effect on that right or claim.
prejudice.eg: My client accepts the formal apology without prejudice to any further legal action she may decide to take.

prejudice.eng_def: Someone or something that prejudices you influences you unfairly so that you form an unreasonable opinion about something.
prejudice.chi_def: 使有成見，使有偏見，使產生歧視
prejudice.eg: His comments may have prejudiced the voters against her.

prejudice.eng_def: Something or someone that prejudices something else has a harmful influence on it.
prejudice.eg: The fact that you were late all this week may prejudice your chances of getting a promotion.

preliminary.eng_def: coming before a more important action or event, especially introducing or preparing for it
preliminary.eg: Preliminary results show that the vaccine is effective, but this has to be confirmed by further medical trials.

preliminary.eng_def: an event or action that introduces or prepares for something else
preliminary.eg: After a few polite preliminaries (= introductions), we stated our main ideas and intentions.

premature.eng_def: happening or done too soon, especially before the natural or suitable time
premature.chi_def: 過早的；不成熟的；倉促的

premier.eg: He's one of the nation's premier scientists.

premier.eng_def: (especially used in news reports) the leader of the government of a country, or of a large part of a country

preparation.eng_def: the things that you do or the time that you spend preparing for something
preparation.eg: The teacher didn't seem to have done much preparation for the class.

preparation.eng_def: plans or arrangements that you make to prepare for something
preparation.eg: We are making preparations to fly Mr Goodall to the nearest hospital.

preparation.eng_def: a mixture of substances, often for use as a medicine

prepare.eng_def: to make or get something or someone ready for something that will happen in the future
prepare.chi_def: 準備，預備；把…準備好，使預備好
prepare.eg: Have you prepared for your interview?

prepare.eng_def: to expect that something will happen and to be ready for it
prepare.chi_def: （在思想上或心理上）作好準備；防範
prepare.eg: It almost seems as if she is preparing to die.

preposition.eng_def: in grammar, a word that is used before a noun, a noun phrase, or a pronoun, connecting it to another word
preposition.eg: In the sentences "We jumped in the lake", and "She drove slowly down the track", "in" and "down" are prepositions.

prescribe.eng_def: (of a doctor) to say what medical treatment someone should have
prescribe.eg: The drug is often prescribed for ulcers.

prescribe.eng_def: to tell someone what they must have or do, or to make a rule of something
prescribe.eg: Penalties for not paying taxes are prescribed by law.

prescription.eng_def: a piece of paper on which a doctor writes the details of the medicine or drugs that someone needs
prescription.chi_def: 處方，藥方；處方上開的藥

prescription.eng_def: the act of telling someone else what they must have or do
prescription.eg: So what is his prescription for success?

presence.eng_def: the fact that someone or something is in a place
presence.chi_def: 出席，在場；（事物的）存在，出現
presence.eg: She was overawed by the presence of so many people.

presence.eng_def: a feeling that someone is still in a place although they are not there or are dead
presence.eg: His daughter's presence seemed to fill her empty bedroom.

presence.eng_def: a group of police or soldiers who are watching or controlling a situation
presence.chi_def: （觀察控制形勢的）一隊員警（或部隊）
presence.eg: The United Nations has maintained a presence in the region for some time.

presence.eng_def: a quality that makes people notice or admire you, even when you are not speaking

present.eng_def: something that you are given, without asking for it, on a special occasion, especially to show friendship, or to say thank you
present.chi_def: （尤指表示友誼或致謝的）禮物，贈品

present.eng_def: the period of time that is happening now, not the past or the future
the form of the verb that is used to show what happens or exists now
present.eg: The verb in this sentence is in the present.
I don't have her present address.

present.eng_def: to give, provide, or make something known
present.eg: The winners were presented with medals.

present.eng_def: to introduce a television or radio show
present.chi_def: 主持播出（電視或廣播節目）

present.eng_def: to arrive somewhere and introduce yourself
present.eg: He presented himself at the doctor's at 9.30 a.m. as arranged.

present.eng_def: If something presents itself, it happens.

presentation.eng_def: a talk giving information about something
presentation.eg: The speaker gave an interesting presentation on urban transport.

presentation.eng_def: an occasion when prizes, qualifications, etc. are formally given to those who have won or achieved them
presentation.eg: The presentation of prizes and certificates will take place in the main hall.

presentation.eng_def: the way something looks when it is shown to other people, or the way someone looks
presentation.eg: Presentation is important if you want people to buy your products.

preservation.eng_def: the act of keeping something the same or of preventing it from being damaged

preserve.eng_def: to keep something as it is, especially in order to prevent it from decaying or being damaged or destroyed
to treat food in a particular way so that it can be kept for a long time without going bad
a food made from fruit or vegetables boiled with sugar and water until it becomes a firm sauce
an activity that only one person or a particular type of person does or is responsible for
preserve.eg: Owning racehorses is the preserve of the rich.

preserve.chi_def: （尤指野生動物）保護區（同 reserve）

preside.eng_def: to be in charge of a formal meeting, ceremony, or trial
preside.eg: Who would be the best person to preside at/over the public enquiry?

presidency.eng_def: the job of being president, or the period when someone is a president
presidency.eg: He has announced that he is running for the presidency.

president.eng_def: (the title given to) the person who has the highest political position in a country that is a republic and who, in some of these countries, is the leader of the government
the person who has the highest position in an organization or, especially in the US, in a company
president.chi_def: （機構的）負責人，會長，主席；（尤指美國的）總裁，董事長
president.eg: a former president of the Royal Society

presidential.chi_def: 副總統的；副總裁的，副總經理的

press.eng_def: to push something firmly, often without causing it to move permanently further away from you
press.eg: Press the button to start the machine.

press.eng_def: to make clothes smooth by ironing them
to put a weight on fruit in order to remove the juice
to make a CD, DVD, etc.
press.eg: Over 3,000 copies of the CD were pressed and sent out to college radio stations.

press.eng_def: to make something flat and firm by putting it under something heavy
to try hard to persuade someone to do something
press.eg: The committee pressed him to reveal more information.

press.eng_def: to complain officially about someone in a law court
press.eg: The family have decided not to press charges against him.

press.eng_def: to continue to try to make people accept your demands
press.eg: Once again he tried to press his case for promotion.

press.eng_def: newspapers and magazines, and those parts of television and radio that broadcast news, or reporters and photographers who work for them
press.chi_def: 報刊；報道；新聞界；記者，新聞工作者
press.eg: The incident has been widely reported in the press.

press.eng_def: the judgment that is given of someone or something in the newspapers or on radio or television
press.eg: What kind of press did his play get?

press.eng_def: a business that prints and produces books and similar things
a machine that is used for printing

press.eg: The newspaper will go to press at midnight.

press.eng_def: a firm push against something using the fingers
press.eg: To start the machine, just give this button a press.

press.eng_def: the act of making cloth smooth with an iron
press.eg: Can you give this shirt a quick press?

press.eng_def: a piece of equipment that is used to put weight on something in order to crush it, remove liquid from it or to make it flat

pressure.eng_def: the force you produce when you press something
pressure.eg: He put too much pressure on the door handle and it snapped.

pressure.eng_def: the force that a liquid or gas produces when it presses against an area
the act of trying to make someone else do something by arguing, persuading, etc.
a difficult situation that makes you feel worried or unhappy
pressure.eg: She's got a lot of pressure on her at work just now.

pressure.eng_def: something that you say when what someone has just said makes you feel that you must try very hard to do something
pressure.eg: "These exams are the most important of all." "Oh, so no pressure then!"

pressure.eng_def: a situation in a football game in which attacking players are moving forward and getting closer to scoring a goal, and players from the opposing team have to work hard to stop them from scoring
pressure.chi_def: （足球比賽中）一方向前進攻，臨近進球，對方不得不全力防守
pressure.eg: Ryan Giggs put the home defence under pressure.

pressure.eng_def: to strongly persuade someone to do something they do not want to do
pressure.eg: She was pressured into joining the club.

prestige.eng_def: respect and admiration given to someone or something, usually because of a reputation for high quality, success, or social influence
prestige.eg: The company has gained international prestige.

prestige.eng_def: causing admiration because of being connected with being rich or powerful
prestige.chi_def: 有威望的，有威信的；令人羨慕的

presume.eng_def: to believe something to be true because it is very likely, although you are not certain
presume.eg: I presume (that) they're not coming, since they haven't replied to the invitation.

presume.eng_def: to do something although you know that you do not have a right to do it
presume.eg: I wouldn't presume to tell you how to do your job, but shouldn't this piece go there?

pretend.eng_def: to behave as if something is true when you know that it is not, especially in order to deceive people or as a game
pretend.eg: He pretended (that) he didn't mind, but I knew that he did.

pretend.eng_def: to not claim something that is false
pretend.eg: I don't pretend to be an expert on the subject.
"Do you want a cup of tea?" she asks, offering me a pretend cup.

pretty.eg: The house has four bedrooms, so it's pretty big.

pretty.chi_def: 差不多；幾乎全部地，幾乎完全地

pretty.eng_def: pleasant to look at, or (especially of girls or women or things relating to them) attractive or pleasant in a delicate way
pretty.chi_def: （尤指女孩、女子或與其相關事物）漂亮的，美麗的，標緻的
pretty.eg: That's a pretty hat you're wearing.

prevail.eg: I am sure that common sense will prevail in the end.

prevail.eng_def: to be common among a group of people or area at a particular time
prevail.eg: This attitude still prevails among the middle classes.

prevent.eng_def: to stop something from happening or someone from doing something
prevent.eg: Label your suitcases to prevent confusion.

prevention.eng_def: the act of stopping something from happening or of stopping someone from doing something

preventive.eng_def: intended to stop something before it happens
preventive.eg: In the past ten years, preventive measures have radically reduced levels of tooth decay in children.

preview.eng_def: an opportunity to see something such as a film or a collection of works of art before it is shown to the public, or a description of something such as a television programme before it is shown to the public
preview.chi_def: 預覽；預展；預映；（電視節目等的）預告

preview.eng_def: short parts of a television show or film that are shown to the public in order to advertise it
to describe something or be shown before it officially begins
preview.eg: Miller's new play is previewing (= being performed publicly before it officially opens) at the Theatre Royal tomorrow.

previous.eng_def: happening or existing before something or someone else
previous.eg: The previous owner of the house had built an extension on the back.

prey.eng_def: an animal that is hunted and killed for food by another animal
prey.eg: A hawk hovered in the air before swooping on its prey.

price.eng_def: the amount of money for which something is sold
price.eg: The price of oil has risen sharply.

price.eng_def: the unpleasant results that you must accept or experience for getting or doing something
price.eg: Perhaps being unpopular is the price of success.

price.eng_def: to say what the price of something is
to discover how much something costs
price.eg: We went around all the travel agents pricing the different tours.

priceless.eng_def: A priceless object has such a high value, especially because it is rare, that the price of it cannot be calculated.
priceless.eg: A priceless collection of vases was destroyed.

priceless.eng_def: extremely funny to see or hear
priceless.eg: You should have seen the look on her face when I told her - it was priceless!

prick.eng_def: to make a very small hole or holes in the surface of something, sometimes in a way that causes pain
prick.eg: Prick the skin of the potatoes with a fork before baking them.
I'm not wearing that - I'd look a complete prick.

pride.eng_def: a feeling of pleasure and satisfaction that you get because you or people connected with you have done or got something good
pride.eg: She felt a great sense of pride as she watched him accept the award.

pride.eng_def: to feel very pleased about something or someone you are closely connected with
pride.eg: If you don't take professional pride in your work, you're probably in the wrong job.

pride.eng_def: your feelings of your own worth and respect for yourself
pride.eg: She has too much pride to accept any help.

pride.eng_def: the belief that you are better or more important than other people

priest.eng_def: a person, usually a man, who has been trained to perform religious duties in the Christian Church, especially the Roman Catholic Church, or a person with particular duties in some other religions
priest.chi_def: 神父，牧師，司鐸；（基督教以外的）神職人員
priest.eg: Father O'Dooley was ordained a priest in 1949.

primary.eng_def: more important than anything else; main
primary.eg: The Red Cross's primary concern is to preserve and protect human life.

primary.eng_def: of or for the teaching of young children, especially those between five and eleven years old
in the US, an election in which people choose who will represent a particular party in an election for political office
primary.chi_def: （美國推舉黨內候選人的）初選

prime.eg: This is a prime example of 1930s architecture.

prime.eng_def: the period in your life when you are most active or successful
prime.chi_def: 全盛時期；盛年，壯年時期
prime.eg: This is a dancer in her prime.

prime.eng_def: to tell someone something that will prepare them for a particular situation
prime.chi_def: 事先給（某人）提供情況，使有所準備
prime.eg: I'd been primed so I knew not to mention her son.

prime.eng_def: to cover the surface of wood with a special paint before the main paint is put on
prime.chi_def: 在（木質表面）上塗底漆（或底色）

prime.eng_def: to make a bomb or gun ready to explode or fire

primitive.eng_def: relating to human society at a very early stage of development, with people living in a simple way without machines or a writing system
primitive.eg: Primitive races colonized these islands 2,000 years ago.

primitive.eng_def: Primitive living conditions are basic, unpleasant, and uncomfortable.
primitive.eg: Early settlers had to cope with very primitive living conditions.

prince.eng_def: an important male member of a royal family, especially a son or grandson of the king or queen
a male ruler of a country, usually a small country
prince.eg: Prince Albert II is the ruling prince of Monaco.

prince.eng_def: a man who is excellent at something
prince.eg: that prince of flautists, William Bennett

princess.eng_def: an important female member of a royal family, especially a daughter or granddaughter of a king and queen, or the wife of a prince
princess.eg: Lady Diana Spencer became Princess Diana when she married Prince Charles.

principal.eng_def: the person in charge of a school
the person in charge of a college or university
an amount of money that someone has invested in a bank or lent to a person or organization so that they will receive interest on it from the bank, person, or organization
principal.eg: She lives off the interest and tries to keep the principal intact.

principle.eng_def: a basic idea or rule that explains or controls how something happens or works
principle.eg: the principles of the criminal justice system

principle.eng_def: If you agree with or believe something in principle, you agree with the idea in general, although you might not support it in reality or in every situation.
principle.eg: In principle I agree with the idea, but in practice it's not always possible.

principle.eng_def: a moral rule or standard of good behaviour

print.eng_def: letters, numbers, or symbols that have been produced on paper by a machine using ink
print.eg: The title is in bold print.
The debate is still raging, both in print and online.

print.eng_def: If a book is in print, it is possible to buy a new copy of it, and if it is out of print, it is not now possible.
print.eg: Is her work still in print?

print.eng_def: a photographic copy of a painting, or a picture made by pressing paper onto a special surface covered in ink, or a single photograph from a film
print.chi_def: （用照相製版法製作的）繪畫複製品；印出的版畫；（底片洗出的單張）照片

print.eng_def: any type of pattern produced using ink on a piece of clothing

print.eg: The burglar had left his prints all over the window.

print.eng_def: to produce writing or images on paper or other material with a machine
print.eg: The leaflets will be printed on recycled paper.

print.eng_def: to include a piece of writing in a newspaper or magazine
print.eg: Some newspapers still refuse to print certain swear words.

print.eng_def: to produce a newspaper, magazine, or book in large quantities
print.eg: 20,000 copies of the novel will be printed in hardback.

print.eng_def: to write without joining the letters together
print.eg: Please print your name clearly below your signature.

print.eng_def: to produce a photograph on paper
print.eg: Photographs are better if they are printed from the original negative.

print.eng_def: to produce a pattern on material or paper
print.eg: The designs are printed onto the fabric by hand.

printer.eng_def: a machine that is connected to a computer and prints onto paper using ink
a person whose job is to print books, newspapers, and magazines

prior.eng_def: existing or happening before something else, or before a particular time
prior.eg: The course required no prior knowledge of Spanish.

prior.eng_def: before a particular time or event
prior.eg: the weeks prior to her death
Mothers with young children have a prior claim on funds.

prior.eng_def: a man who is in charge of a priory or who is second in charge of an abbey
prior.chi_def: 小修道院長；修道院副院長

priority.eng_def: something that is very important and must be dealt with before other things
priority.eg: The management did not seem to consider office safety to be a priority.

prison.eng_def: a building where criminals are forced to live as a punishment
prison.eg: Conditions in the prison are said to be appalling.

prison.eng_def: the system of keeping people in prisons
a situation or relationship from which it is difficult to escape
prison.eg: She felt that her marriage had become a prison.

prisoner.eng_def: a person who is kept in prison as a punishment
prisoner.eg: Prisoners climbed onto the prison roof to protest the conditions inside the prison.

prisoner.eng_def: to catch and guard someone so that they cannot escape
prisoner.eg: Of 10,000 troops, 7,000 were killed, wounded, or taken prisoner.

privacy.eng_def: someone's right to keep their personal matters and relationships secret
privacy.eg: The new law is designed to protect people's privacy.
I hate sharing a bedroom - I never get any privacy.

private.eng_def: only for one person or group and not for everyone
private.eg: She has a small office that is used for private discussions.

private.eng_def: Private activities involve personal matters or relationships and are not related to your work.
private.eg: Apparently in interviews he refuses to talk about his private life.

private.eng_def: Private thoughts and opinions are secret and not discussed with other people.
private.eg: Although I support the project in public, my private opinion is that it will fail.

private.eng_def: A private place is quiet and has no other people to see or hear you.
private.eg: Is there somewhere private where we can talk?

private.eng_def: A private person does not like to talk about their personal feelings and thoughts.
private.chi_def: 不願吐露心思的；不愛交流思想的；內向的

private.eng_def: If you talk to someone or do something in private, you do it without other people being present.
private.eg: Jamie wants to speak to me in private.

private.eng_def: controlled or paid for by a person or company and not by the government
a soldier of the lowest rank in an army

privilege.eng_def: an advantage that only one person or group of people has, usually because of their position or because they are rich
privilege.chi_def: （特定個體或群體的）特權，特別待遇
privilege.eg: Healthcare should be a right, not a privilege.

privilege.eng_def: an opportunity to do something special or enjoyable
privilege.eg: I had the privilege of interviewing Picasso in the 1960s.

privilege.eng_def: the way in which rich people or people from a high social class have most of the advantages in society
privilege.chi_def: （富人或有權勢者的）特權，特別待遇

privilege.eng_def: the special right that some people in authority have that allows them to do or say things that other people are not allowed to

prize.eng_def: something valuable, such as an amount of money, that is given to someone who succeeds in a competition or game or that is given to someone as a reward for doing very good work
prize.eg: The critics' prize for best film was won by Marc Abbott for "Belly Laugh".

prize.eng_def: something important and valuable that is difficult to achieve or get
prize.chi_def: 難能可貴的東西；不易達到的目標
prize.eg: The prize would be her hand in marriage.

prize.eng_def: to think that someone or something is very valuable or important
prize.eg: In parts of Asia this plant is prized for its medicinal qualities.

prize.eng_def: to use force to lift something off something else, for example by pressing a tool against a fixed point; to separate things using force
prize.eg: I prized the lid off with a spoon.

prize.eng_def: A prize animal, flower, or vegetable is one that has won or deserves to win a prize in a competition because it is of very good quality.
prize.chi_def: （指動物、花或蔬菜）得獎的；該得獎的；一流的

prize.eng_def: used to describe something that is a very good or important example of its type

probable.eng_def: likely to be true or likely to happen
probable.chi_def: 很可能真實的；很可能發生的
probable.eg: The probable cause of death was heart failure.

problem.eng_def: a situation, person, or thing that needs attention and needs to be dealt with or solved
problem.chi_def: （須解決的）問題；疑難問題，困難

problem.eng_def: a question in mathematics that needs an answer
problem.eg: We were given ten problems to solve.

problem.eng_def: a child, etc. whose behaviour is bad

procedure.eng_def: a set of actions that is the official or accepted way of doing something
procedure.eg: The company has new procedures for dealing with complaints.

procedure.eng_def: a set of instructions in a computer program that does a particular task

proceed.eg: His lawyers have decided not to proceed with the case.

proceed.eng_def: to do something after you have done something else
proceed.eg: She sat down and proceeded to tell me about her skiing holiday.

proceed.eng_def: to move forward or travel in a particular direction
proceed.eg: Passengers for Madrid should proceed to gate 26 for boarding.

process.eng_def: a series of actions that you take in order to achieve a result
a series of changes that happen naturally
a method of producing goods in a factory by treating natural substances
process.eg: They have developed a new process for extracting aluminium from bauxite.

process.eng_def: to deal with documents in an official way
process.eg: Visa applications take 28 days to process.

process.eng_def: If a computer processes information, it performs a particular series of operations on the information, such as a set of calculations.
to prepare, change, or treat food or natural substances as a part of an industrial operation
to make pictures from photographic film
process.eg: I need to get those films processed.
We watched them process down the aisle.

procession.eng_def: a line of people who are all walking or travelling in the same direction, especially in a formal way as part of a religious ceremony or public celebration
a series of people or things, one after the other
procession.eg: My day has just been a never-ending procession of visitors.

produce.eng_def: to make something or bring something into existence
produce.eg: France produces a great deal of wine for export.

produce.eng_def: When animals produce young, they give birth to them.
produce.eg: Our cat produced four kittens during the course of the night.

produce.eng_def: to cause a reaction or result
produce.eg: The senator's speech produced an angry response from the opposition.

produce.eng_def: to organize the practical and financial matters relating to the preparation of a film, play, or television or radio programme
to be in charge of making a musical recording and to be responsible for the arrangement of the music, the combination of the different instruments or voices and the general sound of it
to bring something out from somewhere and show it
produce.eg: He produced a letter from his desk that he asked me to read.

produce.eng_def: to result in or discover something, especially proof
produce.eg: A lengthy police investigation failed to produce any evidence on which the suspect could be convicted.

produce.eng_def: food or any other substance or material that is grown or obtained through farming
produce.chi_def: （尤指大量生產的）食品，農產品

producer.eng_def: a person who makes the practical and financial arrangements needed to make a film, play, or television or radio programme
a person who makes the practical and financial arrangements needed to make a CD or other recording
a company, country, or person that provides goods, especially those that are produced by an industrial process or grown or obtained through farming, usually in large amounts
producer.chi_def: （尤指工業品或農牧業產品的）生產者，生產公司，出產國

product.eng_def: something that is made to be sold, usually something that is produced by an industrial process or, less commonly, something that is grown or obtained through farming
product.eg: They do a range of skin-care products.
A figure like that is usually the product of many hours spent in the gym.

product.eng_def: the result you get when two or more numbers are multiplied together

production.eng_def: the process of making or growing goods to be sold
production.eg: Coke is used in the production of steel.

production.eng_def: the amount of something that is made or grown by a country or a company
production.eg: Swedish industrial production has fallen steadily this year.

production.eng_def: the activity of organizing the practical and financial matters relating to the preparation of a film, play, or television or radio programme
production.eg: She's hoping to get into television production.

production.eng_def: a particular series of performances of a theatre entertainment such as a play or opera
production.eg: They're doing a new production of Macbeth at the National Theatre.

production.eng_def: the preparation and general quality of a musical recording's sound, showing the way in which the music was recorded rather than the quality of the singing and the music
production.eg: George Martin did the production on the Beatles records.

production.eng_def: the act of taking something out and showing it
production.eg: Entry to the club is only permitted on production (= the showing) of a membership card.

productive.eng_def: resulting in or providing a large amount or supply of something
productive.eg: In order to turn the deserts into fertile and productive land, engineers built an 800-mile canal.
We had a very productive meeting - I felt we solved lots of problems.

productivity.eng_def: the rate at which a company or country makes goods, usually judged in connection with the number of people and the amount of materials necessary to produce the goods
productivity.eg: Studies show that if a working environment is pleasant, productivity increases.

profession.eng_def: any type of work that needs special training or a particular skill, often one that is respected because it involves a high level of education
profession.chi_def: （尤指需要特殊訓練或專業技能的）職業
profession.eg: He left the teaching profession in 1965 to start his own business.

profession.eng_def: the people who do a particular type of work, considered as a group
profession.chi_def: 某職業的全體人員；同行，同業
profession.eg: There's a feeling among the nursing profession that their work is undervalued.

profession.eng_def: jobs that need special training and skill, such as being a doctor or lawyer, but not work in business or industry
profession.chi_def: （醫生或律師等需特殊訓練或技能的）職業

profession.eng_def: a statement about what someone feels, believes, or intends to do, often made publicly
profession.eg: The energy companies' professions of commitment to the environment seem less believable every day.

professional.eng_def: relating to work that needs special training or education
professional.eg: Chris, you're a nurse, so can I ask your professional opinion on bandaging ankles?

professional.eng_def: having the qualities that you connect with trained and skilled people, such as effectiveness, skill, organization, and seriousness of manner
professional.chi_def: 非常內行的；極為稱職的
professional.eg: It would look more professional if the letter was typed.

professional.eng_def: used to describe someone who does a job that people usually do as a hobby
professional.chi_def: 把（別人通常作為愛好的活動）作為職業的

professional.eng_def: having the type of job that is respected because it involves a high level of education and training
professional.chi_def: 專業人士的；為專業人士的
professional.eg: Room for rent in shared house - would suit professional person.

professional.eng_def: a person who has the type of job that needs a high level of education and training
someone who has worked hard in the same type of job for a long time and has become skilled at dealing with any problem that might happen
professional.eg: I thought the whole meeting was going to fall apart but you rescued it like a true professional!

professional.eng_def: a person who does a job that people usually do as a hobby
professional.chi_def: 把（別人通常作為愛好的活動）作為職業的人
professional.eg: He's only been playing football as a professional for two years.

professional.eng_def: a person who plays a sport, especially a golf or tennis player, who is employed by a club to train its members in a particular sport
professional.chi_def: （受僱於高爾夫或網球協會的）職業教練

professor.eng_def: a teacher of the highest rank in a department of a British university, or a teacher of high rank in an American university or college

profile.eng_def: a short description of someone's life, work, character, etc.
the amount of public attention and notice that something receives
profile.eg: We need to increase our company's profile in Asia.

profile.eng_def: a side view of a person's face
profile.eg: Drawing profiles is somehow easier than drawing the full face.

profit.eng_def: money that is earned in trade or business after paying the costs of producing and selling goods and services
profit.eg: She makes a big profit from selling waste material to textile companies.

profit.eng_def: to begin to earn a profit
profit.eg: He’s been in business five years, but has not yet turned a profit.

profit.eng_def: the good result or advantage that can be achieved by a particular action or activity
profit.eg: There's no profit to be gained from endlessly discussing whose fault it was.

profitable.eng_def: resulting in or likely to result in a profit or an advantage
profitable.eg: Over the years it has developed into a highly profitable business.

profound.eng_def: felt or experienced very strongly or in an extreme way
profound.eg: His mother's death when he was aged six had a very profound effect on him.

profound.eng_def: showing a clear and deep understanding of serious matters

program.eng_def: a series of instructions that can be put into a computer in order to make it perform an operation
US and Australian English spelling of  programme UK
program.chi_def: （美式和澳大利亞英語中programme的拼寫）

program.eng_def: to write a series of instructions that make a computer perform a particular operation
program.chi_def: 為（電腦）程式設計；編制…的程式
program.eg: She programmed the computer to calculate the rate of exchange in twelve currencies.

progress.eng_def: movement to an improved or more developed state, or to a forward position
progress.eg: Technological progress has been so rapid over the last few years.
Repair work is in progress on the south-bound lane of the motorway and will continue until June.

progress.eng_def: to improve or develop in skills, knowledge, etc.
progress.eg: My Spanish never really progressed beyond the stage of being able to order drinks at the bar.
As the war progressed, more and more countries became involved.

progressive.eg: There's been a progressive decline in the standard of living over the past few years.

progressive.eng_def: Progressive ideas or systems are new and modern, encouraging change in society or in the way that things are done.
progressive.chi_def: （指思想或體制）進步的，先進的

progressive.eng_def: A progressive tax system is one in which the rate of tax is higher on larger amounts of money.
The progressive form of a verb is used to show that the action is continuing. It is formed with the verb "be" followed by the present participle (= -ing form of the verb).
progressive.eg: "He's working hard at the moment" is an example of the present progressive form of the verb "work".

progressive.eng_def: a person who supports new ideas and social change, especially one who belongs to a political party
progressive.chi_def: 支持進步政策者；改革派人士

prohibit.eng_def: to officially refuse to allow something
prohibit.eg: Motor vehicles are prohibited from driving in the town centre.

prohibit.eng_def: to prevent a particular activity by making it impossible
prohibit.eg: The loudness of the music prohibits serious conversation in most nightclubs.

prohibition.eng_def: the act of officially not allowing something, or an order that does this
prohibition.eg: New York City has announced a prohibition on smoking on buses.

prohibition.eng_def: the period from 1920 to 1933 when the production and sale of alcohol was not allowed in the US
prohibition.chi_def: 禁酒時期（1920至1933年間美國禁止生產和銷售酒的時期）

project.eng_def: a piece of planned work or an activity that is finished over a period of time and intended to achieve a particular purpose
a study of a particular subject done over a period of time, especially by students
project.eg: He's doing a class project on pollution.

project.eng_def: to calculate an amount or number expected in the future from information already known
project.eg: Government spending is projected to rise by three percent next year.

project.eng_def: to throw or direct something forwards, with force
project.eg: 90 percent of the projected missiles will hit their target.

project.eng_def: to sing or speak loudly and clearly
project.eg: It's a big theatre so you really have to project your voice if you're going to be heard at the back.

project.eng_def: to cause a film, image, or light to appear on a screen or other surface
project.eg: Laser images were projected onto a screen.

project.eng_def: to wrongly imagine that someone else is feeling a particular emotion or desire when in fact it is you who feels this way
project.chi_def: 投射（自己的感覺給別人）
project.eg: I suspect he's projecting his fears onto you.

project.eng_def: If you project a particular quality, that quality is what most people notice about you.
project.eg: Recently the president has sought to project a much tougher image.

project.eng_def: to stick out over an edge or from a surface
project.eg: The hotel dining room projects out over the water.

projection.eng_def: a calculation or guess about the future based on information that you have
projection.eg: The company has failed to achieve last year's sales projections by 30 percent.

projection.eng_def: the act of projecting a film or an image onto a screen or wall
something that projects from a surface or above the edge of something
a drawing that represents a solid shape or a line as seen from a particular direction

prolong.eng_def: to make something last a longer time
prolong.eg: We were having such a good time that we decided to prolong our stay by another week.

prominent.eng_def: Something that is in a prominent position can easily be seen.
prominent.eg: New books are displayed in a prominent position on tables at the front of the store.

promise.eng_def: to tell someone that you will certainly do something
promise.eg: He promised faithfully to call me every week.

promise.eng_def: If something promises to be good, exciting, etc. it is expected to be good, exciting, etc.
promise.eg: It promises to be a really exciting game.

promise.eng_def: the act of saying that you will certainly do something
promise.eg: I'll put my things away tonight - and that's a promise!

promise.eng_def: to do/not do what you said that you would do
promise.eg: If I make a promise, I like to keep it.

promise.eng_def: the idea that someone or something is likely to develop successfully and that people expect this to happen
promise.chi_def: （成功的）跡象，徵兆；（有）出息，（有）前途
promise.eg: His English teacher had written on his report that he showed great promise.

promising.eng_def: Something that is promising shows signs that it is going to be successful or enjoyable.
promising.chi_def: 有希望的；有出息的；有前途的
promising.eg: They won the award for the most promising new band of the year.

promote.eng_def: to encourage people to like, buy, use, do, or support something
promote.eg: Advertising companies are always having to think up new ways to promote products.

promote.eng_def: to raise someone to a higher or more important position or rank
promote.eg: If I'm not promoted within the next two years, I'm going to change jobs.

promote.eng_def: to move a sports team to a higher group
promote.chi_def: （體育隊）晉級（至高一級別的聯賽組別）
promote.eg: If Coventry City win this match, they'll be promoted to the Premier League.

promote.eng_def: If a student is promoted, he or she goes up to the next level in school.

promotion.eng_def: the act of encouraging something to happen or develop
promotion.eg: the promotion of a healthy lifestyle

promotion.eng_def: the act of raising someone to a higher or more important position or rank
promotion.eg: Did Steve get/Was Steve given the promotion he wanted?

promotion.eng_def: If a sports team wins promotion, it moves to a higher division at the end of the season.
promotion.chi_def: （體育隊）晉級（至高一級別的聯賽組別）
promotion.eg: River Plate's win last night has considerably increased their chances of promotion this season.

prompt.eg: The bishop's speech has prompted an angry response from both political parties.

prompt.eng_def: to make someone decide to say or do something
prompt.chi_def: 促使（某人）決定說（或做）某事
prompt.eg: What prompted you to say that?

prompt.eng_def: to help someone, especially an actor, to remember what they were going to say or do
prompt.eg: I forgot my line and had to be prompted.

prompt.eng_def: (of an action) done quickly and without delay, or (of a person) acting quickly or arriving at the arranged time
prompt.eg: They've written back already - that was a very prompt reply.

prompt.eng_def: a sign on a computer screen that shows that the computer is ready to receive your instructions
prompt.chi_def: （電腦螢幕上的）提示符（顯示電腦已經準備好接受指令）

prompt.eng_def: words that are spoken to an actor who has forgotten what he or she is going to say during the performance of a play
a person whose job is to help actors, during a performance, to remember words that they have forgotten
at the time stated and no later
prompt.eg: We'll be leaving at six o'clock prompt.

prone.eng_def: likely to suffer from an illness or show a particular negative characteristic
prone.chi_def: 易於遭受（疾病）的；有（消極）傾向的
prone.eg: I've always been prone to headaches.
The photograph showed a man lying prone on the pavement, a puddle of blood around his head.

prone.eng_def: likely to experience a particular problem more often than is usual

pronoun.eng_def: a word that is used instead of a noun or a noun phrase
pronoun.eg: Pronouns are often used to refer to a noun that has already been mentioned.

pronounce.eng_def: to say a word or a letter in a particular way
pronounce.eg: How do you pronounce your surname?

pronounce.eng_def: to say something officially or certainly
pronounce.eg: He was taken to the hospital where he was pronounced dead on arrival.

proof.eng_def: a fact or piece of information that shows that something exists or is true
proof.eg: Do they have any proof that it was Hampson who stole the goods?

proof.eng_def: a printed copy of something that is examined and corrected before the final copies are printed
of the stated alcoholic strength, a higher number meaning a greater amount of alcohol
proof.eg: It says on the bottle that it's 60 percent proof.
No household security devices are proof against (= protect completely against) the determined burglar.

proof.eng_def: to treat a surface with a substance that will protect it against something, especially water
proof.chi_def: 給（表面）作防護處理；（尤指）給…作防水處理

proof.eng_def: protecting against, or not damaged by, a particular thing

prop.eng_def: to support something physically, often by leaning it against something else or putting something under it
prop.eg: I propped my bike (up) against the wall.

prop.eng_def: an object used by the actors performing in a play or film
prop.eg: The set is minimal and the only props used in the show are a table, a chair, and a glass of water.

prop.eng_def: an object that is used to support something by holding it up
prop.eg: I need some sort of a prop to keep the clothes line up.

prop.eng_def: a player in a rugby team who is large and strong, and who supports the scrum
prop.chi_def: （橄欖球隊）支柱前鋒（該球員體壯有力，可支持並列爭球）

prop.eg: I have to give her her props for being such a great athlete.

propaganda.eng_def: information, ideas, opinions, or images, often only giving one part of an argument, that are broadcast, published, or in some other way spread with the intention of influencing people's opinions

propel.eng_def: to push or move something somewhere, often with a lot of force
to cause someone to do an activity or be in a situation
propel.chi_def: 推動（某人）做…／將（某人）推向（某一境地）
propel.eg: The film propelled him to international stardom.

propeller.eng_def: a device that causes a ship or aircraft to move, consisting of two or more blades that spin at high speed

proper.chi_def: 適合的；適當的；恰當的；正確的
proper.eg: This is Sara's first proper job - she usually does temporary work just for the money.

proper.eng_def: showing standards of behaviour that are socially and morally acceptable
proper.eg: In those days it was considered not quite proper for young ladies to be seen talking to men in public.

proper.eng_def: belonging to the main, most important, or typical part
proper.chi_def: 嚴格意義上的；屬於最重要（或最典型）部分的
proper.eg: It's a suburb of Los Angeles really - I wouldn't call it Los Angeles proper.
I've got myself into a proper mess!

proper.eng_def: sometimes used instead of the adverb "properly" to describe how someone speaks
proper.chi_def: 合適地，得體地（有時代替副詞 properly，用於描述某人說話的方式）
proper.eg: She was an educated lady so she talked proper.

property.eng_def: an object or objects that belong to someone
property.eg: The club does not accept responsibility for loss of or damage to club members' personal property.

property.eng_def: a building or area of land, or both together
property.eg: He owns a number of properties on the south coast.

property.eng_def: the legal right to own and use something
a quality in a substance or material, especially one that means that it can be used in a particular way
property.eg: One of the properties of copper is that it conducts heat and electricity very well.

prophet.eng_def: a person who is believed to have a special power that allows them to say what a god wishes to tell people, especially about things that will happen in the future
a person who supports a new system of beliefs and principles
prophet.eg: Rousseau, that great prophet of the modern age

prophet.eng_def: Mohammed, the man who made Islam known to the world through the Koran
prophet.chi_def: 穆罕默德（伊斯蘭教創始人）

proportion.eng_def: the number or amount of a group or part of something when compared to the whole
proportion.eg: Children make up a large proportion of the world's population.

proportion.eng_def: the number, amount, or level of one thing when compared to another
proportion.eg: The proportion of women to men at my college was about five to one.

proportion.eng_def: the correct or most attractive relationship between the size of different parts of the same thing or between one thing and another
proportion.chi_def: （某物各個組成部分或一物與另一物之間的）相稱，協調，均衡，勻稱
proportion.eg: Your legs are very much in proportion to (= the right size for) the rest of your body.

proportion.eng_def: the size, shape, or level of something
used in a number of phrases to mean importance and seriousness
proportion.eg: You have to keep a sense of proportion (= the ability to understand what is important and what is not).

proposal.eng_def: a suggestion, sometimes a written one
proposal.eg: Congress has rejected the latest economic proposal put forward by the President.

propose.eng_def: to offer or suggest a possible plan or action for other people to consider
propose.eg: I propose that we wait until the budget has been announced before committing ourselves to any expenditure.

propose.eng_def: to suggest someone for a position in, or as a member of, an organization
propose.chi_def: 提名，推薦（某人）擔任某職（或參加某組織）
propose.eg: To be nominated for union president you need one person to propose you and another to second you.

propose.eng_def: to ask someone to marry you
propose.eg: I remember the night your father proposed to me.

propose.eng_def: to ask people at a formal social occasion to express their good wishes or respect for someone by holding up their glasses, usually of alcohol, at the same time and then drinking from them
propose.chi_def: 提議為…祝酒；提議為…乾杯
propose.eg: Now, if you'd all please raise your glasses, I'd like to propose a toast to the bride and groom.
How do you propose to complete the project in such a short time?

prose.eng_def: written language in its ordinary form rather than poetry
prose.eg: I've always preferred reading prose to poetry.

prosecute.eng_def: to officially accuse someone of committing a crime in a law court, or (of a lawyer) to try to prove that a person accused of committing a crime is guilty of that crime
to continue to take part in a planned group of activities, especially a war
prosecute.chi_def: 把…進行到底，繼續參與（尤指戰爭）
prosecute.eg: He seemed convinced that the US would prosecute the war to its end.

prosecution.eg: A number of the cases have resulted in successful prosecution.

prosecution.eng_def: the lawyers in a court case who represent the side that accuses someone of committing a crime
prosecution.eg: His plea of guilty to manslaughter was not accepted by the prosecution.

prosecution.eng_def: the act of taking part in a planned set of activities, especially a war
prosecution.chi_def: 把…進行到底，繼續參與（尤指戰爭）

prospect.eng_def: the possibility that something good might happen in the future
prospect.chi_def: （發生好事情的）可能，可能性，機會
prospect.eg: Is there any prospect of the weather improving?

prospect.eng_def: the possibility of being successful, especially at work
prospect.eg: She's hoping the course will improve her career prospects.

prospect.eng_def: the idea of something that will or might happen in the future
prospect.eg: The prospect of spending three whole days with her fills me with horror.

prospect.eng_def: a person who might be chosen, for example as an employee
prospect.eg: We'll be interviewing four more prospects for the jobs this afternoon.

prospect.eng_def: a good view of a large land area or of a city
prospect.eg: From the restaurant there was a marvellous prospect of/over the valley and the mountains beyond.

prospect.eng_def: to search for gold, oil, or other valuable substances on or under the surface of the earth

prospective.eng_def: people who are expected to buy something, employ someone, become parents, etc.
prospective.chi_def: 潛在的客戶／可能成為僱主的人／即將為人父母者等
prospective.eg: We've had three sets of prospective buyers looking at the house.

prosper.eng_def: (of a person or a business) to be or become successful, especially financially
prosper.chi_def: （人或企業）成功；（尤指經濟上）繁榮，昌盛
prosper.eg: Lots of microchip manufacturing companies prospered at that time.

prosperity.eng_def: the state of being successful and having a lot of money
prosperity.chi_def: 成功；（尤指經濟上的）繁榮，昌盛
prosperity.eg: A country's future prosperity depends, to an extent, upon the quality of education of its people.

prosperous.eng_def: successful, usually by earning a lot of money
prosperous.eg: In a prosperous country like this, no one should go hungry.

protect.eng_def: to keep someone or something safe from injury, damage, or loss
protect.eg: clothing that protects you against the cold

protect.eng_def: If a government protects a part of its country's trade or industry, it helps it by taxing goods from other countries.
to provide someone with insurance against injury, damages, etc.

protection.eng_def: the act of protecting or state of being protected
protection.eg: Their flimsy tent gave/offered little protection against the severe storm.

protection.eng_def: a condom (= thin rubber covering for the penis) used as a way of preventing pregnancy or the spread of disease

protective.eng_def: wanting to protect someone from criticism, hurt, danger, etc. because you like them very much
protective.chi_def: 對（某人）關切保護的；願意做…保護人的
protective.eg: It's easy to be too protective towards/of your children.

protein.eng_def: one of the many substances found in food such as meat, cheese, fish, or eggs, that is necessary for the body to grow and be strong

protest.eng_def: a strong complaint expressing disagreement, disapproval, or opposition
protest.eg: Protests have been made/registered by many people who would be affected by the proposed changes.

protest.eng_def: an occasion when people show that they disagree with something by standing somewhere, shouting, carrying signs, etc.
protest.eg: a public protest against the war

protest.eng_def: If something is done under protest, it is done unwillingly.
protest.eg: I only went to the meeting under protest.

protest.eng_def: to show that you disagree with something by standing somewhere, shouting, carrying signs, etc.
protest.eg: A big crowd of demonstrators were protesting against cuts in health spending.

protest.eng_def: to say something forcefully or complain about something
protest.eg: Lots of people protested about the new working hours.

proud.eng_def: feeling pleasure and satisfaction because you or people connected with you have done or got something good
proud.eg: You must be very proud of your son.

proud.eng_def: having or showing respect for yourself
proud.chi_def: 有自尊心的，自尊的，自重的
proud.eg: We Albanians are a proud people.

proud.eng_def: feeling that you are better and more important than other people
proud.eg: Come on, admit you're wrong and don't be so proud.

proud.eng_def: sticking out from the surrounding area
proud.eg: Sand the surface with abrasive paper until no flakes of paint stand proud of the surface.

prove.eng_def: to show a particular result after a period of time
prove.eg: The operation proved a complete success.

prove.eng_def: to show that you are good at something
prove.eg: I wish he'd stop trying to prove himself all the time.

prove.eng_def: to show that something is true
prove.eg: They suspected that she'd killed him but they could never actually prove that it was her.

proverb.eng_def: a short sentence, etc., usually known by many people, stating something commonly experienced or giving advice
proverb.eg: The appetite, says the proverb, grows with eating.

provide.eng_def: to give someone something that they need
provide.eg: This booklet provides useful information about local services.

provide.eng_def: (of a law or decision) to say that something must happen if particular conditions exist
provide.eg: Section 17 provides that all decisions must be circulated in writing.

province.eng_def: an area that is governed as part of a country or an empire
the parts of a country that are not the capital city
province.chi_def: 外省，外地（指首都以外的地區）

province.eng_def: a subject or activity of special interest, knowledge, or responsibility
province.chi_def: （某人的興趣或知識的）範圍，領域；職責範圍
province.eg: Renaissance art is not really his province - he specializes in the modern period.

provincial.eng_def: a person who comes from somewhere in a country outside its capital city
provincial.chi_def: 外省人；外地人；首都以外的人

provincial.eng_def: relating to an area that is governed as part of a country or an empire
in or from the parts of the country that are not the capital city
provincial.eg: The majority of young professionals in the capital have moved there from provincial towns.

provincial.eng_def: having opinions and ideas that are old-fashioned and simple

provoke.eng_def: to cause a reaction, especially a negative one
provoke.chi_def: 激起，引起（尤指負面反應）
provoke.eg: The prospect of increased prices has already provoked an outcry.

provoke.eng_def: to make or try to make a person or an animal angry
provoke.eg: It was a vicious-looking dog and I didn't want to provoke it.

prowl.eng_def: to move around quietly in a place trying not to be seen or heard, such as an animal does when hunting
prowl.chi_def: （打獵等時）悄悄來回游走（於），潛行，逡巡
prowl.eg: There have been reports of a masked man prowling in the neighbourhood.

prowl.eng_def: to be moving around quietly in a place trying not to be seen or heard
prowl.eg: There was a fox on the prowl earlier.

prune.eng_def: to cut off branches from a tree, bush, or plant, especially so that it will grow better in the future
prune.eg: She spent the afternoon pruning roses.

prune.eng_def: to reduce something by removing things that are not necessary
prune.eg: Arco has reacted to the loss in revenue by pruning (back) its expansion plans.

psychological.eng_def: relating to the human mind and feelings
(of an illness or other physical problem) caused by worry or sadness
psychological.chi_def: 由焦慮（或悲傷）引起的；存在於心理上的
psychological.eg: I suspect his headaches are purely psychological.

psychological.eng_def: A psychological film or book is one in which there is a lot of attention given to the way people influence each other's behaviour.
psychological.chi_def: （電影或書籍）心理的，心理分析的

psychologist.eng_def: someone who studies the human mind and human emotions and behaviour, and how different situations have an effect on people

psychology.eng_def: the scientific study of the way the human mind works and how it influences behaviour, or the influence of a particular person's character on their behaviour

pub.eng_def: a place, especially in Great Britain or Ireland, where alcoholic drinks can be bought and drunk and where food is often available
pub.eg: Do you want to go to (informal go down) the pub after work?

public.eng_def: relating to or involving people in general, rather than being limited to a particular group of people
public.eg: Public opinion (= the opinions of most people) has turned against him.

public.eng_def: provided by the government from taxes to be available to everyone
A public place is one where a lot of people are.
public.eg: It's too public here - let's go back to my room to talk.
The public has a right to know about this.
