public.eng_def: the group of people who are involved with you or your organization, especially in a business relationship
public.eg: Newspapers publish these outrageous stories because they know what their public wants.

public.eng_def: in a place where people can see you
public.eg: I'd never behave like that in public.

publication.eng_def: the act of making information or stories available to people in a printed or electronic form
publication.eg: The brochure will be ready for publication in September.

publication.eng_def: a book, magazine, newspaper, or document in which information or stories are published
publication.eg: Our latest publication is a magazine for health enthusiasts.

publicity.eng_def: the activity of making certain that someone or something attracts a lot of interest or attention from many people, or the attention received as a result of this activity
publicity.chi_def: 宣傳活動；宣傳，推廣；關注
publicity.eg: He attracted a lot of adverse/bad publicity with his speech about unmarried mothers.

publicize.eng_def: to make information about something generally available
publicize.eg: Attitudes seem to be changing as a result of recent highly publicized cases of sexual harassment.

publish.eng_def: to make information available to people, especially in a book, magazine, or newspaper, or to produce and sell a book, magazine, or newspaper
publish.eg: She's just had an article published in their weekend supplement.

publisher.eng_def: an organization that publishes text or music
publisher.chi_def: 出版商，出版社；發行機構

publisher.eng_def: an employee of a publishing company who has responsibility for deciding what is published

pudding.eng_def: a sweet and usually hot dish made with pastry, flour, bread, or rice, and often fruit
pudding.chi_def: 布丁（通常由油酥麵團、麵粉、麵包或米加上水果製成的熱甜食）

pudding.eng_def: a sweet, soft food made from milk, sugar, eggs, and flavouring, eaten cold
pudding.chi_def: 布丁（由牛奶、糖、雞蛋和調味料製成的鬆軟的冷甜食）

pudding.eng_def: the final part of a meal, when a sweet dish is eaten
a hot dish made with pastry or flour that contains or is eaten with meat

puff.eng_def: to breathe fast and with difficulty, usually because you have been exercising
puff.eg: He came puffing up the stairs.

puff.eng_def: to breathe fast and with difficulty, usually because you have been exercising

puff.eg: She was puffing on a cigarette at the time.

puff.eng_def: to blow out in clouds, or make steam or smoke do this
puff.eg: The engine puffed a huge cloud of steam, then rolled down the tracks.

puff.eng_def: a small amount of smoke, air, or something that can rise into the air in a small cloud
puff.chi_def: 一小口（煙霧），一小股（空氣）
puff.eg: Sean blew a puff of smoke at his reflection in the mirror.

puff.eng_def: a piece of food made of puff pastry filled with something sweet or with food such as cheese
a piece of writing or speech that praises something too much
to be breathing with difficulty because you have been doing physical exercise

puff.eg: She took a puff on her cigarette and thought for a moment.

pull.eng_def: to move something towards yourself, sometimes with great physical effort
pull.eg: Could you help me move this bookcase over there? You pull and I'll push.

pull.eng_def: to take something out of or away from a place, especially using physical effort
to remove or stop something that was going to be published or broadcast, especially because it is found to be offensive or not accurate
pull.chi_def: （尤指因為有冒犯性或不準確）撤下即將出版（或傳播）的材料
pull.eg: When officials realized the cultural gaffe, the company pulled the ad and apologized.

pull.eng_def: to move in the stated direction
pull.eg: During the last lap of the race one of the runners began to pull ahead.

pull.eng_def: to take hold of something and use effort to move your body forwards or up
pull.chi_def: 抓住…並努力向上（或向前）移動身體
pull.eg: She pulled herself up the stairs, holding onto the rail.

pull.eng_def: to attract a person or people
pull.eg: The show has certainly pulled (in) the crowds.

pull.eng_def: to succeed in starting a sexual relationship with someone
pull.eg: He certainly knows how to pull women.

pull.eng_def: to injure a muscle by stretching it too much
pull.eg: I pulled a muscle in my back lifting some drawers.
The gang that pulled the bank robbery were all arrested.

pull.eng_def: to get information from the internet, after asking or searching for it
pull.chi_def: 通過詢問和搜索在網際網路上找到資訊
pull.eg: Companies should encourage customers to pull information from their website, thus putting the customer in control.

pull.eng_def: the act of pulling something towards yourself
pull.eg: Give the rope a hard pull.

pull.eng_def: something that you pull to make something work or to open something

pull.eg: "How can we persuade people to come to the meeting?" "A glass of wine is quite a good pull."

pull.eng_def: the physical or emotional power to attract something
pull.eg: The greater the mass of an object, the greater its gravitational pull.
He's still got quite a bit of pull in the club - he could probably get you elected.

pulse.eng_def: the regular beating of the heart, especially when it is felt at the wrist or side of the neck
to hold someone's wrist and count how many times the heart beats in one minute
a short period of energy that is repeated regularly, such as a short, loud sound or a short flash of light
pulse.eg: The data, normally transmitted electronically, can be changed into pulses of light.

pulse.eng_def: seeds such as beans or peas that are cooked and eaten
pulse.chi_def: 豆類植物的種子；莢果；豆子
pulse.eg: Pulses include peas, lentils, and chickpeas.

pulse.eng_def: to move or beat with a strong, regular rhythm
pulse.chi_def: （以規律且強有力的節拍）跳動，搏動，振動
pulse.eg: I could feel the blood pulsing through my veins.

pump.eng_def: a piece of equipment that is used to cause liquid, air, or gas to move from one place to another
pump.chi_def: 唧筒，幫浦，抽水機；油泵；打氣筒

pump.eng_def: a type of flat shoe, like a ballet dancer's shoe, worn by women
a type of plain shoe with a raised heel and no way of fastening it to the foot, worn by women
a flat shoe made of heavy cloth, worn by children for doing sports
to force liquid or gas to move somewhere
pump.eg: Our latest machine can pump a hundred gallons a minute.

pump.eng_def: to keep asking someone for information, especially in a way that is not direct
pump.eg: She was pumping me for details of the new project.

pumpkin.eng_def: a large, round vegetable with hard, yellow or orange flesh

punch.eng_def: a forceful hit with a fist (= closed hand)
punch.eg: She gave him a punch on the nose.

punch.eng_def: the power to be interesting and have a strong effect on people
punch.eg: I felt the performance/speech/presentation lacked punch.

punch.eng_def: a cold or hot drink made by mixing fruit juices, pieces of fruit, and often wine or other alcoholic drinks
punch.chi_def: 潘趣酒（一種果汁、水果與酒調成的冷飲或熱飲）

punch.eng_def: a piece of equipment that cuts holes in a material by pushing a piece of metal through it
to hit someone or something with your fist (= closed hand)
punch.eg: He punched him in the stomach.

punch.eng_def: to hit with your fingers the buttons on a phone or the keys on a keyboard
to make a hole in something with a special piece of equipment
punch.eg: I was just punching holes in some sheets of paper.

punctual.eng_def: arriving, doing something, or happening at the expected, correct time; not late
punctual.eg: a punctual start to the meeting

punish.eng_def: to cause someone who has done something wrong or committed a crime to suffer, by hurting them, forcing them to pay money, sending them to prison, etc.
punish.eg: Those responsible for these crimes must be brought to court and punished.

punish.eng_def: to punish anyone who commits a particular crime
punish.eg: Drunken driving can be punished with a prison sentence.

punish.eng_def: to use or treat something badly, violently, or without care
punish.eg: He really punishes that horse of his.

punishment.eg: Many people think that the death penalty is too severe a punishment for any crime.
These trucks are designed to take a lot of punishment.

pupil.eng_def: a person, especially a child at school, who is being taught
someone who is being taught a skill, especially painting or music, by an expert
pupil.eg: The painting is believed to be by a pupil of Titian.

pupil.eng_def: the circular black area in the centre of an eye, through which light enters
pupil.eg: Pupils contract in bright light, and dilate in darkness.

puppet.eng_def: a toy in the shape of a person or animal that you can move with strings or by putting your hand inside
puppet.eg: We took the children to a puppet show/theatre.

puppet.eng_def: a person or group whose actions are controlled by someone else
puppet.eg: Western powers have been accused of trying to establish a puppet government/regime in the divided country.

puppy.eg: Our dog has just had four puppies.

purchase.eg: Tickets must be purchased two weeks in advance.
How do you wish to pay for your purchases?
New restrictions have been placed on the purchase of guns.

purchase.eng_def: a firm hold that allows someone or something to be pulled or lifted without sliding or falling
purchase.eg: Dancers use a special powder on their shoes to help them get a better purchase on the floor.

pure.eng_def: A pure colour is not mixed with any other colour.
A pure sound is clear and perfect.
pure.eg: the pure vocal tones of the choirboy

pure.eng_def: clean and free from harmful substances
pure.chi_def: 潔淨的，純淨的，無有害物質的
pure.eg: The mountain air was wonderfully pure.
It was pure coincidence/chance that we met.

pure.eng_def: used to refer to an area of study that is studied only for the purpose of developing theories about it, not for the purpose of using those theories in a practical way
used after a noun to mean "and nothing else"
pure.chi_def: （用於名詞後）完全是，不折不扣，不過是
pure.eg: He is motivated by greed, pure and simple.

pure.eng_def: behaving in a way that is morally good, especially in things related to sex
pure.chi_def: 純潔的；無邪的；清白的；貞潔的
pure.eg: I'm trying to think only pure thoughts.

purify.eng_def: to remove bad substances from something to make it pure
purify.eg: Plants help to purify the air.

purify.eng_def: to remove immoral thoughts or acts from something
purify.eg: One of the main teachings of Buddhism is that you should try to purify your mind.

purity.eng_def: the state of not being mixed with anything else
purity.eg: the atrocities carried out in the name of ethnic/racial purity

purity.eng_def: the clear and perfect quality of a sound
the fact of being clean or free from harmful substances
purity.chi_def: 潔淨，純淨；不含有害物質

purity.eng_def: the quality of being morally good or the state of not having sex
purity.eg: the purity and innocence of children

purple.eng_def: dark red in the face because of anger
used to describe a piece of writing that is complicated or sounds false because the writer has tried too hard to make the style interesting
purple.chi_def: （作品）詞藻華麗的，華而不實的
purple.eg: Despite occasional patches of purple prose, the book is mostly clear and incisive.

purpose.eng_def: why you do something or why something exists
purpose.eg: The purpose of the research is to try to find out more about the causes of the disease.

purpose.eng_def: If you do something on purpose, you do it intentionally, not by accident.
purpose.eg: I didn't do it on purpose - it was an accident.

purpose.eng_def: determination or a feeling of having a reason for what you do
purpose.eg: I've always admired her for her strength of purpose.
We haven't yet managed to find new premises that are suitable for our purposes.
These small village shops serve a very useful purpose.

purse.eng_def: a small container for money, usually used by a woman
the total amount of money that an organization or government has available for spending
purse.chi_def: （機構或政府的）備用金，可用的資金，財力
purse.eg: Having a lot of people out of work places a large drain on the public purse.

purse.eng_def: an amount of money that is offered as a prize in a sports competition
purse.eg: The players in the golf tournament are competing for a purse of £525,000.

purse.eng_def: to bring your lips tightly together so that they form a rounded shape, usually as an expression of disapproval
purse.eg: "I don't approve of that kind of language," she said, pursing her lips.

pursue.eng_def: to follow someone or something, usually to try to catch him, her, or it
pursue.eg: The car was pursued by helicopters.

pursue.eng_def: to try very hard to persuade someone to accept a job
pursue.eg: The company has been pursuing Holton for some time, but so far he has rejected all their offers.

pursue.eng_def: to try to discover information about a subject
pursue.eg: We will not be pursuing this matter any further.

pursue.eng_def: to try very hard to persuade someone to have a relationship with you
pursue.eg: He's been pursuing her for months and yet she's so clearly not interested.

pursue.eng_def: If you pursue a plan, activity, or situation, you try to do it or achieve it, usually over a long period of time.
pursue.eg: He decided to pursue a career in television.

pursuit.eng_def: an activity that you spend time doing, usually when you are not working
pursuit.eg: I enjoy outdoor pursuits, like hiking and riding.

pursuit.eng_def: the act of following someone or something to try to catch him, her, or it
pursuit.eg: Three people have been killed in high-speed pursuits by the police recently.

pursuit.eng_def: the act of trying to achieve a plan, activity, or situation, usually over a long period of time

push.eng_def: to use physical pressure or force, especially with your hands, in order to move something into a different position, usually one that is further away from you
push.eg: Can you help me move this table? You push and I'll pull.

push.eng_def: to move forcefully, especially in order to cause someone or something that is in your way to move, so that you can go through or past them
When an army pushes in a particular direction, it moves forward in that direction.
push.eg: The invading troops have pushed further into the north of the country.

push.eng_def: to forcefully persuade or direct someone to do or achieve something
push.eg: Her parents pushed her into marrying him.

push.eng_def: to advertise something repeatedly in order to increase its sales
push.eg: They're really pushing their new car.
He was arrested for pushing drugs to schoolchildren.

push.eng_def: to send information over the internet without receiving a request for it first
the act of moving someone or something by pressing them with your hands or body
push.eg: Get on the swing and I'll give you a push.

push.eng_def: a strong movement towards a place
push.eg: The army is continuing its push (= advance) towards the capital.

push.eng_def: a determined attempt to get an advantage over other companies in business
push.chi_def: （生意上為贏得優勢而進行的）努力，攻勢
push.eg: The company plans to make a big push into the European market next spring.

push.eng_def: encouragement to make someone do something
push.eg: My mother had always wanted to learn how to paint - she just needed a gentle push.
This film is unlikely to attract large audiences unless it gets/it is given a big push in the media.

put.eng_def: to move something or someone into the stated place, position, or direction
put.eg: Where have you put the keys?
She puts her name in all her books.
She wanted to tell him that she didn't want to see him any more, but she didn't know how to put it.

put.eng_def: to say what you think the price or value of something is
put.eg: The agent has put a price of £720,000 on our house.

put.eng_def: used to describe the way you are expressing an event or opinion
put.chi_def: 直言不諱／簡單地說／簡而言之／委婉地說
put.eg: To put it bluntly, you're going to have to improve.

put.eng_def: to cause someone or something to be in the stated condition or situation
put.chi_def: 使處於某種狀態（或境地、局面）
put.eg: Are you prepared to put your children at risk?

put.eng_def: to bring into operation; to cause to be used
put.eg: When the drugs failed to cure her, she put her faith/trust in herbal medicine.

put.eng_def: to judge something or someone in comparison with other similar things or people
put.eg: I'd put him among the top six tennis players of all time.

put.eng_def: to travel in a boat or ship across the sea
put.eg: Our mast broke, so we had to put about (= turn round) and return to port.

puzzle.eng_def: a situation that is difficult to understand
puzzle.chi_def: 令人費解的情況；難題；謎
puzzle.eg: Scientists have been trying to solve this puzzle for years.

puzzle.eng_def: a game or toy in which you have to fit separate pieces together, or a problem or question that you have to answer by using your skill or knowledge
puzzle.chi_def: 測驗智力的遊戲（或玩具）

puzzle.eng_def: to cause someone to feel confused and slightly worried because they cannot understand something, or to think hard about something in order to understand it
puzzle.chi_def: （使）感到迷惑；（使）感到為難，（使）感到困窘
puzzle.eg: The findings of the survey puzzle me - they're not at all what I would have expected.

pyramid.eng_def: a solid object with a square base and four triangular sides that form a point at the top
a pile of things that has the shape of a pyramid
pyramid.chi_def: 擺成金字塔形的一堆東西
pyramid.eg: The acrobats formed a pyramid by standing on each other's shoulders.

pyramid.eng_def: a group of ancient pyramid-shaped structures built in Egypt as tombs (= places to bury people) for the Pharaohs (= kings of Ancient Egypt)
pyramid.chi_def: （古埃及為埋葬法老修建的）金字塔

quack.eng_def: to make the usual sound of a duck
quack.eg: The ducks started quacking loudly when we threw them some bread.

quack.eng_def: a person who dishonestly pretends to have medical skills or knowledge
quack.chi_def: 冒牌醫生，江湖醫生，庸醫，江湖郎中

quack.eg: Have you seen a quack about that cough?

quack.eng_def: the sound that a duck makes
quack.chi_def: （鴨子）呱呱的叫聲，嘎嘎的叫聲

quake.eng_def: to shake because you are very frightened or find something very funny, or to feel or show great fear
quake.eg: Every time I get on a plane, I quake with fear.

qualification.eng_def: an official record showing that you have finished a training course or have the necessary skills, etc.
qualification.eg: You'll never get a good job if you don't have any qualifications.

qualification.eng_def: an ability, characteristic, or experience that makes you suitable for a particular job or activity
qualification.eg: Some nursing experience is a necessary qualification for this job.

qualification.eng_def: success in getting into a competition
qualification.eg: The win earned them qualification for the World Cup finals.

qualification.eng_def: an extra piece of information that limits the effect of something that you say or write
qualification.eg: The doctor said I can leave hospital today, but with the qualification that I have to come back every day to get the dressing changed.

qualify.eng_def: to successfully finish a training course so that you are able to do a job; to have or achieve the necessary skills, etc.
qualify.eg: She hopes to qualify (as a lawyer) at the end of the year.

qualify.eng_def: to have the legal right to have or do something because of the situation you are in, or to cause someone to have such a right
qualify.eg: She doesn't qualify for maternity leave because she hasn't been in her job long enough.

qualify.eng_def: to succeed in getting into a competition
qualify.eg: Nigeria was the first team to qualify for the World Cup.

qualify.eng_def: to limit the strength or meaning of a statement
qualify.eg: I'd like to qualify my criticisms of the school's failings, by adding that it's a very happy place.

qualify.eng_def: In grammar, a word or phrase that qualifies another word or phrase limits its meaning and makes it less general
qualify.eg: In the sentence "He walked quickly along the road", "quickly" and "along the road" qualify "walked".

quality.eng_def: how good or bad something is
quality.eg: a shop advertising top quality electrical goods
He's not interested in quality. All he cares about is making money.

quality.eng_def: the level of enjoyment, comfort, and health in someone's life
quality.eg: My quality of life has improved tremendously since I moved to the country.

quality.eng_def: a characteristic or feature of someone or something

quantity.eng_def: the amount or number of something, especially that can be measured
quantity.chi_def: （尤指可測量或確定的）量，數量，分量
quantity.eg: Police found a large/small quantity of drugs in his possession.

quarrel.eng_def: an angry disagreement between two or more people or groups
quarrel.eg: They had a bitter quarrel about/over some money three years ago and they haven't spoken to each other since.

quarrel.eng_def: to have an angry disagreement with someone

quarrelsome.eng_def: A quarrelsome person repeatedly argues with other people.

quart.eng_def: a unit of measurement for liquids, equal to approximately 1.14 litres in the UK, or 0.95 litres in the US
quart.chi_def: 誇脫（液體單位，英制中約為1.14升，美制中約為0.95升）
quart.eg: A quart is so called because it is a quarter of a gallon.

quarter.eng_def: one of four equal or almost equal parts of something; ¼
quarter.eg: He cut the orange into quarters.
I waited a quarter of an hour and then went home.

quarter.chi_def: 差十五分鐘兩點/三點/四點等
quarter.eg: It was a quarter to six when I left.

quarter.chi_def: 兩點/三點/四點等過十五分鐘
quarter.eg: I'll meet you at a quarter past five.

quarter.eng_def: one of four periods of time into which a year is divided for financial calculations, such as for profits or taxes
quarter.eg: There was a fall in unemployment in the second quarter of the year.

quarter.eng_def: one of four periods in a game of American football and other ball sports
quarter.chi_def: （橄欖球賽或其他球賽的）一節，一局

quarter.eng_def: in the US and Canada, a coin worth 25 cents
an area of a town where a particular group of people live or work or where a particular activity happens
quarter.eg: This is the bustling commercial quarter of the city.

quarter.eng_def: one or more people who provide help, information, or a particular reaction to something but who are not usually named
quarter.chi_def: （提供幫助、訊息或作出反應的）個人，群體
quarter.eg: Help came from an unexpected quarter.

quarter.eng_def: a room or house that has been provided, especially for servants or soldiers and their families, to live in
quarter.chi_def: （尤指僕人或者部隊）的住處；營地
quarter.eg: The army's married quarters are just outside the town.

quarter.eng_def: a house or other place to live that has been provided by a company for an employee
quarter.chi_def: 由公司為雇員提供的房屋（或其他居住場所）

quarter.eng_def: the fact of being kind towards or forgiving an enemy or opponent
quarter.chi_def: （對敗者的）寬恕，仁慈，（尤指）饒命
quarter.eg: We can expect no quarter from our enemies.

quarter.eng_def: to cut something into four parts
to send someone, especially soldiers, to live in a place
quarter.eg: The soldiers were quartered with (= they lived with) local people during the war.

queen.eng_def: a woman who rules a country because she has been born into a royal family, or a woman who is married to a king
queen.eg: How long did Queen Victoria reign?

queen.eng_def: any woman who is considered to be the best at what she does
queen.eg: She's the reigning queen of crime writers.

queen.eng_def: the most powerful piece on the board in the game of chess
in a group of insects, a single large female that produces eggs
in a set of playing cards, a card with a picture of a queen on it. It is usually worth less than a king.
a gay man, especially an older man, whose way of behaving is noticeable and artificial
queen.chi_def: （舉止明顯像女人的）同性戀男子，（尤指）老同性戀男子
queen.eg: James is such an old queen.

queer.eg: What a queer thing to say!

queer.eng_def: a gay person, especially a man
queer.chi_def: 同性戀者；（尤指）男同性戀者

queer.eng_def: to spoil a chance or an opportunity for someone, often on purpose
queer.eg: If she asks Dan for a pay rise before I do, it will probably queer my pitch.

quench.eng_def: to drink liquid so that you stop being thirsty
quench.eg: When it's hot, it's best to quench your thirst with water.

quench.eng_def: to use water to put out a fire
quench.eg: The flames were quenched by heavy rain.

quench.eng_def: to satisfy a need or wish
quench.eg: Her thirst for knowledge will never be quenched.

query.eng_def: a question, often expressing doubt about something or looking for an answer from an authority
query.eg: If you have any queries about your treatment, the doctor will answer them.

query.eng_def: to ask questions, especially in order to check if something is true or correct
query.eg: A few students have queried their marks.

quest.eng_def: a long search for something that is difficult to find, or an attempt to achieve something difficult
quest.eg: Nothing will stop them in their quest for truth.

question.eng_def: a sentence or phrase used to find out information
question.eg: The police asked me questions all day.

question.eng_def: in an exam, a problem that tests a person's knowledge or ability
question.eg: Answer/Do as many questions as you can.

question.eng_def: any matter that needs to be dealt with or considered
question.eg: This raises the question of teacher pay.
There's no question about (= it is certain) whose fault it is.

question.eng_def: the person or thing that is being discussed
question.eg: I stayed at home on the night in question.

question.eng_def: to ask a person about something, especially officially
question.eg: Several men were questioned by police yesterday about the burglary.

question.eng_def: to express doubts about the value or truth of something
question.eg: I questioned the wisdom of taking so many pills.

questionnaire.eng_def: a list of questions that several people are asked so that information can be collected about something
questionnaire.eg: Visitors to the country have been asked to fill in a detailed questionnaire.

quick.eng_def: happening or done with great speed, or lasting only a short time

quick.eg: I tried to catch him but he was too quick for me.

quick.eng_def: to do something fast, sometimes too fast
quick.eg: She was quick to point out that it wasn't her fault.

quick.eng_def: used to describe someone who is clever and understands or notices things quickly
quick.eg: She was quick at understanding what we wanted her to do.

quick.eng_def: someone who is able to learn things quickly
quick.eg: He's a quick study and easily grasps all the details of a discussion.

quick.eng_def: used for telling someone to do something quickly
quick.chi_def: 快點！（用於督促某人做某事）
quick.eg: Quick! Close the door before the cat comes in!
We bought it quick, before someone else could.

quick.eng_def: the area of flesh under your nails
quick.eg: He's bitten his nails to the quick.

quiet.eg: She spoke in a quiet voice so as not to wake him.

quiet.eng_def: having little activity or excitement and few people
A quiet person is one who does not talk much
quiet.eg: He was a quiet, almost taciturn, young man.

quiet.eng_def: to try to stop other people from finding out about a fact
quiet.eg: She managed to keep the operation quiet for a while.

quiet.eng_def: to (cause someone to) become calmer or less noisy
quiet.eg: The barking dogs quieted when they recognized me.

quilt.eng_def: a decorative cover for a bed

quilt.chi_def: 羽絨被；蓬鬆棉被（同 duvet）

quit.eng_def: to stop doing something or leave a job or a place
quit.eg: Would you quit your job if you inherited lots of money?

quite.eg: The two situations are quite different.

quite.eng_def: used to express that you are not certain about something
quite.eg: I don't quite know what to say.

quite.eng_def: used to show agreement with someone's opinion
quite.eg: "You'd think he could spare some money - he's not exactly poor." "Quite."

quite.eng_def: used to emphasize the degree or amount of something, or to say that someone or something is impressive, interesting, or unusual
quite.chi_def: （用來強調…的程度或數量）很，挺
quite.eg: They have been working on this for quite some time.

quite.chi_def: （表示強調）絕對是最好/最糟糕的等
quite.eg: It was quite the worst dinner I have ever had.

quite.eng_def: a little or a lot but not completely
quite.eg: I'm quite tired but I can certainly walk a little further.

quiver.eng_def: to shake slightly, often because of strong emotion
quiver.eg: Lennie's bottom lip quivered and tears started in his eyes.

quiver.eng_def: a long, thin container for carrying arrows
a slight shake, often because of strong emotion
quiver.eg: The opening bars of the music sent a quiver of excitement through the crowd.

quiz.eng_def: a game or competition in which you answer questions

quiz.eg: There was a pop (= surprise) quiz in history at school today.

quiz.eng_def: to ask someone questions about something
quiz.eg: She spent an hour being quizzed by journalists.

quotation.eng_def: a phrase or short piece of writing taken from a longer work of literature, poetry, etc. or what someone else has said
quotation.eg: At the beginning of the book there's a quotation from Abraham Lincoln.

quotation.eng_def: the price that a person or company says they will charge to do a piece of work
quotation.eg: We decided to go with the lowest quotation.

quotation.eng_def: the fact that a company's shares are being traded on a particular stock market
quotation.eg: Changes in the listing rules have reduced the advantage of obtaining a quotation on this stock market.

quote.eng_def: to repeat the words that someone else has said or written
quote.eg: He's always quoting from the Bible.

quote.eng_def: If you quote a fact or example, you refer to it in order to add emphasis to what you are saying.
quote.eg: Quote me one organization that doesn't have some bad managers.

quote.eng_def: to give a price, especially one that will be charged for doing a piece of work
quote.eg: The architect has quoted £90,000 to build a patio.

quote.eng_def: the price that a person or company says they will charge to do a piece of work
quote.eg: I asked several companies to give me a quote for the building work.

quote.eng_def: the symbols “ ” or ‘ ’ that are put around a word or phrase to show that someone else has written or said it
quote.eg: Put the title of the article in quotes.

rabbit.eng_def: a small animal with long ears and large front teeth that moves by jumping on its long back legs, or the meat of this animal eaten as food

race.eng_def: a competition in which all the competitors try to be the fastest and to finish first
race.eg: Do you know who won/lost the race?

race.eng_def: an attempt to be the first to do or to get something
race.eg: Kieran and Andrew are in a race for promotion.

race.eng_def: a series of horse races in a particular place on one day
race.eg: He often has a day at the races.

race.eng_def: a group, especially of people, with particular similar physical characteristics, who are considered as belonging to the same type, or the fact of belonging to such a group
race.eg: People of many different races were living side by side.

race.eng_def: a group of people who share the same language, history, characteristics, etc.
race.eg: The British are an island race.

race.eng_def: to (cause to) compete in a race
race.eg: He has been racing for over ten years.

race.chi_def: （使）快速移動（或行進；（使）疾走（或疾馳；（使）快速奔跑

racial.eng_def: happening between people of different races
racial.chi_def: 種族的；種族間的；種族關係的
人種的，種族的；作為人種（或種族、民族）特點的
racial.eg: They are members of a racial minority.

racism.eng_def: the belief that people's qualities are influenced by their race and that the members of other races are not as good as the members of your own, or the resulting unfair treatment of members of other races
racism.chi_def: 種族主義；種族歧視，種族迫害
racism.eg: The authorities are taking steps to combat/fight/tackle racism in schools.

rack.eng_def: a frame or shelf, often formed of bars, that is used to hold things
a wooden or plastic triangle used to arrange the balls at the start of a game of billiards, pool, snooker, etc.
rack.chi_def: （用於桌球或撞球比賽開球時放置球的）三角框

rack.eng_def: in the past, a device to which people were tied that stretched their bodies by pulling their arms in one direction and their legs in the other direction, usually used as a way of forcing them to give information
rack.chi_def: （舊時為逼供而使用的）拉肢刑具

rack.eng_def: a large piece of meat cut from the neck of a sheep or pig
rack.eg: The butcher prepared a rack of pork.

rack.eng_def: a bar with tooth-like parts along one edge that fits into a pinion (= a wheel with tooth-like parts) allowing change between circular and straight-line movement

rack.chi_def: 糟糕透頂（的狀態）；破損，損壞
rack.eg: The whole farm was going to rack and ruin.

rack.eng_def: to cause physical or mental pain, or trouble, to someone or something
rack.chi_def: 使肉體（或精神上）受巨大痛苦；折磨
rack.eg: Even at the end, when cancer racked his body, he was calm and cheerful.

radar.eng_def: a system that uses radio waves to find the position of objects that cannot be seen
radar.eg: Other vessels in the area show up on the ship's radar (screen).

radiant.eng_def: obviously very happy, or very beautiful
radiant.chi_def: 喜氣洋洋的；容光煥發的；光彩照人的
radiant.eg: He gave a radiant smile when he heard her news.

radiant.chi_def: （熱或光）輻射的，放射的，發散的

radiate.eng_def: to produce heat and/or light, or (of heat or light) to be produced
radiate.eg: The planet Jupiter radiates twice as much heat from inside as it receives from the Sun.

radiate.eng_def: to show an emotion or quality, or (of an emotion or quality) to be shown or felt
radiate.eg: He was radiating joy and happiness.

radiate.eng_def: to spread out in all directions from a central point
radiate.chi_def: 從中心散開；呈輻射狀發出
radiate.eg: Flows of lava radiated out from the volcano's crater.

radiation.eng_def: a form of energy that comes from a nuclear reaction and that can be very dangerous to health
radiation.eg: Many servicemen suffered radiation sickness after the early atomic tests.

radiation.eng_def: energy from heat or light that you cannot see

radiator.eng_def: a device, usually a container filled with water, that sends out heat, often as part of a heating or cooling system
radiator.chi_def: （通常指依靠水迴圈的）暖氣裝置；散熱器；冷卻器
radiator.eg: When we installed the central heating, we put a radiator in every room.

radical.eng_def: believing or expressing the belief that there should be great or extreme social or political change
radical.eg: He was known as a radical reformer/thinker/politician.

radical.eng_def: relating to the most important parts of something or someone; complete or extreme
radical.eg: We need to make some radical changes to our operating procedures.

radical.eng_def: aimed at removing all diseased tissue
radical.chi_def: （指移除所有患病組織）根本的
radical.eg: Cervical cancer may be cured with radical surgery when it is confined to the pelvis or regional lymph nodes.

radical.eng_def: a person who supports great social and political change
radical.eg: She was a radical all her life.

radio.eng_def: a piece of electronic equipment used for listening to radio broadcasts
the programmes that you hear when you listen to the radio
radio.eg: I heard a good programme on the radio last night.

radio.eng_def: the system or work of broadcasting sound programmes for the public to listen to
a piece of electronic equipment that can send and receive spoken messages or signals, or the messages or signals that are sent or received
radio.chi_def: 無線電收發設備；無線電通訊
radio.eg: We sent a message over the radio/by radio.

radio.eng_def: to send a message to someone by radio
radio.chi_def: 用無線電發送（資訊）；向…發送無線電報；用無線電通訊
radio.eg: We'll have to radio for more supplies.

radish.eng_def: a small vegetable, usually red or white and round or shaped like a finger, that grows underground and is usually eaten uncooked in salads
radish.chi_def: （通常指紅色或白色，圓形或手指形的）小蘿蔔

radius.eng_def: (the length of) a straight line joining the centre of a circle to its edge or the centre of a sphere to its surface
radius.eg: The radius of this wheel is 30 cm..

radius.eng_def: a distance from a central point
radius.chi_def: 半徑距離；半徑範圍；周圍
radius.eg: The station, shopping centre and school lie within a one-mile radius of the house.

radius.eng_def: the thicker of the two bones in the lower arm

raft.eng_def: a flat floating structure for travelling across water, often made of pieces of wood tied roughly together and moved along with a paddle (= pole with a flat end)
raft.eg: We lashed together anything that would float to make a raft.

raft.eng_def: a fixed, flat floating structure that swimmers can use to land on or dive from
a small rubber or plastic boat that can be filled with air
a large number or range; a lot
to travel or transport something on a raft
raft.chi_def: 乘坐筏子（渡河）；用筏子運送
raft.eg: They rafted their supplies down the river.

rag.eng_def: a torn piece of old cloth
rag.eg: I keep these rags for cleaning the car.

rag.eng_def: clothes that are old and torn
rag.eg: an old man dressed in rags.

rag.eng_def: a newspaper or magazine that is considered to be of bad quality
rag.chi_def: 質量低劣的報紙（或雜誌）；低俗小報；粗製濫造的雜誌
rag.eg: He had his picture taken for some local rag.

rag.eng_def: in Britain, a series of entertaining events and activities organized by college students once a year to collect money for charity
rag.chi_def: （英國大學生每年組織的）慈善募捐活動

rag.eng_def: to say things that are funny but a little unkind
rag.eg: They ragged him about his girlfriend.

rage.eng_def: (a period of) extreme or violent anger
rage.chi_def: （一陣）盛怒；（一陣）狂怒；（一陣）暴怒
rage.eg: Her sudden towering rages were terrifying.

rage.eng_def: an exciting or entertaining event involving a lot of activity
to speak very angrily to someone
rage.eg: He raged at (= spoke angrily to) us for forgetting to order a replacement.

rage.eng_def: to happen in a strong or violent way
rage.chi_def: 激烈進行；猛烈發作；肆虐

rage.eng_def: used to refer to situations where people become extremely angry or violent

ragged.eng_def: (of clothes) torn and not in good condition
ragged.chi_def: （衣服）破舊的，破爛的，不整齊的
ragged.eg: The children were wearing dirty, ragged clothes.

ragged.eng_def: (of a person) untidy, dirty, and wearing old, torn clothes
ragged.chi_def: （人）邋遢的，不整潔的，衣衫襤褸的
ragged.eg: Two ragged children stood outside the station, begging for money.

ragged.eng_def: (especially of an edge) rough and not smooth
ragged.chi_def: （尤指邊緣）參差不齊的；粗糙的，不規則的
ragged.eg: The leaves of this plant have ragged edges.

ragged.eng_def: not performing well, because of not being organized
ragged.chi_def: （表演）不協調的，沒有章法的，拙劣的
ragged.eg: The team was rather ragged in the first half of the game.

raid.eng_def: a short sudden attack, usually by a small group of people
raid.chi_def: （通常由一小隊人發起的）突襲，襲擊
raid.eg: The commandos made/staged/carried out a daring raid (on the enemy).

raid.eng_def: the act of entering a place by force in order to steal from it
raid.eg: Millions of dollars were stolen in a bank raid last night.

raid.eng_def: an occasion when the police enter a place suddenly in order to find someone or something
raid.eg: The drugs were found during a police raid on the house.
The nomads raided the enemy camp and captured over 100 camels.

raid.eng_def: to enter a place illegally and usually violently, and steal from it
raid.eg: The post office was raided late at night.

raid.eng_def: (of the police) to enter a place suddenly in order to find someone or something
raid.eg: Police officers from the organized crime division have raided businesses in central London.

raid.eng_def: to take something from a place, usually secretly
raid.chi_def: （通常指偷偷地）從…把東西拿走，取走（某處的）東西
raid.eg: I caught Toby raiding the fridge.

rail.eng_def: the system of transport that uses trains
rail.chi_def: 鐵路交通；鐵路交通系統
rail.eg: Environmentalists argue that more goods should be transported by rail.

rail.eng_def: one of the two metal bars attached to the ground on which trains travel
rail.eg: A train left/went off the rails and crashed into the bank, killing several passengers.

rail.eng_def: a horizontal bar fixed in position, especially to a wall or to vertical posts, used to close something off, as a support, or to hang things on
rail.chi_def: （尤指固定在牆上或豎杆上的）橫杆，欄杆，扶手
rail.eg: Will spectators please stay behind the rail?
He railed against/at the injustices of the system.

railroad.eng_def: the metal tracks on which trains run
railroad.eg: We live close to the railroad line.

railroad.eng_def: the system of tracks, stations, trains, etc.
to force something to happen or force someone to do something, especially quickly or unfairly
railroad.chi_def: （尤指以倉促或不公正的方式）強迫，迫使
railroad.eg: We were railroaded into signing the agreement.

rain.eng_def: the season of the year in tropical countries when there is a lot of rain
rain.eg: Villagers are now waiting for the rains to come so that the rice will grow.

rain.eng_def: If it rains, water falls from the sky in small drops.
rain.eg: I think it's starting to rain.

rainbow.eng_def: an arch (= curved shape) of different colours seen in the sky when rain is falling and the sun is shining
rainbow.eg: The sun came out and we saw a rainbow.

rainfall.eng_def: rain, or the amount of rain that falls

rainy.eg: We had three rainy days on holiday, but otherwise it was sunny.

raise.eng_def: to lift something to a higher position
raise.eg: Would all those in favour please raise their hands?

raise.eng_def: to cause something to increase or become bigger, better, higher, etc.
raise.eg: The government plan to raise taxes.
Her answers raised doubts/fears/suspicions in my mind.

raise.eng_def: to take care of a person, or an animal or plant, until they are completely grown
raise.eg: Her parents died when she was a baby and she was raised by her grandparents.

raise.eng_def: If you raise another player in a game of cards, you risk more money than that player has risked.
raise.chi_def: （賭牌時）比對手多下賭注，提高（賭注），加賭注

raise.eg: They agreed to raise the trade embargo if three conditions were met.

raise.eng_def: to communicate with someone, especially by phone or radio
raise.chi_def: （尤指透過電話或無線電）與…取得聯繫，與…通話
raise.eg: I've been trying to raise Jack/Tokyo all day.

raise.eng_def: an increase in the amount that you are paid for the work you do
raise.eg: She asked the boss for a raise.

rally.eng_def: a public meeting of a large group of people, especially supporters of a particular opinion
rally.chi_def: （尤指為表明支援某種主張的）集會，群衆大會

rally.eng_def: a car or motorcycle race, especially over long distances on public roads
rally.chi_def: （尤指長距離的）公路汽車賽；（汽車或機車）拉力賽
rally.eg: The French driver has taken the lead in the Paris-Dakar rally.

rally.eng_def: a continuous exchange of hits between players in tennis, squash or badminton
rally.chi_def: （網球等比賽中）持續對打，相持，拉鋸戲

rally.eg: Share prices fell again today after yesterday's rally.

rally.eng_def: to (cause to) come together in order to provide support or make a shared effort
rally.eg: Supporters/Opponents of the new shopping development are trying to rally local people in favour of/against it.

rally.eng_def: to return to a better condition
rally.eg: The nurse said my mother had rallied after a poor night.

ranch.eng_def: a very large farm on which animals are kept, especially in North and South America

random.eng_def: happening, done, or chosen by chance rather than according to a plan

random.eg: I just saw Billy wearing a top hat - he's so random!

random.eng_def: by chance, or without being chosen intentionally
random.eg: The winning entry will be the first correct answer drawn at random.

range.eg: I offered her a range of options.

range.eng_def: the goods made by one company or goods of one particular type that are sold in a shop
range.chi_def: （某公司生産或某商店出售的）某一類産品，某一系列産品
range.eg: We stock the full range of model railway accessories.

range.eng_def: a group of hills or mountains
the amount, number, or type of something between an upper and a lower limit
range.chi_def: （數量、種類等變化的）範圍，幅度，區域
range.eg: The price range is from $100 to $500.

range.eng_def: the distance within which you can see, hear, or hit someone
range.eg: The ship was in/out of range of our guns.

range.eng_def: the period of time in the future within which something is planned or expected to happen
range.chi_def: （計劃、預期的）期限，時間段，時間範圍

range.eng_def: the distance that a vehicle or aircraft can travel without having to stop for more fuel
range.chi_def: （車輛、飛機）加一次油可行駛的距離

range.eng_def: all the musical notes that a singer can sing or a musical instrument is able to produce
an area where people can practise shooting or where bombs or other weapons can be tested
range.chi_def: 射擊場，靶場；（武器）試射場
range.eg: The soldiers were practising on the rifle/shooting range.

range.eng_def: land for animals to feed on
range.eg: The cowboys were herding the cattle on the range.

range.eng_def: an old type of cooker, with one or more ovens and cooking surfaces, that is heated with wood or coal and is kept hot all the time
range.chi_def: （燒木材或煤長期不熄火、單眼或多眼的老式）爐灶

range.eng_def: a large box-shaped device that is used to cook and heat food, either by putting the food inside or by putting it on the top
range.eg: She was cooking soup on the range.

range.eng_def: to have an upper and a lower limit in amount, number, etc.
range.chi_def: （數量、種類等變化的）範圍，幅度，區域
range.eg: Dress sizes range from petite to extra large.

range.eng_def: to position people or things together, especially in rows
range.eg: The crowd ranged itself along the route of the procession.
The hens range freely about/over the farm.

range.eng_def: (of a piece of writing or speech) to deal with
range.eg: Our discussion ranged over many current issues.

rank.eng_def: a position in an organization, such as the army, showing the importance of the person having it
a particular position, higher or lower than others
rank.eg: He's in the front/first rank of (= one of the best) international tennis players.

rank.eng_def: the members of a group or organization
rank.eg: Party ranks have swelled by nearly 300,000.

rank.eng_def: to be moved up from a low level position in an organization to a higher one
rank.chi_def: （從很低的職位）擢升，步步高升
rank.eg: He rose through the ranks to become a general.

rank.eng_def: a row, especially of people or things standing side by side
rank.eg: The front rank of the riot squad raised their shields.

rank.eng_def: a place where taxis wait for passengers
rank.eg: There were no taxis at the taxi/cab rank.

rank.eng_def: (especially of something bad) complete or extreme
rank.chi_def: （尤指壞事）完全的，十足的，極端的
rank.eg: It was rank stupidity to drive so fast on an icy road.

rank.eng_def: used to describe plants that grow too fast or too thickly, or an area covered by these
rank.chi_def: （植物）瘋長的，蕪生蔓長的；（地方）長滿（雜草）的
rank.eg: The abandoned garden was rank with weeds.
His clothes were rank with sweat.

rank.eng_def: to have a position higher or lower than others, or to be considered to have such a position
rank.chi_def: 具有…的地位（或等級）；把…分等級；確定…的地位（或等級）
rank.eg: A captain ranks (= has a position) above a lieutenant.

ransom.eng_def: a large amount of money that is demanded in exchange for someone who has been taken prisoner, or sometimes for an animal
to pay money in order to set someone free
ransom.eg: Her father ransomed her for a million dollars.

rapid.eg: The 1990s were a period of rapid change/growth.

rare.chi_def: 稀少的；罕見的；不常發生的

rare.eng_def: (of meat) not cooked for very long and still red
rare.eg: I'd like my steak rare, please.

rare.eng_def: used to describe the air at the top of a mountain, which contains less oxygen, making it harder to breathe

rascal.eng_def: a person, especially a child or a man, who does things that you disapprove of, but who you still like
rascal.eg: I caught those little/young rascals dressing up in my clothes.

rash.eng_def: a lot of small red spots on the skin
rash.eg: I've got an itchy rash all over my chest.

rash.eng_def: a large number of unpleasant events of the same type
rash.chi_def: （一下子出現的）大量令人不快的事
rash.eg: There has been a rash of robberies/accidents/complaints in the last two months.

rash.eng_def: careless or unwise, without thought for what might happen or result
rash.eg: That was a rash decision - you didn't think about the costs involved.

rat.eng_def: a small rodent, larger than a mouse, that has a long tail and is considered to be harmful
an unpleasant person who deceives others or is not loyal
rat.chi_def: 卑鄙小人；騙子；背信棄義的人

rate.eng_def: the speed at which something happens or changes, or the amount or number of times it happens or changes in a particular period
rate.eg: Although she's recovering from her illness, her rate of progress is quite slow.

rate.eng_def: an amount or level of payment
rate.eg: We agreed a rate with the painter before he started work.

rate.eng_def: a local tax paid in Australia, and in Britain in the past, by the owners of houses and other buildings
rate.chi_def: （澳大利亞以及舊時英國的）房産稅，房地産稅

rate.eng_def: to judge the value or character of someone or something
rate.eg: How do you rate him as a football player?

rate.eng_def: to be considered to be something of a particular quality
rate.eg: That rates as the worst film I've ever seen.

rate.eng_def: In Britain in the past, a building was rated to decide how much local tax the owner should pay.
rate.chi_def: （舊時英國為收房產稅而）給（房屋）核定應繳稅款

rate.eng_def: used with words such as first, second, etc. to show how good you think something is
rate.chi_def: 級別；水準；質量（與 first、second 等詞連用，表明你認為某物的優劣如何）
rate.eg: His suggestions are always first-rate (= very good).

rather.eg: It's rather cold today, isn't it?
She'll fly to California on Thursday, or rather, she will if she has to.

rather.eng_def: used to express an opposite opinion
rather.eg: The ending of the war is not a cause for celebration, but rather for regret that it ever happened.

rather.eng_def: instead of; used especially when you prefer one thing to another
rather.eg: I think I'd like to stay at home this evening rather than go out.
Actually, I did rather well in my exams.
"Do you want to come out for dinner with us this evening?" "Rather!"

ratio.eng_def: the relationship between two groups or amounts that expresses how much bigger one is than the other
ratio.eg: The ratio of men to women at the conference was ten to one/10:1.

rational.eng_def: based on clear thought and reason
rational.eg: There must be some rational explanation for what happened.

rattle.eng_def: a sound similar to a series of quickly repeated knocks
rattle.chi_def: （連續重複的）嗒嗒聲，嘎嘎聲；連續短促的碰撞聲
rattle.eg: From across the town came the rattle of machine-gun fire.

rattle.eng_def: a toy that makes a noise like a series of knocks
rattle.eg: The baby was waving around a plastic rattle.

rattle.eng_def: a wooden device that when turned round and round produces a noise like a series of knocks
rattle.chi_def: （轉動時發出嗒嗒聲的木制）響板

rattle.eng_def: the part of a rattlesnake's tail that produces a noise
to worry someone or make someone nervous
rattle.eg: The creaking upstairs was starting to rattle me.

rattle.eng_def: to (cause something to) make a noise like a series of knocks
rattle.chi_def: （使）發出連串的敲擊聲；（使）發出嘎嘎聲
rattle.eg: The explosion rattled the cups on the table.

ravage.eng_def: to cause great damage to something
ravage.eg: The area has been ravaged by drought/floods/war.

raw.chi_def: （食物）生的，未經烹調的，沒煮的

raw.eng_def: (of materials) in a natural state, without having been through any chemical or industrial process
raw.chi_def: 原料未經加工的，自然狀態的
raw.eg: Oil is an important raw material that can be processed into many different products, including plastics.

raw.eng_def: Raw information has been collected but has not yet been studied in detail.
raw.chi_def: （資訊）沒有經過處理的，未經分析的，原始的

raw.eng_def: used to refer to a person who is not trained or is without experience
raw.chi_def: （人）無經驗的，未經訓練的，生疏無知的
raw.eg: I would prefer not to leave this job to John while he's still a raw recruit/beginner.

raw.eng_def: Feelings or qualities that are raw are natural and difficult to control.
raw.chi_def: （感情、品質）等處於自然狀態的，強烈的，粗獷的
raw.eg: We were struck by the raw energy/power of the dancers' performances.

raw.eng_def: A piece of writing that is raw is one that does not try to hide anything about its subject.
raw.chi_def: （文字）不加掩飾的，如實坦陳的，反映真實情況的
raw.eg: His new play is a raw drama about family life.

raw.eng_def: sore or painful because of being rubbed or damaged
raw.chi_def: （肌肉）擦掉表皮而外露的；（傷口）露肉而刺痛的；創痛的
raw.eg: The shoe had rubbed a raw place on her heel.

raw.eng_def: used to describe weather that is very cold

ray.eng_def: a narrow beam of light, heat, etc. travelling in a straight line from its place of origin
ray.chi_def: 光線，光束；（熱能等的）輻射線
ray.eg: A ray of sunshine shone through a gap in the clouds.

ray.eng_def: to stay outside in the sun for a period of time
ray.eg: I'm going out to catch a few rays before lunch.

ray.eng_def: a small amount of a feeling that makes you feel happier or more full of hope
ray.chi_def: 一線，少量的（積極情感或希望等）
ray.eg: There's still a ray of hope that the missing child will be found alive.

ray.eng_def: a large, flat sea fish with a long, narrow tail

ray.chi_def: 長音階第二音；C大調第二音（同 re）

razor.eng_def: a small device with a sharp blade for removing hair, especially from the face or legs
razor.chi_def: （尤指刮鬍鬚或腳毛的）剃刀，刮鬍刀，剃鬚刀
razor.eg: Do you use an electric razor or the kind that you have to put a razor blade in?

razor.eng_def: to cut something such as hair using a razor
razor.eg: She razored the hair in long wispy layers.

reach.eng_def: to arrive at a place, especially after spending a long time or a lot of effort travelling
reach.chi_def: （尤指經過很長時間或費很大氣力旅行後）到達，抵達
reach.eg: We won't reach Miami until five or six o'clock.

reach.eng_def: to make a decision, agreement, etc. about something
reach.chi_def: 作出決定／達成協定／得出結論等
reach.eg: She reached the conclusion that there was no more she could do.

reach.eng_def: to get to a particular level, especially a high one
reach.chi_def: 達到，發展到，提升到（尤指高的水準等）
reach.eg: The temperature is expected to reach 30°C today.

reach.eng_def: to stretch out your arm in order to get or touch something
reach.chi_def: 伸出手臂（去拿或觸摸），伸手及到
reach.eg: She's grown so tall that she can reach the door handle now.

reach.eng_def: If an object reaches something, the top or bottom of it touches that thing.
reach.eg: The ladder won't quite reach the top of the wall.

reach.eng_def: to communicate with someone in a different place, especially by phone or email
reach.chi_def: （尤指透過電話或信件）和…聯繫，與…取得聯繫
reach.eg: I've been trying to reach you on the phone all day.

reach.eng_def: to understand and communicate with someone
reach.eg: He's a strange child and his teachers find it difficult to reach him.

reach.eng_def: Your reach is the distance within which you can stretch out your arm and touch something.
reach.eg: I like to keep a notebook and pencil within (arm's) reach.

reach.eng_def: the distance that can be travelled, especially easily
reach.eg: We live within (easy) reach of the station.

reach.eng_def: the length of your arm when you stretch it out
reach.eg: You've got quite a long reach - can you get that box down from the top shelf for me?

reach.eng_def: an act of stretching out your arm
reach.eg: He made a sudden reach for his gun.

reach.eng_def: the limit within which someone can achieve something
reach.eg: An expensive trip like that would be completely beyond/out of (my) reach (= I would not have enough money to pay for it).

reach.eng_def: a part of a river or part of an area of land
reach.eg: The expedition set out for the upper reaches of the Amazon.

reach.eng_def: the highest or lowest levels of an organization
reach.chi_def: （一個組織中最高或最低的）層次，等級
reach.eg: The news has shocked the upper reaches of the government.

react.eng_def: to act in a particular way as a direct result of something else
react.eg: She slapped him and called him names, but he didn't react.

react.eng_def: to change in a physical or chemical way when put with another substance

reaction.eng_def: behaviour, a feeling or an action that is a direct result of something else
reaction.eg: I love to watch people's reactions when I say who I am.

reaction.eng_def: someone's ability to act quickly when something happens
reaction.chi_def: （對突發事件的）反應能力，反應靈敏度
reaction.eg: You need to have quick reactions to play these computer games.

reaction.eng_def: a type of behaviour or opinion that is produced or held with the intention of being different from something else
reaction.eg: Her left-wing views are a reaction against the conservatism of her parents.

reaction.eng_def: an unpleasant effect resulting from eating particular things or taking particular drugs
reaction.chi_def: （對食物、藥物等的）不良反應，過敏
reaction.eg: Some people have an allergic reaction to shellfish.

reaction.eng_def: an occasion when two or more substances react with and change each other
the belief or principle that there should be no social or political change, and the attempt to stop such change from happening
reaction.eg: We must not allow reaction to stand in the way of progress.

read.eng_def: to look at words or symbols and understand what they mean
read.eg: He spent a pleasant afternoon reading (the newspaper/a book).

read.eng_def: to say the words that are printed or written
read.eg: She read (the poem) slowly and quietly.

read.eng_def: to understand and give a particular meaning to written information, a statement, a situation, etc.
read.chi_def: 理解；讀作；（用於訂正訛誤）改作，換用
read.eg: She missed the train because she read 18.30 p.m. as 8.30 p.m. instead of 6.30 p.m.

read.eng_def: How you read a piece of writing, or how it reads, is how it seems when you read it
read.chi_def: 讀起來（給人某種印象）；看著好像是…
read.eg: The letter reads as if it was written in a hurry.

read.eng_def: (especially when communicating by radio), to hear and understand someone
read.chi_def: （尤指用無線電聯絡時）聽到，收聽到

read.eng_def: to read aloud to someone until they go to sleep
read.chi_def: 給（某人）讀書（或故事）使其入睡
read.eg: Every night when I was a child my father used to read me to sleep.

read.eng_def: (of something written or printed) to have or give the stated information or meaning
read.eg: The start of the US Constitution reads "We, the people of the United States..."

read.eng_def: to study at university or to study for a specialized qualification
read.eg: They're both reading history at Cambridge.
It's not brilliant but it's worth a read.

ready.eng_def: prepared and suitable for fast activity
ready.chi_def: 準備好的，有準備的；現成的；方便使用的
準備好並等待著；準備好隨時行動
ready.eg: Secret information allowed the police to be ready and waiting when the robbers came out of the bank.

ready.eng_def: quick with answers, jokes, solutions, etc.
ready.eg: He had a ready reply to every question.

ready.eng_def: prepared to be used or to act immediately
ready.chi_def: 準備好；可隨時使用；可隨時採取行動
ready.eg: He stood by the phone, pencil at the ready.

real.eng_def: existing in fact and not imaginary
real.chi_def: 實際存在的，現實的；真實的
real.eg: Assuring the patient that she has a real and not imaginary problem is the first step.

real.eng_def: the value of earnings, etc. after the effect of rising prices is considered
real.chi_def: （把物價上漲因素考慮在內的）實際收入
real.eg: Wages rose by 2.9 percent last year, but real earnings still fell by 1.3 percent.

real.eng_def: after considering things that affect what a number or amount really means, such as the effect of rising prices
real.eg: Average earnings rose 5 percent in real terms after deducting income tax.

real.eng_def: things as they really are, not as they exist in the imagination, in a story, on the internet, etc.
real.chi_def: 真實世界（而非存在於想像、故事和網路中的）
real.eg: Over-protecting children does not equip them to deal with the real world.

real.eng_def: being what it appears to be and not false
(especially of foods) produced using traditional methods and without artificial substances
real.chi_def: （尤指食物）正宗的，用傳統手藝做的
real.eg: The pub sells several kinds of real ale (= traditional beer).
I thought it was just a drill but apparently it was for real.

real.chi_def: 最重要的；主要的；真正關鍵的
real.eg: The real difficulty was the language, because my children don't speak English.

real.chi_def: （用於強調名詞）真正的，地道的，十足的

real.eg: I like this homemade lemonade, it's real good!

realism.eng_def: a way of thinking and acting based on facts and what is possible, rather than on hopes for things that are unlikely to happen
realism.chi_def: 現實（性）；務實作風；注重實際
realism.eg: His decision not to expand the business shows his down-to-earth realism.

realism.eng_def: in science and philosophy, the belief that objects continue to exist in the world even when no one is there to see them
realism.chi_def: （科學或哲學的）實在主義，實在論，唯實論

realism.eng_def: paintings, films, books, etc. that try to represent life as it really is
realism.chi_def: （繪畫、電影、書籍等的）現實主義，現實主義風格
realism.eg: The director used handheld camera techniques to add to the gritty realism of the film.

realistic.eng_def: accepting things as they are in fact and not making decisions based on unlikely hopes for the future
realistic.chi_def: 現實的；實事求是的；務實的
realistic.eg: Let's be realistic (about this) - I just can't afford to pay that much money.

realistic.eng_def: seeming to exist or be happening in fact
realistic.eg: The special effects were so realistic.

reality.eng_def: the state of things as they are, rather than as they are imagined to be
reality.eg: The reality of the situation is that unless we find some new funding soon, the youth centre will have to close.
The book confronts the harsh social and political realities of the world today.

realization.eng_def: the fact or moment of starting to understand a situation
realization.eg: The realization was dawning that this was a major disaster.

realization.eng_def: the act or moment of achieving something you planned to do or hoped for
realization.eg: To win the Olympic gold medal was the realization of his life's dream.

realization.eng_def: the act of getting money by selling something
realization.eg: Even the realization of all his assets would not be enough to prevent financial ruin.

realize.eng_def: to understand a situation, sometimes suddenly
realize.eg: They didn't realize the danger they were in.

realize.eng_def: to achieve something you were hoping for
realize.chi_def: 實現；使變為事實；使發生
realize.eg: Lots of money, a luxury house, a fast car - Danny had realized all his ambitions by the age of 25.

realize.eng_def: used for saying that something that someone was worrying about really happened
realize.eg: Ten years later her worst fears were realized.

realize.eng_def: to be sold for a particular amount of money
realize.eg: The paintings are expected to realize $500,000 each.

realize.eng_def: to sell property in order to get some money
realize.eg: He had to realize all his assets to pay off his debts.

realm.eng_def: an area of interest or activity
realm.eg: Her interests are in the realm of practical politics.

realm.eng_def: a country ruled by a king or queen

reap.eng_def: to cut and collect a grain crop

rear.eg: There's a sticker on the rear door/window.
We walked round to the rear of the house.

rear.eng_def: to care for young animals or children until they are able to care for themselves
rear.eg: Some women make a deliberate choice to rear a child alone.

rear.eng_def: to rise up or to lift something up
rear.eg: The horse reared (up) (= suddenly rose onto its back legs) when it heard the gun shot.

reason.eng_def: the cause of an event or situation or something that provides an excuse or explanation
reason.eg: The reason for the disaster was engine failure, not human error.
He's always asked to these occasions by reason of his position.

reason.eng_def: the ability of a healthy mind to think and make judgments, especially based on practical facts
reason.chi_def: （尤指基於實際情況的）判斷力，理性，理智
reason.eg: We humans believe that we are the only animals to have the power of reason.

reason.eng_def: within the limits of what is acceptable and possible
reason.chi_def: 合情合理；有分寸；有道理
reason.eg: We can wear anything we like to the office, within reason.

reason.eng_def: to try to understand and to make judgments based on practical facts
reason.eg: Newton reasoned (that) there must be a force such as gravity

reasonable.eng_def: based on or using good judgment and therefore fair and practical
reasonable.chi_def: 合情理的；講道理的；公平的
reasonable.eg: If you tell him what happened, I'm sure he'll understand - he's a reasonable man.

reasonable.chi_def: 可以接受的；合意的；尚好的

reasonable.eg: Tomatoes are very reasonable at this time of year.

rebel.eng_def: a person who is opposed to the political system in their country and tries to change it using force
rebel.chi_def: （試圖武裝推翻國家政治制度的）反抗者，造反者
rebel.eg: The rebels took over the capital and set up a new government.

rebel.eng_def: a person who does not like rules or authority, and shows this by behaving differently from most people in society
rebel.eg: He was a rebel when he was a teenager and dyed his hair pink.
The people rebelled against the harsh new government.

rebel.eng_def: to refuse to obey rules or people in authority
rebel.eg: Jacob rebelled against his parents' plans for him and left school at the age of 16.

rebel.eng_def: to react against a feeling, action, plan, etc.
rebel.eg: My poor sick stomach rebelled at the idea of any more food.

rebellion.eng_def: violent action organized by a group of people who are trying to change the political system in their country
rebellion.eg: The government has brutally crushed the rebellion.

rebellion.eng_def: action against those in authority, against the rules, or against normal and accepted ways of behaving
rebellion.eg: a backbench rebellion against the new foreign policy

recall.eng_def: to bring the memory of a past event into your mind, and often to give a description of what you remember
recall.eg: The old man recalled the city as it had been before the war.

recall.eng_def: to cause you to think of a particular event, situation, or style
recall.chi_def: 使聯想起；使想到；勾起（聯想）
recall.eg: His paintings recall the style of Picasso.

recall.eng_def: to order the return of a person who belongs to an organization or of products made by a company
recall.eg: The ambassador was recalled when war broke out.
Old people often have astonishing powers of recall.

recall.eng_def: an occasion when someone orders the return of a person who belongs to an organization, or orders the return of products made by a company

receipt.eng_def: a piece of paper that proves that money, goods, or information have been received
receipt.eg: Make sure you are given a receipt for everything you buy.

receipt.eng_def: the act or state of receiving money or goods
receipt.eg: Goods will be delivered on receipt of payment (= after the money is received).

receipt.eng_def: the amounts of money received during a particular period by a business
receipt.eg: The theatre's receipts for the winter were badly down.

receive.eng_def: to get or be given something
(of a radio or television) to change a signal into sounds and pictures
to be able to hear someone's voice when they are communicating with you by radio
receive.chi_def: （用無線電通話時）收聽到，聽得到
receive.eg: I'm receiving you loud and clear.

receive.eng_def: to formally welcome a visitor or guest
receive.eg: She stood by the door to receive her guests as they arrived.

receive.eng_def: to meet someone when they arrive somewhere
receive.eg: My friend offered to receive me at the railway station.

receive.eng_def: to react to something or someone in a particular way that shows how you feel about it, him, or her
receive.eg: The speech was well/warmly/coldly, etc. received by the conference delegates.

receive.eng_def: to be made a member of an organization
receive.eg: He was received into the church.

receiver.eng_def: the part of a phone in two parts that you hold to your ear and mouth
receiver.eg: She picked up the receiver and dialled his number.

receiver.eng_def: a piece of equipment that changes radio and television signals into sounds and pictures
receiver.chi_def: （無線電或電視）接收器，接收機

receiver.eng_def: a person who officially deals with the business matters of companies who cannot pay their debts
receiver.eg: The company went bankrupt and was put into the hands of the receivers.

receiver.eng_def: A receiver of stolen goods is a person who buys and sells property that they know has been stolen.

recent.eng_def: happening or starting from a short time ago

reception.eng_def: a formal party at which important people are welcomed
reception.eg: The president gave a reception for the visiting heads of state.

reception.eng_def: the way in which people react to something or someone
reception.eg: Her first book got a wonderful/warm/frosty reception from the critics.

reception.eng_def: the act of welcoming someone or something
reception.eg: The new hospital was ready for the reception of its first patients.

reception.eng_def: the place in a hotel or office building where people go when they first arrive
reception.chi_def: （飯店或辦公樓的）接待處，服務台，前臺

reception.eng_def: the degree to which mobile phone, radio, or television signals are strong and clear
reception.chi_def: （收音機或電視信號）接收效果，接收質量
reception.eg: The phone reception is really bad out here in the woods.

reception.eng_def: the first year of infant school

recession.eng_def: a period when the economy of a country is not successful and conditions for business are bad
recession.eg: The country is sliding into the depths of (a) recession.

recipe.eng_def: a set of instructions telling you how to prepare and cook food, including a list of what food is needed for this
recipe.eg: For real South Asian food, just follow these recipes.

recipient.eg: Former Nobel Peace Prize recipients include Jimmy Carter and Barack Obama.

recite.eng_def: to say a piece of writing aloud from memory, or to publicly say a list of things
recite.eg: She proudly recited the Pledge of Allegiance.

reckless.eng_def: doing something dangerous and not worrying about the risks and the possible results
reckless.chi_def: 魯莽的；輕率的；不顧後果的
reckless.eg: He was found guilty of reckless driving.

reckon.eg: I reckon it's going to rain.

reckon.eng_def: to consider or have the opinion that something is as stated
reckon.eg: I don't reckon much to (US of) their chances of winning (= I do not think they will win).
Angela quickly reckoned the amount on her fingers.

recognition.eng_def: agreement that something is true or legal
recognition.eg: It's a new country, hoping for diplomatic recognition from the international community.

recognition.eng_def: If you are given recognition, people show admiration and respect for your achievements.
recognition.eg: Ella complained that the company never gave her any recognition for her work.

recognition.eng_def: the fact of knowing someone or something because you have seen or heard him or her or experienced it before
recognition.eg: When he returned to his home town after the war, he found it had changed out of all/beyond all recognition (= it had changed so much that he no longer recognized it).

recognize.eng_def: to know someone or something because you have seen or heard him or her or experienced it before
recognize.eg: I hadn't seen her for 20 years, but I recognized her immediately.

recognize.eng_def: to accept that something is legal, true, or important
recognize.eg: The international community has refused to recognize (= officially accept the existence of) the newly independent nation state.

recognize.eng_def: If a person's achievements are recognized, official approval is shown for them.
recognize.eg: The Queen recognized his services to his country by awarding him an MBE.

recommend.eng_def: to suggest that someone or something would be good or suitable for a particular job or purpose, or to suggest that a particular action should be done
recommend.eg: I can recommend the chicken in mushroom sauce - it's delicious.

recommendation.eng_def: a suggestion that something is good or suitable for a particular purpose or job
recommendation.eg: I bought this computer on John's recommendation (= because John told me that it was good).

recommendation.eng_def: advice telling someone what the best thing to do is
recommendation.eg: The report makes the recommendation that no more prisons should be built.

reconcile.eng_def: to find a way in which two situations or beliefs that are opposed to each other can agree and exist together
reconcile.eg: It is sometimes difficult to reconcile science and religion.

reconcile.eng_def: When two people are reconciled, they become friendly again after they have argued.
reconcile.eg: They were finally reconciled with each other, after not speaking for nearly five years.

record.eng_def: to store sounds or moving pictures using electronic equipment so that they can be heard or seen later
record.eg: Cliff Richard has recorded more number one hit songs than any other British pop star.

record.eng_def: to keep information for the future, by writing it down or storing it on a computer
record.eg: She records everything that happens to her in her diary.

record.eng_def: If a device records a measurement, it shows that measurement.
record.eg: The thermometer recorded a temperature of 30 degrees Celsius.

record.eng_def: a piece of information or a description of an event that is written on paper or stored on a computer
record.eg: The weather centre keeps a record of the weather.

record.eng_def: information about someone or something that is stored by the police or by a doctor
record.eg: A person's medical records are confidential.

record.eng_def: the facts that are known about a person or a company and the actions they have done in the past
record.eg: I won't fly with an airline that has a bad safety record (= whose aircraft have often had accidents).

record.eng_def: something that you say before you tell someone something important that you want them to remember
record.chi_def: （用於對聽話人強調所說之話的重要性）為記錄在案目的
record.eg: And, just for the record, we were never any more than good friends.

record.eng_def: a flat plastic disc on which music is recorded
record.eg: Would you like to listen to some records?

record.eng_def: a song or music that has been recorded and is available for the public to buy
record.eg: The Beatles' first hit record was "Love Me Do".

record.eng_def: the best or fastest ever done
record.eg: He ran the 100 metres in 9.79 seconds and broke/smashed the world record.

record.eng_def: at a higher level than ever achieved before
record.eg: The long hot summer has led to a record harvest this year.

recorder.eng_def: a musical instrument consisting of a wooden or plastic tube that you blow down while covering holes with your fingers
a  cassette recorder , a  tape recorder  or a  video recorder
recorder.chi_def: 盒式磁帶錄放機，磁帶錄音機；盒式磁帶錄像機

recover.eng_def: to become completely well again after an illness or injury
recover.chi_def: （在疾病或受傷之後）完全恢復健康
recover.eg: It took her a long time to recover from/after her heart operation.

recover.eng_def: to become successful or normal again after being damaged or having problems
recover.chi_def: （在被破壞或出現問題之後）恢復正常，再獲成功
recover.eg: It took a long time for the economy to recover after the slump.

recover.eng_def: to get back something lost or spent
recover.eg: She went into a coma and died without recovering consciousness.

recovery.eng_def: the process of becoming well again after an illness or injury
recovery.chi_def: （在疾病或受傷之後）恢復健康
recovery.eg: Mira made a full recovery from the operation.

recovery.eng_def: the process of becoming successful or normal again after problems
recovery.chi_def: （在出現問題之後）再獲成功，恢復正常
recovery.eg: At last the economy is showing signs of recovery.

recovery.eng_def: the process of getting something back
recovery.eg: The police arranged the recovery of the body from the river.

recreation.eng_def: (a way of) enjoying yourself when you are not working
recreation.eg: His favourite recreations are golf and playing Scrabble.

recreation.eng_def: the act of making something exist or happen again
recreation.eg: a recreation of one of the most famous events in history

recreational.eg: Prescription painkillers are being used as recreational drugs.

recruit.eng_def: to persuade someone to work for a company or become a new member of an organization, especially the army
recruit.chi_def: 招聘，吸收；（尤指軍隊）徵募新兵
recruit.eg: Charities such as Oxfam are always trying to recruit volunteers to help in their work.

recruit.eng_def: a new member of an organization, especially the army
recruit.chi_def: 新成員，新來的人；（尤指）新兵
recruit.eg: Raw recruits (= completely new soldiers) were trained for six months and then sent to the war front.

rectangle.eng_def: a flat shape with four 90° angles and four sides, with opposite sides of equal length

recur.eng_def: to happen many times or to happen again
recur.chi_def: 反復出現；再次發生；重新産生
recur.eg: The theme of freedom recurs throughout her writing.

recycle.eng_def: to sort and collect rubbish in order to treat it and produce useful materials that can be used again
recycle.chi_def: 分揀收集（垃圾）用於回收再用
recycle.eg: The Japanese recycle more than half their waste paper.

recycle.eng_def: to use something again for a different purpose
recycle.eg: Why not recycle Christmas cards as gift tags?

red.eng_def: of the colour of fresh blood
used to describe hair that is an orange-brown colour
If you go/turn red, your face becomes red because you are angry or embarrassed.
red.chi_def: （因為憤怒或窘迫）臉漲得通紅的
red.eg: Look, you've embarrassed him - he's gone bright red!

red.eng_def: If your eyes are red, the white part of your eyes and the skin around your eyes is red, because of crying, tiredness, too much alcohol, etc.
red.chi_def: （眼睛）布滿血絲的，紅腫的，充血的

red.eg: She uses a lot of reds and pinks in her paintings.

red.eng_def: a person who has socialist or communist political opinions
red.chi_def: 社會主義者；共産主義者；赤色分子

reduce.eng_def: to become or to make something become smaller in size, amount, degree, importance, etc.
reduce.eg: Do nuclear weapons really reduce the risk of war?

reduce.eng_def: to heat a liquid until it becomes thicker and less in quantity; to become thicker and less in quantity in this way
reduce.chi_def: （通過加熱）使（液體）變稠；（液體因加熱而）變稠
reduce.eg: Reduce the sauce by boiling for five minutes.

reduction.eng_def: the act of making something, or of something becoming, smaller in size, amount, degree, importance, etc.
a copy of a photograph, picture, etc. that is smaller than the original one
reduction.chi_def: 縮影（照片或圖片的一個複製本，比原來的圖像小）

redundant.eng_def: (especially of a word, phrase, etc.) unnecessary because it is more than is needed
redundant.chi_def: （尤指詞、片語等）多餘的，不需要的，累贅的，囉唆的
redundant.eg: In the sentence "She is a single unmarried woman", the word "unmarried" is redundant.

redundant.eng_def: having lost your job because your employer no longer needs you
redundant.chi_def: 失業的，被解僱的，被裁減的
redundant.eg: To keep the company alive, half the workforce is being made redundant.

reef.eng_def: a line of rocks or sand just above or just below the surface of the sea, often dangerous to ships

reel.eng_def: a round, wheel-shaped object on which sewing thread, fishing wire, film, etc. can be rolled, or the amount of thread, etc. stored on one of these
reel.chi_def: 捲軸；捲筒；捲盤；繞在捲軸上的線

reel.eng_def: a fast Scottish or Irish dance, or the music for this
reel.chi_def: 裡爾舞（一種輕快的蘇格蘭或愛爾蘭舞蹈）；裡爾舞曲

reel.eng_def: to walk, moving from side to side, looking like you are going to fall
reel.chi_def: 踉蹌；打趔趄；蹣跚；搖搖晃晃地挪動
reel.eg: At closing time he reeled out of the bar and fell down on the pavement.

reel.eng_def: If the place where you are reels, what you are looking at seems to go round and round in front of you.
reel.eg: A stone hit his head and the street reeled before his eyes.

reel.eng_def: If you reel, or your mind or brain reels, you feel very confused or shocked and unable to act.
reel.eg: We were reeling (in amazement/shock/delight, etc.) from/with the news that we had won all that money.
